Why is that? \n \n\u201cOn offense, just generally speaking, there are more things that can go wrong than can on the defensive side of the ball,\u201d Theismann said in a telephone interview. \n \nHe won the Super Bowl in 1983 and lost it the following year after having directed Washington to a then-record 541 points in the regular season. \n \nOne of his Redskins\u2019 NFC East rivals back then were the New York Giants, where Belichick was the defensive coordinator during the 1985-90 seasons. \n \n\u201cA lot of offenses go through one or two players, and so a defense \u2014 and Bill is great at this \u2014 will focus on a particular player or a particular concept and that\u2019s where they will make sure to stop the opponent,\u201d Theismann said. \n \n\u201cYou can\u2019t really do the same thing on offense and say, \u2018Who do we want to go after?\u2019 It\u2019s tough to pick out one person. You\u2019re not going to isolate on a particular linebacker or a corner. There is just less susceptibility to that on defense.\u201d \n \nIn New England\u2019s 36-17 victory over Pittsburgh in the AFC title game last weekend, for example, the Patriots made sure to limit what Steelers star receiver Antonio Brown did. \n \nHis catches amounted to only 77 yards, with no TDs. \n \n\u201cBill basically uses common sense: \u2018If you have one player who\u2019s really good, let\u2019s see how you play without him.\u2019 They weren\u2019t going to allow Antonio Brown to make plays. They said, \u2018Look, we\u2019re going to bump him at the line, put somebody over the top, and you\u2019re going to have to make plays with the other nine players.\u2019 If a defense can limit 20-25 percent of an offense by taking one individual away from it, the pendulum swings to the defensive side,\u201d Theismann said. \n \n\u201cIn this Super Bowl,\u201d he added, \u201cJulio Jones is going to get the bulk of the attention.\u201d \n \nMake no mistake: This is a versatile Falcons offense overseen by coordinator Kyle Shanahan, who is expected to be hired to run the San Francisco 49ers after this season ends and whose father Mike was the head coach of two Super Bowl champions with the Denver Broncos. \n \nRyan spread out his 38 TD passes to a league-record 13 receivers. Jones is the best of the bunch, but Mohamed Sanu, Taylor Gabriel and running backs Devonta Freeman (who ran for more than 1,000 yards and caught 54 passes) and Tevin Coleman (more than 500 yards rushing, more than 400 receiving) need to be accounted for, too. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s not one thing that you can point out and say, \u2018Stop Julio Jones. Stop Sanu. Stop the running game,\u2019\u201d Patriots linebacker Dont\u2019a Hightower said. \n \nOr as Belichick put it: \u201cEvery guy that gets the ball can score a touchdown from 80 yards away or more.\u201d \n \nThe Falcons (13-5) scored at least 30 points in 13 of their 18 games this season, including the playoffs, reaching 40 a half-dozen times. During their current six-game winning streak, they never scored fewer than 33. \n \n\u201cWe know that they\u2019re the cream of the crop, offensively,\u201d Patriots cornerback Logan Ryan said. \u201cAnd for us, we feel like we\u2019re that, defensively.\u201d \n \nThe Patriots (16-2) allowed more than 25 points only once in their 18 games, a 31-24 loss to Seattle in November. Since then, they\u2019ve won nine games in a row, never trailing at any moment in their past seven. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s the best defense that we\u2019ve seen in the NFL this year. The numbers show it, and watch the film and you see exactly why their numbers are the way they are,\u201d Shanahan said.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"HOWARD FENDRICH The"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: NFL - Washington Redskins news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: NFL - Atlanta Falcons news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: NFL - New England Patriots news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: American football news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: NFL news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Super Bowl LI: Top D (Patriots) usually beats top O (Falcons) in Super Bowl","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Dubuque","zipCode":"52004","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Dubuque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"TH Online","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169695972","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2992"},"name":"TH Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202479741","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:14Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/telegraphherald.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/b2/9b2b50bb-b805-5e7c-9785-313906d5d65c/588bda1acfd04.image.jpg?resize=300%2C219"}],"video":[]}}

Castor improved to 21-8-2, lowered his goals against average to 2.06 and raised his save percentage to .914 one night after being pulled early in the first period. \n \n\"I kind of had an idea of what they like to do after talking to (Keenan Suthers) before the shootout,\" Castor said of his teammate who began the season with the Lumberjacks. \"Fortunately, Svechnikov shot it right into my glove, and Adams missed the net. It was a little lucky, but sometimes you have to have a little luck to win. \n \n\"It's pretty tough, letting in three goals on four shots, but there's nothing you can do about it once it's happened. I knew I had to come out and have a good game tonight, and thankfully the guys in front of me had a great game. I knew I had more than that, and I knew our team had more than what we showed in the first five minutes (Friday), so I wasn't too worried about how we'd respond.\" \n \nDubuque improved to 24-10-3 for 51 points and maintained sole possession of second place in the Eastern Conference, two points ahead of Muskegon (23-12-3, 49 points). \n \nThe teams evenly split the four-game season series, which featured four one-goal games and shootout games on the final two nights. The Lumberjacks took Friday night\u2019s game, 4-3, in a shootout. \n \nOne night after surrendering three goals on five shots in the first 5 minutes, the Saints started considerably better. Dubuque\u2019s Michael Boyle dropped the gloves with Matt Steeves just 9 seconds into the game, and the Saints tightened defensively to hold the Lumberjacks without a shot for the first 8:05. \n \nRegen Cavanagh staked the Saints to a 1-0 lead at the 11:54 mark. Austin Rueschhoff won a faceoff back to Patrick Kudla, who slid the puck along the blue line to defense partner Jacob Semik. Cavanagh drove to the net and deposited Semik\u2019s backdoor pass under goalie Adam Brizgala for his seventh goal of the season. \n \n\"It really started with Boyle having that absolutely huge fight right off the draw, because that gave the boys a lot of momentum,\" Cavanagh said. \"I can't take credit for my goal. Rueschhoff had a great faceoff win to Kuddy, and Semik had unbelievable vision to pretty much put it right on my tape. It was a great team effort. \n \n\"We came out flat (Friday) night. We saw what we did wrong and wanted to make sure that didn't happen again.\" \n \nDubuque finished with a 15-4 advantage in first-period shots. The Lumberjacks generated more offense in the second period, when they outshot the Saints, 10-4, but neither team scored despite two power plays each. \n \nMuskegon tied the game with 6:32 remaining in regulation while enjoying a 5-on-3 power play. Andrei Svechnikov wired a one-timer from the slot past goaltender Jaxon Castor\u2019s outstretched glove hand. Bo Hanson set up Svechnikov\u2019s 19th goal of the season. Svechnikov leads all USHL rookies in scoring with 36 points. \n \nMuskegon had two Grade A chances to win the game late in regulation and in overtime. But Castor stopped Adams in both instances. \n \nThe Lumberjacks went 1-for-4 on the power play, while Dubuque failed to convert on its five opportunities. \n \nMuskegon finished with a 28-23 advantage in overall shots on goal. The Lumberjacks outshot Dubuque, 24-8, over the final two periods and overtime. \n \n\"It's kind of quirky the way this weekend turned out,\" Saints associate head coach JB Bittner said. \"We obviously had the rough start (Friday) night, but, for the most part, we felt we played really well after that. (Saturday) night we played really well in the beginning and kind of ran out of gas in the end. \n \n\"But the thing is this was two really good teams going at it this weekend. Both teams played really well at times. The times when we weren't playing well, it was mainly because Muskegon was doing a lot of things really well. They were two really good hockey games.\" \n \nGuttman saw his league-leading 12-game point streak come to an end. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396109197","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"IMMUNOLOGIC FACTORS","domains":["IND"],"score":"68"},{"name":"DISEASES & DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MAMMALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MEDICAL DIAGNOSTICS, SCREENING & TESTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SPORT HUNTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BIOLOGICAL CONTAMINANTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LAND USE & DEVELOPMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"WILDLIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CHRONIC DISEASES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENT & NATURAL RESOURCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"}],"wordCount":"999","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396109197&p=2kx&v=1&x=W4FcSVvApKS_yjYG0HbISw","id":"29396109197","content":"Nine samples from hunter-harvested deer from near Harpers Ferry during the 2016 hunting seasons have tested positive for chronic wasting disease, bringing the total of CWD positive deer from the area to 15. \n \nThe disease is spread from animal to animal through nose-to-nose contact and through environmental contamination from urine, feces and saliva left by positive deer. There is no cure once an animal becomes infected. \n \nThe DNR met with hunters and landowners in Harpers Ferry and Waukon on Jan. 18 to discuss collecting additional deer samples from areas where data is limited and to get more samples from the immediate areas where new positive cases were confirmed. At each meeting, attendees volunteered to help collect additional samples. \n \n\u201cWe hope to collect 250 to 300 samples from mature deer from a specific area around Harpers Ferry and that will do two things \u2014 provide information on specific areas in the target zone where we do not have any data and to remove animals from the area where CWD-positive deer have been found,\u201d said Dr. Dale Garner, chief of the Iowa DNR\u2019s Wildlife Bureau. \n \n\u201cThere is no good news when it comes to chronic wasting disease. We know that if we leave it alone, it\u2019s going to spread. By removing adult deer, we are trying to target animals that are most likely to carry the prion, which will slow the spread of the disease while still allowing for quality deer hunting experiences each fall.\u201d \n \nChronic wasting disease involves a misshapen protein called a prion. Since this is a protein, a deer\u2019s body does not recognize it as a foreign substance, so it does not produce an antibody response. \n \n\u201cThere is no way to kill the prion and the disease is always fatal,\u201d Garner said. \n \nThe DNR established a scientific collection effort from Jan. 21 to Feb. 5 in a defined area near Harpers Ferry. \n \nParticipants met with local DNR wildlife staff to discuss how to remove the deer, where they planned to focus their effort, and how to contact the DNR to provide the lymph nodes for testing. \n \nOnce a sample is submitted, it takes two-to-three weeks to get results back. \n \nParticipants must have a scientific collectors permit and tags and must contact the DNR within 24 hours of collecting deer to arrange for sample collection. There is no fee for the permits. Participants may use shotguns, muzzleloaders, bows and rifles .24 caliber and larger. All other regulations, including the blaze orange requirement and shooting hours restrictions, apply. \n \nPermits are available from noon to 6:30 p.m. Monday through Friday, and from 7 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. on the weekends until Feb. 5 at the Allamakee County Conservation office at 427 North First Street, in Harpers Ferry. A group leader may sign up other members by having their names and phone numbers. \n \nA similar effort took place in 2015. The collection had a goal of 200 samples, of which 105 deer were collected, providing 85 usable samples. Twenty fawns were not sampled. \n \nThe Iowa DNR began collecting deer tissue samples in 2002 after the CWD outbreak in Wisconsin. Since then, more than 61,000 samples from wild deer and 4,000 samples from hunting preserve deer have been collected and tested. The first wild deer tested positive in 2013, followed by three in 2014, two in 2015 and nine so far in 2016. \n \nChronic wasting disease is not just an Iowa issue; Minnesota has had a spike in deer testing positive for the disease as well. Illinois, Nebraska, Missouri and Wisconsin are all battling this disease. \n \nParticipation is voluntary and there are ways other than removing deer to help slow the spread of CWD in this area. \n \n\u201cWe encourage everyone to not use piles of feed or salt-mineral licks to attract deer. These baited sites increase the concentration of deer which facilitates transmission of the disease,\u201d said Garner. \u201cAnd don\u2019t leave a carcass or bones from this region to decay on the land. Place remains in heavy-duty plastic garbage bags to be properly disposed of in a landfill.\u201d \n WISCONSIN DEER PLAN ACCEPTS APPLICATIONS  \nConservation-minded people throughout Wisconsin are encouraged to enroll in the Deer Management Assistance Program to improve wildlife habitat on property they own or hunt. \n \nDMAP provides resources for wildlife habitat management, which complements land use activities like agriculture and timber management on properties of any size. \n \nThe application deadline is March 1 for properties larger than 160 acres, which may be eligible for a site visit and management plan in 2017. While applications may be submitted at any time, landowners are encouraged to apply now to receive immediate access to informational resources, including: \n \n\u2022 Habitat and deer management information \n \n\u2022 Communication with local DNR staff \n \n\u2022 Annual DMAP reports and publications \n \n\u2022 Volunteer opportunities \n \n\u2022 Invitations to DMAP workshops \n \n\u201cDNR staff currently work with more than 1,000 DMAP cooperators and two public land agencies on nearly 221,000 acres of land across the state to improve habitat for the wildlife resources we all enjoy,\u201d said Bob Nack, DMAP coordinator for the Department of Natural Resources. \u201cWe continue to develop new ways for cooperators to get involved and expand their knowledge of habitat and wildlife management.\u201d \n \nNeighboring landowners with properties within one-half mile of each other are encouraged to enroll as a group cooperative. Landowners in a group cooperative with a combined acreage of 160 acres or more receive a site visit and management plan. Group cooperatives also provide an opportunity to monitor local wildlife populations and share costs and equipment on habitat projects to benefit deer and other wildlife over a greater area. \n \nAnother benefit open to all DMAP cooperators is a series of annual DMAP workshops held regionally throughout Wisconsin. Six deer and habitat workshops were offered to DMAP cooperators in 2016, and additional workshops are slated for spring and summer 2017. Topics range from invasive species management and how to conduct a timber harvest to aging deer by tooth wear. \n \n\u201cDMAP workshops are a great opportunity to network with other conservation-minded people,\u201d Nack said. \u201cDMAP cooperators share a common goal of promoting the principles of land stewardship and sharing their experiences with others.\u201d \n \nFor more information regarding DMAP and to apply, go to dnr.wi.gov and search keyword \u201cDMAP.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"WENDY PAULY For the TH"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Tri-state outdoors notes: Positive tests found for chronic wasting disease in deer near Harpers Ferry","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Dubuque","zipCode":"52004","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Dubuque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"TH Online","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169695972","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2992"},"name":"TH Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://dnr.wi.gov/"],"sequenceId":"695202480720","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Other former Blackhawks included Bobby Hull, Stan Mikita, Tony Esposito, Denis Savard, Max Bentley and Glenn Hall. \n \nWondrous athletes with incredible achievements were in abundance Friday night in downtown Los Angeles, the site of Sunday\u2019s NHL All-Star Game and the celebration of the league\u2019s centennial. Dozens of the NHL 100 members were honored in the gala ceremony. \n \u2018Miracle on Ice\u2019 scoreboard coming down  \nLAKE PLACID, N.Y. \u2014 The scoreboard flashing results during the 1980 U.S. men\u2019s hockey team\u2019s \u201cMiracle on Ice\u201d run to Olympic glory is being replaced. \n \nThe 37-year-old board hanging over center ice at the Lake Placid Olympic Center will be removed on Feb. 6 to make way for a state-of-the-art video display. \n \nThe Olympic Regional Development Authority, which operates Lake Placid\u2019s state-owned sports venues, says South Dakota-based Daktronics designed and built the display used for the 1980 Olympic Winter Games. It showed the scores when the U.S. beat Russia in the hockey semifinals, then Sweden for the gold medal. \n \nDaktronics will get one of the scoreboard\u2019s four panels, while another will go to the Lake Placid Olympic Museum. Locations for the other two panels haven\u2019t been determined. \n NHL leaning toward Olympic shutout  \nLOS ANGELES \u2014 The NHL\u2019s top officials are still leaning against allowing the world\u2019s top hockey players to participate in the Pyeongchang Olympics next year. \n \nDeputy commissioner Bill Daly acknowledged Saturday that the NHL\u2019s Board of Governors doesn\u2019t want to shut down the league to allow its players to participate in South Korea. \n \nDaly says the owners\u2019 minds would have to be changed by something dramatic, but he doesn\u2019t know what that change would be. \n \nThe league and the International Ice Hockey Federation have no firm deadline to decide whether NHL players will participate in their sixth consecutive Olympics, but the final decision has already been left for later than in previous years. \n The players gathered in Los Angeles for All-Star weekend are unanimously hopeful they\u2019ll be allowed to play.  \nBASEBALL \n Twins to erect statue of Tom Kelly  \nMINNEAPOLIS \u2014 The Minnesota Twins plan to honor former manager Tom Kelly with a bronze statue outside Target Field. The team made the announcement at TwinsFest on Friday night. The statue will be unveiled this season, although the date is not yet set. Kelly led the Twins to World Series titles in 1987 and 1991. His record of 1,140-1,244 places him first on the Twins\u2019 managerial list in wins and games. Kelly retired after the 2001 season. His No. 10 was retired in 2012, the first Twins manager to be so honored. \n \nAt Target Field, Kelly\u2019s statue will join the likenesses of Kirby Puckett, Rod Carew, Harmon Killebrew, Calvin Griffith, Carl and Eloise Pohlad, Tony Oliva and Kent Hrbek. \n Dodgers sign 1B Ike Davis  \nLOS ANGELES \u2014 First baseman Ike Davis and the Los Angeles Dodgers have agreed to a minor league contract with an invitation to the team\u2019s spring training camp in Arizona. \n \nDavis played eight games last June for the New York Yankees. His last full year in the majors was 2014 when he split time with the Mets and Pirates, hitting .233 with 11 home runs and 51 RBIs in a combined 427 plate appearances. \n \nThe Dodgers said Friday that Davis will join 21 other non-roster invitees next month in Glendale, Arizona, including infielder Charlie Culberson, outfielder Tyler Holt, reliever Brandon Morrow and catcher Bobby Wilson. \n Rockies officially sign Greg Holland  \nDENVER \u2014 The Colorado Rockies made their deal with Greg Holland official on Saturday, signing the right-handed reliever coming off reconstructive elbow surgery to a one-year, $7 million contract. \n \nHolland was the closer for Kansas City through most of 2014 and 2015, when the Royals made back-to-back trips to the World Series. He injured his right elbow in late 2015 and missed all of last season while recovering from Tommy John surgery. Before his injury, the 31-year-old was considered as one of the most dominant closers in the game, posting a 1.21 ERA in 2013 and a 1.44 ERA in \u201814. \n Former Cy Young pitcher has throat cancer  \nSAN DIEGO \u2014 Randy Jones, the San Diego Padres\u2019 first Cy Young Award winner, is fighting throat cancer linked to tobacco use during his baseball career. \n \nJones told the San Diego Union-Tribune on Thursday that he has been undergoing radiation and chemotherapy treatments since being diagnosed in November. \n \nThe 67-year-old former pitcher says the cancer was caught early and hasn\u2019t spread. Jones said doctors told him it\u2019s a result of the chewing tobacco he used as a player. He has smoked cigars throughout his adult life. \n \nHall of Famer Tony Gwynn, a longtime Padres star and franchise icon, died of salivary gland cancer in 2014 that he believed was related to using tobacco during his major league career. Jones was drafted by the Padres in 1972 and became the club\u2019s first pitcher to appear in an All-Star Game in 1975. He was an All-Star the following year when he won the NL Cy Young Award. \n \nATHLETICS \n Maine high school deploys deaf mascot  \nPORTLAND, Maine \u2014 Kamron King says his goal as the first deaf mascot at Portland High School is something he won\u2019t always notice: making the crowd louder. \n \nFifteen-year-old Kamron is a freshman from Saco who started donning a bulldog costume during the fall football season and is now working the sidelines at basketball games. \n \nKamron says being deaf doesn\u2019t interfere with performing, other than occasionally needing someone to direct him toward young children in need of a high-five. The costume\u2019s heavy mask obscures his vision. Kamron\u2019s parents say it\u2019s a natural fit for a kid who loves sports and costumes.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: MLB - Minnesota Twins news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: MLB - San Diego Padres news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: NHL - Chicago Blackhawks news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: MLB - Los Angeles Dodgers news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: NHL news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: ice hockey news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Sports in brief: Nine Blackhawks land on NHL 100 list","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Dubuque","zipCode":"52004","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Dubuque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"TH Online","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169695972","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2992"},"name":"TH Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202481108","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Coleman-Lands cut the lead to 65-62 with a 3-pointer with 1:58 left before Garner hit four free throws in the final 38 seconds to keep it out of reach. \n \n\u201cI didn\u2019t like our disposition at all in the first half,\u201d Illinois coach John Groce said. \u201cI thought it was unacceptable. They\u2019ll return home for their next two but it won\u2019t get any easier \u2014 their next two opponents are a combined 33-10 \u2014 before heading back out of town to face third-place Northwestern (17-4, 6-2). \n \nPenn State: The Nittany Lions needed to reboot after being outscored by an average of 26 points in their last two losses on the road. \n BIG FIRST HALF  \nGarner, who entered the game shooting just 36 percent from 3-point range, admitted he had been frustrated with his shots not falling. \n \nHis solution? \n \n\u201cI\u2019ve definitely got in the gym more over the past week,\u201d Garner said. \u201cA little bit of extra work didn\u2019t hurt.\u201d \n \nPenn State led for all but 1:15 and took control early with pinpoint shooting sparked by Garner\u2019s first make \u2014 the first of nine 3-pointers for Penn State \u2014 on his first attempt. \n \nThe Nittany Lions made 60 percent of their first-half shots and Garner and Banks combined to make 8 of 13 from the field and 6 of 9 3s. \n \nDUNKS FOR THE WIN \n \nPenn State got it done inside, too, mostly with big dunks that brought a sizable Bryce Jordan Center crowd to its feet. \n \nNone of Penn State\u2019s six dunks were nicer than a big slam by Watkins with less than a minute in the first half. Garner noted the setup \u2014 a drive and behind-the-back feed from Terrence Samuel \u2014 might\u2019ve been prettier. \n \n\u201cThose guys are slashers, they like to get in the paint and finish,\u201d Garner said. \u201cWhen we\u2019re hitting shots, the defense has to try to contain (Banks and Garner) and the Red Sea opens. When we\u2019re open, they\u2019re tough to guard.\u201d \n \nUP NEXT \n \nIllinois hosts No. 15 Wisconsin on Tuesday. \n \nPenn State travels to Indiana on Wednesday.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"TRAVIS JOHNSON The"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: US college sports news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: basketball news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: college basketball news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"College basketball: Banks, Garner lead Penn State over Illinois","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Dubuque","zipCode":"52004","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Dubuque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"TH Online","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169695972","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2992"},"name":"TH Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202481277","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/telegraphherald.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/c/aa/caabfe90-68c7-575f-8faa-213598bd3292/588d4bf5259d4.image.jpg?resize=300%2C441"}],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396109354","companies":[{"symbol":"2120","primary":true,"name":"NEXT Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3758140002"},{"symbol":"NXCLF","primary":true,"name":"NEXT Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3758140002"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SOFTBALL","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"COLLEGIATE SPORTS ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"YOUTH CLUBS & ACTIVITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"STADIUMS & ARENAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SPORTS FANS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY SPORTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"SPONSORSHIP","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION FACILITIES & VENUES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"FUNDRAISING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SPORTS SPONSORSHIP","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"YOUTH SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BASEBALL","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SCHOOL SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"VOLUNTEERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"WINTER SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"}],"wordCount":"2106","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396109354&p=2kx&v=1&x=4RHjDoUL7V0NkcCo_1P0pg","id":"29396109354","content":"The Northwoods League has come a long way since the Dubuque Mud Puppies struggled to make a go of it two decades ago at Petrakis Park. \n \nIn two years, Dubuque baseball fans will have the opportunity to see just how far. \n \nThe non-profit Dubuque Area Youth Baseball and Softball Club on Saturday announced plans to bring a Northwoods League franchise to its proposed 30-acre, five-diamond complex located between Derby Grange Road and Asbury Plaza. Fundraising for the $5.5 million project will begin immediately, and Yoko said the group will seek corporate sponsors, private donors and other potential grants and awards. \n \nFollowing a business model similar to the non-profit Dubuque Community Ice & Recreation Center, Inc., the complex will serve as the home base for the local Protect Our Nation\u2019s Youth organization, with the Northwoods League franchise serving as the marquis tenant in a 1,500- to 2,000-seat stadium. The high-profile of the Fighting Saints and the United States Hockey League played a pivotal role in the development of the Mystique Community Ice Center from a small facility to a 3,000-seat arena prior to the 2010-11 season. \n \n\u201cThe ice arena has made our community a better place to live because it\u2019s created so many more opportunities and things to do, and we believe this project will do the same thing from a baseball perspective,\u201d said Greg Yoko, one of the organizers of the Dubuque Area Youth Baseball and Softball Club. \u201cJust like the Fighting Saints have been a great asset to the community, the Northwoods League franchise will do the same.\u201d \n \nThe 20-team Northwoods League, which features top NCAA Division I underclassmen competing in a setting much like the professional minor leagues, has blossomed into the largest collegiate summer league in the United States. Last summer, the Madison Mallards led the league in attendance with an average of 6,039 fans to 34 home dates, while the league average hovered around 1,700. \n \nUnder the Dubuque proposal, the new Northwoods League franchise will lease the stadium from the non-profit group and manage the complex. \n \n\u201cAs a non-profit group, we have a hard time every year finding parents to volunteer their time to sell team sponsorships, sell outfield signs and raise money,\u201d Yoko said. \u201cThat\u2019s not what we do for a living. We just want to play baseball. A Northwoods League franchise understands the business of selling sponsorships and revenue enhancements a lot better than we do. Hopefully, that includes securing a business or individual who sees the benefit in having their name attached to our project.\u201d \n \nThe PONY League, which annually averages 600 players of all abilities ranging in age from 4 to 18, currently leases three diamonds at the Derby Grange Golf & Recreation facility but has been scouting locations for a permanent home for more than two years. The league initially hoped to relocate to an 80-acre area along West 32nd Street but drew opposition from neighbors concerned about traffic, lighting and noise. \n \nThe PONY League plans to initially lease the land from current owners John and Sally Jo Herrig with the intent of purchasing it before the end of 2019. \n \n\u201cI applaud the group for having the tenacity they\u2019ve shown in getting this project off the drawing board,\u201d said Keith Rahe, the president and CEO of the Dubuque Convention & Visitors Bureau, who also understands the business of organized baseball as a long-time member of the Field of Dreams Ghost Players. \u201cFinding the necessary funding isn\u2019t easy, but the addition of a Northwoods League-type stadium is a huge part of any success. The Northwoods League has been very successful over the last decade or so, and their business model certainly works. \n \n\u201cThe Northwoods League is nothing like what Dubuquers remember from the Mud Puppies. Having worked with a lot of those franchises through the Ghost Players, it\u2019s amazing how well some of these franchises do.\u201d \n \nAnd the new team won\u2019t have to look far for business advice. \n \n\u201cThe Fighting Saints are a perfect example of, if you have the right organization that\u2019s well run, people will get behind it and support it, not only as fans but from a financial standpoint,\u201d Rahe said. \u201cIt\u2019s great entertainment and another thing to do to enhance the community.\u201d \n HISTORY IN DUBUQUE  \nThe Mud Puppies joined four other franchises \u2014 Rochester, Minn., and the Wisconsin communities of Kenosha, Manitowoc and Wausau \u2014 when the Northwoods League opened for business in 1994. But the minor league business model never took off at Petrakis Park, a facility more suited for recreational use in the McAleece Sports Complex, so the franchise relocated to St. Cloud, Minn., for the 1997 season. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019ve both changed a lot since then. Dubuque has changed, and obviously, we\u2019ve changed,\u201d said Dick Radatz Jr., the chairman of the Northwoods League. \u201cWe were kind of in our embryotic stage at that point, and we were still trying to figure ourselves out. Obviously, we\u2019ve grown substantially since then, and our business model has proven itself. \n \n\u201cNothing against Petrakis, because it has served a purpose to the community for many, many years. But we wouldn\u2019t consider a venue like that now. It was necessary at the time, but it\u2019s awfully difficult to create the kind of minor league environment you need to make this work from a business standpoint.\u201d \n \nThe Northwoods League will begin its 24th season in 2017 with 20 teams in two divisions. Despite humble beginnings, it has evolved into the largest collegiate summer league in the country and, because of its business model patterned after professional minor league baseball, the most widely attended. \n \nIts footprint ranges from Thunder Bay, Ontario, in the north to Waterloo, Iowa, in the south and from Bismarck, N.D., in the west to Battle Creek, Mich., in the east. In addition to Madison and Waterloo, Dubuque could develop natural geography rivalries with teams in LaCrosse, Wis., and Rockford, Ill. \n \n\u201cWe were pretty big dreamers when we started the league, but this has developed into way more than even we envisioned,\u201d Radatz said. \u201cIt\u2019s been quite a journey, and we had a lot of ups and downs in those early years when Dubuque was involved. Lately, fortunately, we\u2019ve had a lot more ups than downs.\u201d \n \nDespite its previous struggles and lack of a suitable stadium, Dubuque has been on the league\u2019s radar for several years. And Radatz believes it could follow in the footsteps of Kenosha, which departed the league in 1998 but returned in 2014 and finished third in attendance with an average of 2,514 fans last season. \n \n\u201cThey\u2019re both communities that couldn\u2019t survive for one reason or another back in the early days but we believe can thrive now,\u201d Radatz said. \u201cJust as our league has grown a lot since those early days, Dubuque has grown, too.\u201d \n \nLaCrosse Loggers general manager Chris Goodell, a former honorable mention all-state baseball player at Oelwein (Iowa) High School who played at the University of Dubuque under Dennis Rima in the late 1990s, said his organization would jump at the opportunity to operate an expansion franchise in Dubuque. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019ve been poking around Dubuque for the last couple of years, and we love the market,\u201d Goodell said. \u201cThere are a lot of similarities between LaCrosse and Dubuque in terms of the size of the market, the rich baseball history and the fact that the economic development group has a lot of positive, forward-thinking things going on. And we love the fact that, geographically, it fits perfectly within the footprint of our league, which will keep costs down. \n \n\u201cThe league is drastically different now than it was when the Mud Puppies were in Dubuque. There\u2019s so much more stability in it, and it really fits in well with the Midwest style of life. That explains why you have someone like me who has stayed in the league for the past 18 years.\u201d \n \nLaCrosse entered the Northwoods League in 2003 and immediately developed into one of the league\u2019s top draws. The Loggers built the Lumberyard at Copeland Park and have developed it over the years to suit growing needs. \n \n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t take long to figure out that there are good organizations and those that just don\u2019t get it, and the Loggers are definitely one that get it,\u201d Rahe said. \u201cThey\u2019ve developed quite the atmosphere, and to have them as the main draw of a complex like the one in Dubuque brings a level of importance to the project.\u201d \n \nGoodell believes his organization could hit the ground running in Dubuque. \n \n\u201cWe have 15 years of experience, so we have the knowledge and the wherewithal to have success with our model,\u201d Goodell said. \u201cWe live and breathe baseball, and this is our main thing. There wouldn\u2019t be any kind of learning curve, like you\u2019d have with a new organization. We could come in and engage with the community right away.\u201d \n CALIBER OF PLAY  \nReed Stumpf loves the idea of the Northwoods League returning to Dubuque. \n \nThe University of Dubuque senior pitcher spent the last month of the 2016 season with the Wisconsin Rapids Rafters and helped the team win its first Northwoods League playoff championship in franchise history. \n \nStumpf, a former Dubuque Hempstead standout, appeared in six regular-season games and went 2-0 with a 2.45 ERA and six strikeouts in 11 innings of work for the Rafters. The reliever earned a victory in his only postseason appearance, striking out four and not allowing a run in four innings. \n \n\u201cIt was an experience I\u2019ll never forget, because the environment, the atmosphere and the level of play was exactly like what you could expect if you were playing professional baseball,\u201d said Stumpf, one of the rare NCAA Division III athletes to earn an opportunity to play in the Northwoods League. \u201cSo many of the guys who played in the league last year will be playing pro ball in the next couple of years, and the Northwoods League is great preparation for that. \n \n\u201cThe talent level was unbelievable. You had elite college players who were so smooth and so advanced, and the community really embraced it. It\u2019s something Dubuque doesn\u2019t get to see right now, so I\u2019d love for the city to get a franchise.\u201d \n \nThe Northwoods League has proven to be fertile proving ground for future Major League Baseball players. Jeff Weaver, who played for the Mud Puppies in 1995 and won a World Series with the St. Louis Cardinals in 2006, became the first Northwoods League graduate to reach the big leagues in 1999, and 162 players have followed suit. The Mud Puppies produced two other big leaguers, Shawn Sedlacek and Robb Quinlan. \n \nThe list of Northwoods League graduates includes Juan Pierre (Manitowoc), Curtis Granderson (Mankato), Andre Ethier (Rochester), World Series MVP Ben Zobrist (Wisconsin), National League Cy Young winner Max Scherzer (LaCrosse) and Chris Sale (LaCrosse). \n \n\u201cEvery team is loaded with high-end talent that you\u2019re going to be seeing in the big leagues in a few years,\u201d Goodell said. \u201cBecause they\u2019re still amateur athletes and we don\u2019t have to pay salaries, we can keep the ticket prices very family friendly. It\u2019s a great opportunity to see the up-and-coming talent at an affordable price before they make it.\u201d \n \nThe Northwoods League environment advances the careers of more than just the players. Stumpf said several of his University of Dubuque classmates have served sports management internships with Northwoods League franchises. \n \nThe typical Northwoods League franchise employs up to 10 full-time staff members and several dozen seasonal workers. \n NEED FOR STADIUM  \nLast season, the Loggers played just 36 home games at the Lumberyard in LaCrosse. Local colleges, high schools and American Legion teams accounted for the other 184 games at the one-diamond facility. \n \nYoko expects the stadium diamond at the proposed complex to experience similar usage. \n \n\u201cThe facility won\u2019t be exclusive to the Northwoods League or the PONY League,\u201d Yoko said. \u201cObviously, the No. 1 reason for us doing this is to have a place to play, and we will have priority as far as scheduling goes. But we really want this to be a community amenity that enhances the quality of life in Dubuque. \n \n\u201cWe want it to be so much more than just a baseball facility.\u201d \n \nFor years, baseball visitors to Dubuque have complained about the lack of quality facilities. The county\u2019s top diamonds reside in the outlying communities of Cascade, Dyersville, Farley and Peosta. \n \n\u201cHaving a nice baseball facility is huge for Dubuque,\u201d Rahe said. \u201cWe definitely need that. I\u2019m a baseball guy, and from a fan\u2019s perspective, I really love this.\u201d \n \nYoko said plans for the complex include a walking/biking trail as well as park-like amenities, such as playground equipment, to make it a more well-rounded recreational outlet. It will also include ample concessions and restroom facilities. \n \nYoko hopes the complex can include a display honoring the Dubuque County Baseball Hall of Fame and the local history of the sport.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"JIM LEITNER jim.leitner@thmedia.com"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Northwoods League returning to Dubuque in 2019","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Dubuque","zipCode":"52004","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Dubuque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"TH Online","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169695972","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2992"},"name":"TH Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202482618","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:17Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/telegraphherald.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/d/f8/df865ec8-85eb-5681-b6db-ed00639b2ee5/588d57c84f6ca.image.jpg?resize=300%2C166"}],"video":[]}}

while others said that he was shot and has been taken to Damascus Hospital for treatment. \n \nFrance\u2019s Le Point, speculated that Assad might have been assassinated by his personal Iranian Bodyguard Mehdi al-Yaacoubi, going so far as to say that he shot him in the head. \n \nLebanese newspaper, al-Mustaqbal, quoted \u201creliable sources\u201d as saying that Assad suffered from a cerebral infraction and was transferred to Damascus Hospital where he is being treated under high security. \n \nAs for the Saudi newspaper Okaz, Assad is suffering from a \u201cbrain tumor.\u201d He tried to cover up his illness through short and frequent appearances. According to its sources, Assad is being treated by a Russian-Syrian medical team on a weekly basis, adding that he has undergone medical tests when he was in Moscow in October. \n \nPro-Syrian regime Lebanese newspaper al-Diyar reported on Friday that Assad suffered from a stroke, but denied the news today. \n \nThere were also rumors that Assad is at the American University Hospital (AUH) in Beirut. However, Al Arabiya contacted the hospital and no information on the issue was given. Al Arabiya has also tried to contact Damascus Hospital, but there has been no response. \n \nOn the other hand, in a statement carried by the Presidency of the Syrian Arab Republic page on Facebook, Syrian authorities said that such rumors were incorrect. \n \nEarlier this week, Saudi-owned newspaper Asharq al-Awsat claimed the president\u2019s mental health has deteriorated after almost six years of civil war. \n \nCiting unnamed sources it said Russian officials believed Assad was \u201cexhausted by five years of war and tension\u201d and had developed a nervous tick in his left eye as a result of \u201cpsychological pressure\u201d. \u2013 Samaa/Agencies \n \n Tweet  \nStory first published: 29th January 2","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Rumors about Assad\u2019s assassination and critical health","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"PK","country":"Pakistan"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"SAMAA TV","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"361821793","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"232"},"name":"SAMAA TV","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.samaa.tv"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://english.alarabiya.net/en/media/print/2017/01/28/News-of-Bashar-al-Assad-suffering-a-stroke-has-gone-viral.html","https://twitter.com/share"],"sequenceId":"695202483829","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

They started out playing together in Compton, California, hardly a hotbed for tennis, with their father Richard and mother Oracene as coach and mentor. And they still practice and travel together around the world. \n \nThey met for the first time at a major at Melbourne Park in 1998 \u2014 Venus won that one. In 2003, when the younger of the Williams siblings completed her \u201cSerena Slam\u201d of four consecutive titles, Venus was on the other side of the net. She didn\u2019t reach another Australian final for 14 years. \n \nWhen Serena sat on the court, holding both arms up to celebrate on Saturday, Venus walked over to her sister\u2019s side of the net for a hug. \n \n\u201cThis was a tough one,\u201d Serena said. \u201cI really would like to take this moment to congratulate Venus, she\u2019s an amazing person \u2014 she\u2019s my inspiration. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s no way I would be at 23 without her \u2014 there\u2019s no way I would be at one without her. Thank you Venus for inspiring me to be the best player I can be and inspiring me to work hard.\u201d \n \nAsked if it felt awkward to be on the receiving end of so many losses to her sister, the 36-year-old Venus didn\u2019t flinch. \n \n\u201cNo, because I guess I\u2019ve been here before,\u201d she said. \u201cI really enjoy seeing the name Williams on the trophy. This is a beautiful thing.\u201d \n \nVenus won the last of her seven majors in 2008 at Wimbledon. She didn\u2019t make the second week of a major for a few years as she came to terms with an energy-sapping illness after being diagnosed with Sjogren\u2019s syndrome in 2011. And she only made it back to the semifinals last year at Wimbledon. \n \nAnother shot at a first Australian Open title was a sign of progress, she said. \n \n\u201cThat\u2019s exactly where I want to be standing during these Grand Slams, is on finals day, having an opportunity,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s the highlight of all this, is to be in that moment.\u201d \n \nSerena Williams, meanwhile, enjoyed the fact she made history in Melbourne. Only Margaret Court, with 24, is in front of her in terms of overall Grand Slam singles titles, although the Australian great won 13 of her Grand Slams before the Open era began in 1968. \n \n\u201cMy first Grand Slam started here, and getting to 23 here, but playing Venus, it\u2019s stuff that legends are made of,\u201d Serena said. \u201cI couldn\u2019t have written a better story.\u201d \n \nThe match didn\u2019t live up to its classic billing, with nerves and tension causing uncharacteristic mistakes and unforced errors, with four consecutive service breaks before Venus finally held for a 3-2 lead in the first set. That included a game when Serena had game point but served back-to-back double-faults and three in all to give up the break. \n \nThere were six service breaks in total. Both players were relatively subdued, except when Serena smashed her racket in the third game. \n \nAfter the fourth game, however, Serena Williams didn\u2019t face another break point in the 1-hour, 22-minute match. \n \n\u201cSerena Williams, that\u2019s my little sister,\u201d Venus said. \u201cI have been right there with you. Some of them I have lost right there against you. It\u2019s been an awesome thing, your win has always been my win.\u201d \n \nIn terms of total years, it was the oldest Grand Slam women\u2019s final in the Open era \u2014the Williams sisters combining for 71 years, 11 months.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"JOHN PYE The"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: tennis news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Australian Open: Serena Williams sets major record with win over Venus","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Dubuque","zipCode":"52004","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Dubuque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"TH Online","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169695972","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2992"},"name":"TH Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202484357","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/telegraphherald.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/15/91567fea-b4ed-5ab0-b2ee-50f5f97702ab/588d205936dfc.image.jpg?resize=300%2C365"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29386952798","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BAIL","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ARRESTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"PROSTITUTION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"AMERICAN FOOTBALL; SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"93"},{"name":"INTERVIEWS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"ATLANTA, GA, USA; UNITED STATES; GEORGIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"DENVER, CO, USA; UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"71"}],"wordCount":"956","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396109159&p=2kx&v=1&x=pgtvrCU8rRfEKjjXAqDWpQ","id":"29396109159","content":"ATLANTA \u2014 The last time the Atlanta Falcons made it to the Super Bowl, they put on quite a show. \n \nJust not when it mattered. \n \nThe team known as the \u201cDirty Birds\u201d capped off a remarkable season in 1998 by doing almost everything wrong once they claimed a spot in the big game. \n \n\u201cI didn\u2019t do a good enough job of making them understand that you don\u2019t want to just be there,\u201d said Dan Reeves, who was the Falcons\u2019 coach. \u201cYou want to win it.\u201d \n \nIn the lead-up to the Super Bowl, Reeves actually got things rolling by unwittingly rekindling his ugly breakup with the Denver Broncos, who just happened to be Atlanta\u2019s opponent. Then there was a dispute over the way the players got off the plane once they landed in Miami. For some reason, receiver Terance Mathis decided the Super Bowl stage would be a good week to talk about his battle with alcohol and a feeling that he wasn\u2019t appreciated. And brash cornerback Ray Buchanan turned media day into a full-blown circus by wearing a dog collar \u2014 the Falcons were underdogs, you see \u2014 and saying Broncos star Shannon Sharpe looked like a horse. \n \nAll of that paled in comparison to what happened the night before the game, when safety Eugene Robinson \u2014 perhaps the most respected member of the team \u2014 was arrested for trying to pick up a prostitute. Robinson was bailed out of jail and played in the game, only to get beaten on a long touchdown pass. \n \nNot surprisingly, the Broncos cruised to a 34-19 victory and their second straight title in John Elway\u2019s final game. \n \n\u201cAny kind of distraction hurts,\u201d Reeves recalled in an interview from his Atlanta home. \u201cWhen one player causes a distraction the night before the game, it makes it more difficult. But we just got beat by a better team.\u201d \n \nDespite the loss, the team is still remembered fondly in Atlanta, a city that has produced only one championship team \u2014 the 1995 World Series-winning Braves \u2014 in any of the major sports. \n \nJamal Anderson, who rushed for more than 1,800 yards and takes credit for the arm-flapping dance that gave the team its nickname, said he can hardly go anywhere without someone remembering the \u201898 Falcons. \n \n\u201cNo matter what airport I\u2019m in, when people recognize me, they yell, \u2018Dirty Bird!\u2019\u201d Anderson said. \n \nEighteen years later, with the Falcons headed back to the Super Bowl for only the second time in franchise history, the team that paved the way left behind some useful lessons. \n \nFor one, never assume there will be a return trip if things don\u2019t work out. The Dirty Birds certainly thought they\u2019d get another shot, but they followed up their 14-2 season by going 5-11 the following year \u2014 the first of three straight losing campaigns. They didn\u2019t even get back to the playoffs until 2002, with a largely different cast. \n \nBy then, Anderson was out of the league, his career cut short at age 29 by two severe knee injuries. \n \n\u201cYou never know what\u2019s going to happen,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen you get a chance to be there, you\u2019ve got to lay it all on the line.\u201d \n \nPlus, the sting of losing the final game of the season never leaves you. To this day, the 44-year-old Anderson has never watched a replay of his lone Super Bowl. \n \n\u201cYou don\u2019t ever get over losing a Super Bowl,\u201d he said. \u201cYou get that title forever. I\u2019m very proud of winning the NFC Championship and the way we did it. At least we got to hang that banner. But I sure wanted to win the Super Bowl.\u201d \n \nThe NFC Championship Game remains the highlight of the season for Reeves, especially since it came just three weeks after he underwent quadruple-bypass heart surgery. \n \nDespite their lofty record, the Falcons were huge underdogs going on the road to face the Minnesota Vikings, who had lost only one game while setting an NFL scoring record. In the raucous Metrodome, Atlanta trailed by 10 points early in the fourth quarter, and it looked as though the Vikings would clinch the victory when Gary Anderson lined up for a 38-yard field goal with just over 2 minute remaining. \n \nStunningly, Anderson missed for the first time all season. \n \nThe Falcons drove for the tying touchdown and won in overtime on Morten Andersen\u2019s 38-yard field goal. \n \nOn the stage in the middle of a stunned, emptying stadium, Reeves did the \u201cDirty Bird\u201d with his players. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s not any question, the win in Minnesota\u201d was the game Reeves remembers most. \u201cBecause of the circumstances and how good a football team they were and winning on the road, having everything really against you as far as the crowd and everything,\u201d he said. \u201cCertainly, the fact I had bypass surgery made it little more special.\u201d \n \nUnfortunately for Reeves and the Falcons, they couldn\u2019t win the game that really counted. \n \nLittle did they know, their loss would have a profound effect on a current Falcons star. \n \nVic Beasley was just 6 years old, but he was already a huge fan of the team growing up about an hour\u2019s drive north of Atlanta. Now an All-Pro defensive end who led the league in sacks, he hasn\u2019t forgotten the pain he felt watching the Falcons\u2019 first Super Bowl. \n \n\u201cI cried that night,\u201d Beasley said. \u201cI still remained a fan through thick and thin.\u201d \n \nNow, he and his teammates have a chance to finish the job. \n \nThey\u2019ve got no bigger fans than the Dirty Birds. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m very happy for them,\u201d Jamal Anderson said. \u201cI\u2019m really, really happy for the city. I\u2019m really happy for Falcons fans, the true and hardcore fans who are supportive and encouraging. You know, we have an interesting history in this city. LOUIS \u2014 The offseason discussion surrounding Yadier Molina has long centered on whether the St. Louis catcher should rest more during the season. \n \nAfter Molina played in a career-high 147 games last year, that consideration is in the forefront more than ever for the 34-year-old winner of eight Gold Gloves. So is the awareness that his time as one of the dominant backstops in baseball might soon start winding down. \n \nThe discussion about Molina\u2019s playing time hasn\u2019t been limited to only fans, with Cardinals general manager John Mozeliak recently saying he feels Molina would be \u201cbetter off\u201d with more rest. This after a season in which the Puerto Rican star didn\u2019t win the Gold Glove for the first time since 2007. \n \nIt\u2019s not an opinion shared by St. Louis manager Mike Matheny. \n \n\u201cMy job description is to win games,\u201d Matheny said. \u201cAnd if I\u2019ve got a player I feel is going to help us win games, and that I feel is able to answer the bell, he\u2019s going to be in the lineup.\u201d \n \nMatheny knows more than most about the grueling demands of catching over the course of a 162-game season, having won four Gold Gloves of his own for his work behind the plate. \n \nHe\u2019s managed Molina since 2012, during which time the catcher \u2014 who has been a part of nine playoff appearances and two World Series titles since debuting in 2004 \u2014 has played in an average of 133 games per season. \n \nAnd while Matheny understands the long-term concerns about Molina\u2019s ability to continue playing at a high level, he\u2019s also aware that last season was the first time the Cardinals have missed the playoffs over that stretch \u2014 with much of the prior success coming in large part to Molina. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s frustrating, frustrating for me because I remember the years when I was able to play a lot,\u201d Matheny said. \u201cThere were times I felt good, and it just made no sense. And for whatever reason, sometimes you can feel a lot of pressure of the outside influences saying that you shouldn\u2019t be playing.\u201d \n \nMozeliak\u2019s comments about resting Molina more weren\u2019t his first on the topic. YORK: Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly and Department of Homeland Security leadership saw the final details shortly before the order was finalized, government officials said. \n \nFriday night, DHS arrived at the legal interpretation that the executive order restrictions applying to seven countries \u2014 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Syria, Sudan and Yemen \u2014 did not apply to people who with lawful permanent residence, generally referred to as green card holders. \n \nThe White House overruled that guidance overnight, according to officials familiar with the rollout. That order came from the President\u2019s inner circle, led by Stephen Miller and Steve Bannon. Their decision held that, on a case by case basis, DHS could allow green card holders to enter the US. \n \nThere had been some debate whether green card holders should be even allowed to board international flights. It was decided by the Department of Homeland Security they could fly to the US and would be considered on a case-by-case basis after passing a secondary screening. \n \nBut the guidance sent to airlines on Friday night, obtained by CNN, said clearly, \u201clawful permanent residents are not included and may continue to travel to the USA.\u201d \n \nAs of Saturday afternoon, Customs and Border Protection continued to issue the same guidance to airlines as it did Friday, telling airlines that fly to the US that green card holders can board planes to the US but they may get extra scrutiny on arrival, according to an airline official. \n \nBefore the President issued the order, the White House did not seek the legal guidance of the Office of Legal Counsel, the Justice Department office that interprets the law for the executive branch. \n \nA source said the executive order did not follow the standard agency review process that\u2019s typically overseen by the National Security Council, though the source couldn\u2019t specifically say if that included the decision to not have the order go through the Office of Legal Counsel. \n \nSeparately, a person familiar with the matter said career officials in charge of enforcing the executive order were not fully briefed on the specifics until Friday. \n \nThe officials were caught off guard by some of the specifics and raised questions about how to handle the new banned passengers on US-bound planes. \n \nRegarding the green card holders and some of the confusion about whether they were impacted, the person familiar with the matter said if career officials had known more about the executive order earlier, some of the confusion could have been avoided and a better plan could be in place. \n \nAdministration officials also defended the process Saturday. They said the people who needed to be briefed ahead of time on the plane were briefed and that people at the State Department and DHS who were involved in the process were able to make decisions about who to talk and inform about this. This year, the Winter Iowa Games celebrated its 25th year, and Dubuque, as a host city, has been instrumental in making the event an annual opportunity for Iowans to stay active. \n \nChuck Long, executive director of the Iowa Sports Foundation, said the Iowa Winter Games started with a group of 500 athletes. This year, more than 4,000 are participating, with Dubuque hosting 12 competitions at 14 different venues. \n \n\u201cI\u2019ve just seen the chart of how it\u2019s grown,\u201d said Long, who is in his third year running the Games. \u201cIt\u2019s grown in a great way. We love having it in Dubuque. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019ve found that people in Iowa want to be active, and we\u2019re trying to push sports, recreation, health and wellness statewide. We have a great Eastern Iowa presence and it\u2019s really because of the games.\u201d \n \nOn Saturday, the Dubuque region hosted alpine ski racing, girls basketball, fitness walking, ice hockey, indoor soccer, martial arts, swimming, table tennis and volleyball. Today\u2019s schedule contains boys basketball, pickleball, road racing and Zumba, and on February 11-12, four more Winter Games events will take place in Cedar Rapids. Another 11 competitions have or will take place at varying locations throughout the state. \n \nThe Games attract athletes of all ages and experience, said Long. The youngest competitor is 4-year-old Urbandale figure skater Faline Senne; the oldest is Garner-native Marvin Engstler, an 84-year-old horseshoe thrower. Dubuquer Sarah Smith is the second-oldest female athlete at 77, competing today in the pickleball tournament. \n \n\u201cWe want a wide variety,\u201d Long said, adding that people from all 99 Iowa counties are participating this year. \u201cYou don\u2019t have to be an athlete to participate. Anybody can be an athlete at these games.\u201d \n \nWhile the event drives competition, organizers try to instill values of sportsmanship and camaraderie in the athletes. Dubuque-native Jim Rolling served as the commissioner of Saturday\u2019s youth volleyball tournament, and after five years helping run it, he said the reason he loves working the Iowa Games is helping young athletes learn. \n \n\u201cThey\u2019re here to have fun, they\u2019re here to learn, it\u2019s not all about winning,\u201d Rolling said. \u201cTypically it\u2019s a good way to learn. My emphasis is that you\u2019re here to have fun, you\u2019re here to help these kids become better people, not just better athletes.\u201d \n \nLong already deemed this year\u2019s games a success. And at this rate, he\u2019s looking forward to another strong 25 years of Iowa Games. \n \n\u201cWe don\u2019t turn anybody away,\u201d Long said. \u201cThere\u2019s a place and a sport for everybody to participate.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"BRENDEN WEST brenden.west@thmedia.com"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Iowa Games: Celebrating 25 years","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Dubuque","zipCode":"52004","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Dubuque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"TH Online","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169695972","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2992"},"name":"TH Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202491399","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:13Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:08:03Z","duplicateGroupId":"29394761379","companies":[{"symbol":"HSCC","primary":true,"name":"Homeland Security Corp","contentCount":2,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US43741T1007"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CONSTITUTIONAL LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"HABEAS CORPUS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PASSPORTS & VISAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EXECUTIVES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"AVIATION SECURITY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"92"},{"name":"AIRPORTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"REFUGEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"NATIONAL SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"TRAVELER SAFETY & SECURITY","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"JUDGES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EXCISE & CUSTOMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"53"},{"name":"EXECUTIVE ORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PETITIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DEPORTATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"99"},{"name":"NEW YORK, NY, USA; UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"IRAQ","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"735","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396109483&p=2kx&v=1&x=5JMNVrVh3YbCkrOo0lYkhw","id":"29396109483","content":"© Stephanie Keith / AFP \nProtestors rally during a demonstration against the new immigration ban issued by President Donald Trump at John F. Kennedy International Airport on January 28, 2017 in New York City \n        A Brooklyn judge issued an emergency stay, temporarily freezing the expulsion of travelers under the newly-signed executive order by President Donald Trump that covers 7 Arab nations, after a habeas corpus petition was filed by the American Civil Liberties Union. \nJudge Ann Donnelly of the US District Court for the Eastern District of New York issued the ruling after the American Union of Civil Liberties (ACLU) filed a legal challenge on behalf of two Iraqi immigrants, Hameed Khalid Darweesh and Sameer Abdulkhaleq Alshawi. \n \nBoth were denied entry to the US after landing at the airports despite having valid visas. US President Donald Trump, US Department of Homeland Security and US Customs and Border Protection are listed among the respondents. \nThe emergency stay does not only apply to Darweesh and Alshawi, but will also temporarily forbid US authorities from deporting immigrants with valid travel documents who are stranded at airports across the US due to the Trump's order. \n\n\"Class is pretty well defined as outline in the papers - otherwise would be reviewing stays for a hundred people,\" the presiding judge said, elaborating on the ruling, as reported by Jackie Vimo from National Immigration Law Center, on Twitter. \n \n\"The whole point of this hearing is to preserve the status quo. If this had been two days ago we wouldn't be here,\" she added. \nThe judge also requested a list of all people currently detained in the US as result of the implementation of the executive order. \n\nA statement released by the DHS late on Saturday said the department will \"comply with judicial orders\" of the federal judge. This does not cancel the president's executive order, however, the statement added, which means citizens from the list of seven Muslim countries included in the ban still cannot enter the United States. \n\n\"These individuals went through enhanced security screenings and are being processed for entry to the United States, consistent with our immigration laws and judicial orders,\" the statement said. \n\nDarweesh, who was released later on Saturday, had been granted a Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) for his year-long service to the US as an electrical engineer and contractor, ACLU said. According to a former Washington official, Brandon Friedman, the Iraqi \"was one of the first to sign up [as an interpreter] in 2003.\" \n\n\"Guy literally spent years keeping U.S. soldiers alive in combat in Iraq,\" he tweeted. \n\nACLU Executive Director, Anthony D. Romero, hailed the decision as the \"first loss in court\" for Donald Trump. \n\n\"Our courts today worked as they should, as bulwarks against government abuse or unconstitutional policies and orders,\" he said in statement. \n\nMeanwhile, the US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) said it has not yet seen a copy of the emergency stay, Reuters reported. The DHS continued to monitor litigation over the executive order, it added. \n\nSome 375 travelers have been affected by the order, according to a DHS source cited by Reuters, including 109 people who were denied entry into the US while in transit. Over 170 people were reportedly barred from boarding US-bound aircraft, the source said. \n \nEarlier on Saturday, President Trump insisted that his Friday order was \"not a Muslim ban,\" as the media had dubbed it, as he spoke to reporters in the White House's Oval Office. He said that measures were long overdue, Reuters reported. \n\"It's working out very nicely. You see it at the airports, you see it all over,\" Trump said. \n\nOn Friday, Trump signed the executive order, temporarily barring the citizens from seven countries with predominantly Muslim populations - Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Yemen and Syria - from entering the US. \n\nThe controversial order led to hundreds of immigrants being stranded at airports across the US amid mounting public outrage. \n\nAt least 12 refugees were detained at John F. Kennedy International Airport as a result of the ban, which sparked mass protests there with demonstrators demanding the immediate release of the migrants. \n \nThe executive order called for a pause for all refugee admissions for 120 days and barred travelers from the seven listed countries for at least 90 days. \n\"I'm establishing new vetting measures to keep radical Islamic terrorists out of the United States of America. Don't want them here,\" Trump said on Friday, citing US national security concerns.
