The regional winners will participate in a statewide cook-off at the Florida School Nutrition Association annual conference. \n\nThe ultimate winner will be invited to serve with a professional chef at one of the department's future events. \n\nOn the web: http://www.freshfromflorida.com/Divisions-Offices/Food-Nutrition-and-Wellness/Fresh-From-Florida-Student-Chef-Cook-Off","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"}],"title":"No fries: Florida wants students to whip up healthy dishes","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Manatee","zipCode":"34205","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Bradenton","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Bradenton Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657775","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"626"},"name":"Bradenton Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bradenton.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.freshfromflorida.com/Divisions-Offices/Food-Nutrition-and-Wellness/Fresh-From-Florida-Student-Chef-Cook-Off"],"sequenceId":"695202521817","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:03Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:27Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"prem","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:26Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396110255","companies":[{"symbol":"MLIDS","primary":true,"name":"IDS","contentCount":2,"exchange":"PAR","titleCount":0,"isin":"FR0000079691"},{"symbol":"XKR","primary":false,"name":"KAR Auction Services Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US48238T1097"},{"symbol":"XKR","primary":false,"name":"KAR Auction Services Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"BER","titleCount":0,"isin":"US48238T1097"},{"symbol":"KAR","primary":false,"name":"KAR Auction Services Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US48238T1097"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"PRICE INCREASES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FREELANCE EMPLOYMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"51"},{"name":"DIESEL FUEL PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"OUTPUT & DEMAND","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EXECUTIVES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS; RECESSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WAREHOUSING & STORAGE","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"PRICE CHANGES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ENERGY DEPARTMENTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"GASOLINE PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"PRICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ELECTRONIC COMMERCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"DIESEL FUEL","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"GASOLINE","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"OIL & GAS PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"92"},{"name":"AUTOMOTIVE FUELS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TRENDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"GASOLINE MARKETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"FUEL MARKETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SOUTH BEND, IN, USA; UNITED STATES; INDIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"56"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; INDIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"INDIANAPOLIS, IN, USA; UNITED STATES; INDIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"FORT WAYNE, IN, USA; UNITED STATES; INDIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"56"}],"wordCount":"1097","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396110255&p=2kx&v=1&x=YhnoMBREtwv4H4Ylocfmvg","id":"29396110255","content":"If forecasts are accurate, 2017 will bring something we haven\u2019t seen in five years \u2014 higher gas prices. \n \nFollowing high prices and volatility during the Great Recession and its aftermath, average gasoline prices have been steadily dropping since 2012. \n \nThat trend is set to end this year, according to government forecasting. \n \nThe 2017 increase likely won\u2019t be large \u2014 the U.S. Energy Information Administration predicts a national average retail price of $2.38 per gallon, up from $2.15 in 2016. But a range of local companies, from logistics providers to auto auctioneers, say they\u2019re keeping an eye on the situation. \n \n Story continues below gallery  \n \n\u201cWe have 500 drivers, so it\u2019s something we watch pretty closely,\u201d said Ryan Schwalbach, CEO of Indianapolis-based Now Courier Co. \n \nThe company, which offers delivery, warehousing and logistics services, also has offices in Evansville, Fort Wayne, Merrillville and South Bend, as well as in Louisville and Cincinnati. \n \nWith the economy doing well, Schwalbach said, the company already is in the midst of a \u201csevere drought\u201d of drivers. \n \nWhen gas prices go up, he said, it becomes even harder to recruit drivers because Now\u2019s drivers are independent contractors who pay for their own fuel and vehicle expenses. \n \nMost of Now\u2019s customers pay a fuel surcharge that kicks in when gas reaches $2.10 a gallon. That surcharge is a percentage of the overall delivery fee, Schwalbach said, and as gas prices increase, so does the surcharge. But he said the surcharge isn\u2019t enough to fully reimburse drivers for their increased fuel costs. \n \nSchwalbach said he doesn\u2019t expect a return to the record-high $3.62-a-gallon average from 2012, but he believes prices could climb close to $3 a gallon. \n \nAccording to the Energy Information Administration\u2019s Short-Term Energy Outlook, issued monthly, the national average for unleaded gasoline this year is expected to be $2.38 per gallon, rising to $2.41 in 2018. Diesel prices are expected to rise, too \u2014 from $2.31 per gallon last year to $2.73 this year, and $2.84 in 2018. \n \n\u201cWe kind of reached a low point with all prices at the beginning of 2016,\u201d said Sean Hill, an economist with the Energy Information Administration. \n \nSupply and demand \n \nPrices for gasoline, diesel and oil all fell in recent years because their supplies grew faster than demand, Hill said. But U.S. production declined over the past year, he added, and overseas production is expected to drop this year.Companies across central Indiana, a hotbed for the transportation and logistics industries, will feel the consequences of higher fuel costs if predictions come true. \n \n\u201cWe pay very close attention\u201d to fuel prices, said Chip Edgington, vice president of operations at Fullbeauty Brands, an e-commerce firm selling plus-size women\u2019s clothing through a variety of websites, including Woman Within, Roaman\u2019s, Jessica London and Swimsuitsforall. \n \nThe company is based in New York City but has significant operations in Indianapolis, including about 170 corporate employees and another 500 or so at distribution centers in Indianapolis and Plainfield. \n \nEdgington is also chairman of Conexus Indiana, an Indianapolis-based organization focused on strengthening the state\u2019s advanced manufacturing and logistics sectors. \n \nFuel prices have an impact on shipping prices, which affect a wide range of companies, Edgington said. \n \nThe cost of fuel is \u201cgoing to go up, but is it going to be sustained?\u201d he said. \u201cIs it going to be significant? It\u2019s anyone\u2019s guess.\u201d \n \nFullbeauty imports its goods from overseas via shipping containers, and its per-container shipping cost includes a fuel surcharge. \n \nShipping costs are also a factor on the other end, as Fullbeauty delivers its clothing to consumers. The apparel company uses FedEx, Edgington said, and the companies work together to each absorb some of the delivery cost. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s not much you can do (to prepare) other than establish strong relationships with transportation partners and try to figure out where the meeting point is,\u201d he said. \n \nMark DeFabis, CEO of Plainfield-based logistics company Integrated Distribution Services, said transportation costs \u201care inevitably going to go up\u201d \u2014 driven in part by higher fuel prices. \n \nDeFabis is chairman of Conexus\u2019 Indiana Logistics Council and of the International Warehouse and Logistics Association. \n \nIDS specializes in logistics for e-commerce companies. When shippers like UPS and FedEx charge more to cover their increased fuel costs, some of that gets passed down the line to IDS\u2019 clients. It\u2019s the logistics company\u2019s job to help mitigate that pain. \n \nThat might involve helping clients redesign their packaging, rethink where they ship products from, or bundle shipping so they can get volume discounts. \n \n\u2018A bit of skepticism\u2019 \n \nA sustained increase in gas prices would ripple through the used-car market, including Carmel-based KAR Auction Services. KAR runs auto auctions and provides related services, such as funding for used-car dealers.Fuel prices crept up in December and early January in response to news that OPEC countries, along with Russia, pledged to cut back on oil production, said Tom Kontos, chief economist for ADESA Analytical Services, a KAR business unit. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m casting a bit of skepticism about whether the supply curtailments will actually happen,\u201d Kontos said. \u201cThis situation won\u2019t necessarily be dramatic going forward.\u201d \n \nKAR\u2019s customers are wholesalers who buy cars for resale. When gas prices go up dramatically and continually \u2014 say, 50 cents over several weeks \u2014 KAR sees stronger demand for compact cars. Likewise, the reseller sees more interest in pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles when fuel prices fall. \n \nBut the situation is complex, Kontos said, and fuel prices aren\u2019t the only factor. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s just like a stock market,\u201d he said. \u201cYou see the value of used vehicles fluctuate based on all known news at that moment.\u201d \n \nAnd changes in the vehicle industry itself are making gas prices a less reliable indicator of vehicle demand, Kontos said. \n \nWhen gas prices sometimes passed $4 several years ago, he said, both consumers and manufacturers lost their taste for large vehicles. \n \nThe situation is different today, Kontos said, because technology and lighter parts mean even large vehicles are more fuel-efficient. And with the rise in crossover vehicles, there\u2019s less of a distinction than there used to be between, say, passenger vehicles and SUVs. \n \nSome business and government units are blunting the impact of price swings by locking in prices. \n \nFor example, in December, IndyGo inked a 12-month diesel fuel contract with Avon-based Co-Alliance LLP. The $3.1 million deal allows the bus service to buy up to 1.7 million gallons of diesel fuel at $1.78 per gallon. \n \nThat should cover about 80 percent of IndyGo\u2019s fuel needs this year, said spokesman Bryan Luellen. \n \nIndyGo started using fuel contracts a few years back, Luellen said, when prices were fluctuating wildly. \n \n\u201cThis has been our strategy for several years, to evaluate the market and lock in when it\u2019s advantageous,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cThe fluctuations are really damaging to the business, and we need predictability.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Energy industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Oil and gas news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Indianapolis news","group":"US regional"}],"title":"Pain at the pump: Gas prices heading up after years of decline","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Bartholomew","zipCode":"47201","state":"Indiana","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Columbus","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Columbus Republic","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657345","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"993"},"name":"Columbus Republic","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Miscellaneous"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.therepublic.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202523147","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:26Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"prem","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:28Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396110389","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"WOUNDS & INJURIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION FACILITIES & VENUES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SOCCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"HIGH SCHOOL SPORTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SPORTS INJURIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"KNEE DISORDERS & INJURIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SCHOOL SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BASKETBALL TOURNAMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BASKETBALL","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SPORTS INSTRUCTION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; INDIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"2259","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396110389&p=2kx&v=1&x=0FPV6K5WLlzryOyFw-7d6Q","id":"29396110389","content":"Ashlyn Huffman described it as extremely painful for about 10 seconds and said she had trouble catching her breath. \n \nKat Norman recalls being in shock and then feeling kind of numb for a couple of days. \n \nKelsey Patberg remembers about 15 seconds of pain, then rolling over and ripping out chunks of grass, it hurt so bad. \n \nAsk anyone who\u2019s had an anterior cruciate ligament knee injury, better known as an ACL, and they will tell you it\u2019s not the most pleasant experience. Then, throw in the grueling rehab process and the emotion of having to miss games and practices, and the injury can take a significant toll on any athlete. \n \n Story continues below gallery  \n    \nColumbus North basketball players Kelsey Patberg, from left, Kat Norman, and Ashlyn Huffman pose for a portrait in the gymnasium at Columbus North High School in Columbus, Ind., Friday, Jan. 20, 2017. All three players recently had surgeries to repair their ACLs. Mike Wolanin | The Republic \n   \nColumbus North basketball players Kelsey Patberg, from left, Kat Norman, and Ashlyn Huffman pose for a portrait in the gymnasium at Columbus North High School in Columbus, Ind., Friday, Jan. 20, 2017. All three players recently had surgeries to repair their ACLs. Mike Wolanin | The Republic \n   \nNorth's Ashlyn Huffman, right, drives into the key during the 60 - 48 loss to Perry Meridian at Perry January 7, 2017. Greg Jones/For The Republic \n   \nNorth's Ashlyn Huffman, left, drives to the basket against Southport's Emma DeHart during the win against Southport at Memorial Gym January 5, 2017. \n   \nColumbus North's Ashlyn Huffman, right, dribbles past Evansville Memorial's Kendall Falkenstein, left, during a basketball game in the Columbus North Invitational presented by Subway at Columbus North High School in Columbus, Ind., Thursday, Dec. 22, 2016. Mike Wolanin | The Republic \n   \nColumbus North's Ashlyn Huffman, in white, shoots a lay up against the Zionsville defense during the championship basketball game for the Subway Columbus North Basketball Invitational at Columbus North High School in Columbus, Ind., Friday, Dec. 23, 2016. Mike Wolanin | The Republic \n    \n\u201cI was still crying after the pain was gone just because I was scared,\u201d Patberg said. \u201cI know that a pop comes with an ACL injury, so I knew that\u2019s what it was. But I was scared because I didn\u2019t want it to be that.\u201d \n \nPatberg, like Huffman and Norman, are Columbus North girls basketball players. All tore their ACLs within three months of each other last summer, and all have missed at least part of this season. \n \nBecause Patberg\u2019s injury did not happen until September \u2014 during a soccer practice \u2014 and because she\u2019s a junior, doctors advised her not to rush the knee to try to get back this basketball season. She does not plan to play soccer this fall and is focused on getting back for next basketball season. \n \nHuffman, a senior, and Norman, a junior, meanwhile, are back in their familiar roles for a North team that will host its sectional beginning Tuesday and concluding on Saturday. Huffman, who tore the ACL in her left knee July 8 while playing with the Skye Diggs Elite AAU team, missed the Bull Dogs\u2019 first five games before returning to her starting point guard spot. \n \nPreviously, Huffman had torn the ACL in her right knee while at Franklin Central before transferring to North. Then last February, she tore the meniscus in her right knee during the regional. \n \n\u201cBut even now that I\u2019m back playing, you get stuck in stuff, and some habits form that aren\u2019t always the best and it gets frustrating sometimes, like \u2018Will I ever be back to where I was?\u2019\u201d Huffman said. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of that that goes through your mind. But I know from my previous ACL, I made it back to where I was before that, so that helped a lot with my confidence, knowing that I can get there again.\u201d \n \nNorman tore her ACL on July 23 while playing for the Indiana Faith AAU team. The junior forward was along the baseline, and a teammate threw a low pass from the top of the key. Norman tried to catch it and landed awkward, and the knee popped. \n \nSince making a brief appearance in the North Invitational just before Christmas, Norman has seen increased playing time coming off the bench. \n \n\u201cI was really upset (with the injury) because I had been working hard all summer, trying to get better and getting in shape,\u201d Norman said. \u201cThen, when I got hurt, it was just kind of a bummer to know that hard work might not have paid off, or I might not be able to continue for awhile and have to redo everything.\u201d \n \nAnatomy of the knee \n \nThe ACL is in the center of the knee. Its main function is to stop the tibia from sliding forward when the knee stops. It is not used in straight-line running.\u201cI always liken the ACL to a seat belt,\u201d said Dr. Cary Guse, a surgeon with Southern Indiana Orthopedics. \u201cYou have it on at all times in the car, but it\u2019s not always used. There are many times when an ACL is not being used at all.\u201d \n \nWhen injured, the ACL can tear off the top side of the bone (the femur) or the bottom bone (the tibia) or can just tear in half. \n \nIf the ACL is not functioning and is torn, it will not recover. The knee will shift and give out. \n \nGuse said some middle-aged and older people can get by without an ACL since they\u2019re not running, jumping or shifting as much as young athletes. He said it would be atypical to return to high-level athletics with a torn ACL. \n \nGirls at higher risk \n \nGuse said there\u2019s no question that females have risk factors that can\u2019t easily be changed. He said girls are three to seven times more likely to tear an ACL than boys.Girls have a wider pelvis than boys, which causes a higher knee angle that puts more force on the ACL. Guse said females also are quad-dominant, which also puts more stress on the ACL. \n \nDr. Ilya Schwartzman, who doubles as the East girls soccer coach, agreed that these factors tend to put girls at greater risk. He has had players of all shapes and sizes tear their ACLs. \n \n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t seem to matter the build,\u201d he said. \u201cSoccer, because there\u2019s so much change of direction and stop-and-go-action and pressure on the knee, it happens. It\u2019s a risk that every athlete takes when they play sports.\u201d \n \nGuse said single-sport athletes also have a higher risk of injury than multi-sport athletes since they are using the same muscles over and over again. \n \nColumbus North girls basketball coach Pat McKee, who lost two of his players during summer basketball, thinks specialization might be a factor. He said the injuries tend to happen more on the summer AAU circuit where teams are playing game after game after game, putting more stress on players\u2019 knee ligaments. \n \n\u201cIs there adequate rest time? Is there adequate re-warmup time when you\u2019re in the second or third game of the day? I\u2019m not saying there isn\u2019t, but I\u2019m not sure there\u2019s as much monitoring of that in a summer environment as there is in a winter school environment,\u201d McKee said. \n \nAfflicting the stars \n \nPossibly the two most accomplished female athletes ever to come out of Columbus haven\u2019t been able to avoid an ACL tear. \n \nSoccer player Morgan Proffitt was out of action about four months, while basketball player Ali Patberg missed an entire year. \n \nProffitt tore her ACL playing club soccer the summer before her senior year at North, calling it the worst pain of her life for about 10 seconds. She returned on senior night and played in the sectional, then enjoyed a stellar four-year career at Marquette University that was capped by selection as Big East Defensive Player of the Year. \n \nEarlier this month, Proffitt was selected in the second round of the Women\u2019s Professional Soccer League by the Chicago Red Stars. She said missing most of her senior year in high school wasn\u2019t easy. \n \n\u201cI hadn\u2019t been majorly injured up until that point. So to be out four to six months, that\u2019s pretty tough,\u201d Proffitt said. \u201cI had to do my rehab while they were out competing. It\u2019s definitely tough mentally and physically.\u201d \n \nAli Patberg, who is Kelsey\u2019s cousin, tore her ACL on Nov. 2, 2015, during preseason practice at Notre Dame. That happened just six months after leading the Bull Dogs to the Class 4A state title and earning Indiana Miss Basketball and McDonald\u2019s All-American honors. \n \nWhile working out with the team last summer, Ali Patberg began experiencing pain. She had a second surgery Aug. 3 to remove bone spurs from her surgically repaired right knee. \n \nFinally, Patberg returned to the court when Notre Dame practice began in October. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s a very long process,\u201d she said. \u201cIt gets better every day. I didn\u2019t play basketball for about a year, so it\u2019s rough.\u201d \n \nAli Patberg said she\u2019s not back to 100 percent yet, but she\u2019s close, noting that she has started to be more aggressive offensively and is moving well laterally on defense. \n \nSince coming back from a case of pneumonia that sidelined her for 2½ weeks and allowed the knee time to rest, Patberg has been playing without a knee brace that she wore at the beginning of the season. \n \n\u201cThe biggest part to the whole thing is mentally thinking you\u2019re OK,\u201d Patberg said. \u201cI don\u2019t even realize in a game that I tore my ACL. That\u2019s where you mentally get over the hump.\u201d \n \nPrevention and rehab \n \nSeveral years ago, North teamed with Columbus Regional Hospital to do an ACL prevention program for volleyball and basketball players. Players went through exercises designed to prevent ACL injuries every day before or after practice for six weeks.Guse said the biggest preventative measure is quad strength and making sure athletes have two equally strong legs \u2014 not one good leg and one bad leg. If they\u2019re landing in a knock-kneed position, there is much more force. \n \nThe prevention programs are designed to make the quads stronger and make sure the athlete is landing balanced \u2014 not on one leg more than the other \u2014 and with the knees straight up and down. \n \nGuse said the thinking was that if they do exercises such as hamstring curls for 5 or 10 minutes a day, they might minimize that risk. To his knowledge, nobody in that pilot prevention program at North tore their ACL that year. \n \nMeanwhile, Schwartzman began putting his girls soccer teams through plyometric and strengthening programs about 10 years ago. The plan worked \u2014 at the beginning. \n \n\u201cAfter initiating it, we had a few years of no injuries, and we thought we were onto something,\u201d Schwartzman said. \u201cBut then we had it again. Unfortunately, they still keep occurring, despite the best intentions to prevent it.\u201d \n \nPeople who tear their ACLs are at risk of tearing the same ACL or the one in the opposite knee. Guse cited a study by the Moon Group, a collaboration of ACL experts across the country, that showed a 7 percent to 10 percent recurrent rate nationally. \n \nFollowing surgery, Guse puts patients through six stages or rehab \u2014 swelling control, range of motion, strength, balance, sport-specific movements and explosion. A lot of the rehabilitation centers around getting rid of the recurrent risk factors that they can. \n \nThe long road back \n \nLike her first ACL surgery 2½ years ago, Huffman\u2019s absence from the court lasted about four months following her latest surgery.\u201cI\u2019m very, very thankful for that because you have to have a lot of things go right for a four-month recovery, and I have a mom who\u2019s a physical therapist, which was extremely helpful,\u201d Huffman said. \u201cThe first month is definitely the hardest in therapy. If you can get through that, you can get through almost anything after that.\u201d \n \nNorman was out for 15 weeks following her surgery. She said she could gradually do more and more exercised with every rehab appointment she attended. \n \nKelsey Patberg, who is 4½ months removed from her injury, has been cleared to run and jump but not practice. \n \nHuffman, who last week committed to play at Cedarville (Ohio) University, admitted she sometimes thinks about her surgically-repaired knees when she\u2019s out on the court. She hopes to get back to being as aggressive as she was before the latest injury. \n \n\u201cSometimes, I\u2019ll be sitting in a timeout, and be like, \u2018What if this is the next play that is another knee injury?\u2019\u201d Huffman said. \u201cOn the court, I\u2019ll tweak it sometimes and get a little nervous.\u201d \n \nNorman, meanwhile, said she usually doesn\u2019t think about her injury. \n \n\u201cI just go out there and play, and it usually doesn\u2019t bother me,\u201d she said. \u201cI just try to play as hard as I can and do whatever I can to help my teammates and just play hard and work on my conditioning and get better.\u201d \n \nBoth Norman and Huffman said they\u2019re glad to be done with rehab and are happy to be back on the court. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s a new love for the game when you\u2019re out for that long,\u201d Huffman said. \u201cIt\u2019s frustrating, but when you get back, even when things aren\u2019t going your way, it\u2019s good to be able to take a step back and say, \u2018At least I\u2019m playing.\u2019\u201d \n \nIncidence rates of high school sports injuries \n  \nA Journal of Athletic Training High School Sports-Related Injury Surveillance Study from the 2007-08 through 2011-12 school years lists girls basketball as having the highest rate of ACL injuries as a proportion to all injuries in that sport. Editing by Susan Fenton) \n     Things to do in Boston this weekend: 'Really,' A Fish Called Wanda' and CRASHfest come to town  \nTHEATER Really Company One presents the New England premiere of this play by Jackie Sibblies Drury, about two women sifting through the work of a deceased photographer they both knew, searching for insight into his life and mind. So to catch up, you have to leave your house and buy a ticket. One title you can watch instantly, from the comfort of your recliner, is one of this year\u2019s unexpected moneymakers: That darkly comic dystopia in which single people have 45 days to find a romantic partner or else they\u2019re turned into an animal of their choice. \u201cThe Lobster\u201d nabbed a nom for... \n    Cate Le Bon makes poetic songs for absurd times  \nCate Le Bon is well aware that we live in strange times. That\u2019s the premise for the Welsh singer/songwriter\u2019s new EP \u201cRock Pool\u201d (out today), which came out of the same recording sessions as her 2016 record \u201cCrab Day.\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s almost a reactionary language to the absurdity and horror of the times we\u2019re living in,\u201d says Le Bon, who now lives in Los Angeles. She wrote these songs before Donald Trump came into power and Brexit happened, but she certainly recognizes their significance now. Now 37, Bombino has made recording and performing Tuareg rock across the globe his calling. Beginning tonight, Dead of Winter: Cinema of the Occult is a weeklong celebration of black magic at the movies, offering panel discussions, multimedia presentations and a dozen films depicting dark rituals and necromancy \u2014 everything from Kim Novak bewitching Jimmy Stewart in 1958\u2019s \u201cBell, Book & Candle\u201d to unholy bonds with a goat named Black Phillip in last year\u2019s indie smash, \u201cThe Witch.\u201d The Brattle\u2019s creative director Ned Hinkle enlisted... \n    Asghar Farhadi on why he returned to Iran for 'The Salesman'  \nWith 2011\u2019s \u201cA Separation,\u201d Asghar Farhadi went from an Iranian filmmaker largely known among the film festival circuit to an international master. The drama won the Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film and was nominated for its screenplay. Farhadi went to France next, making \u201cThe Past.\u201d Then he decided to return home. For 20 minutes, we descend into the basement of a gay sex club, where bodies bathed in red and blue lights \u2014 and... \n   5 Photos  You can BOGO poke bowls at Pokéworks this weekend  \nHawaiian poke bowls are taking over the Boston area. Poké City in Porter Square and Love Art Sushi in Back Bay just opened this week, joining Manoa also in Porter from earlier this month and Sushirito in Beacon Hill on the way. [Eater Boston has a solid tracker for the area's official poké watch.] Meanwhile, the first poke stop we heard about is Davis Square\u2019s Pokéworks, who are celebrating their official grand opening on Saturday, Jan. 28. You meet new people. You experience wonderful things, and it's all with the book held in your own hand.\" \n\nFor Edie Bustle and her husband Larry, reading is an important part of their lives \u2014 both volunteer in the community reading to children. In fact, former Manatee County Commissioner Larry Bustle says that in retirement, his occupation is reading. \n\n\"We both love to read,\" Edie Bustle said. \"This was a wonderful way to pay back and see kids read as opposed to play games on the computer.\" \n\nAs a way to ensure more of today's youth become lifelong learners, the Bustles are hoping that the upcoming \"An Evening with Nicholas Sparks\" event, which they are co-chairing, will be a success. Proceeds from the Feb. 7 event at Neel Performing Arts Center benefit Manatee Library System's \"I Am a Lifelong Learner\" program. \n\n\"It's a great way to support the library system in Manatee County and I think we are both very supportive of the lifelong learning project that the library foundation and the library is promoting,\" Larry Bustle said. \n\nWith tickets still available for the Sparks event, there are some ticket promotions \u2014 a 2-for-1 ticket special and a $25 ticket promotion for educators as well as Manatee County high school and Manatee/Sarasota college students. For tickets, call 941-216-8746. \n\n\"The Library Foundation's fund-raising efforts for this event are aimed at improving literacy in Manatee County through excellent library service,\" said Susan Wilcox, foundation event chairwoman. \"This year we are delighted to have the opportunity to offer a position of our seating to educators and to other literacy advocates in our community at a reduced rate. It is one small gesture to let these literacy partners and providers know how important they are and how much we appreciate their life's work.\" \n\nThe Sparks event is the third such program, which has previously brought authors Stephen King and John Grisham to town and raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the county's library system. \n\n\"The money raised from this event is going to go into the lifelong learner program,\" Edie Bustle said. \"We strongly support that, and reading is one of the most important things a child ever learns to do because it opens so many doors.\" \n\nThe library's \"I Am a Lifelong Learner\" literacy program \"aims to improve literacy by targeting the area's youngest readers by providing a Lifelong Learner Campaign Coordinator to meet families at the point-of-need and offer outreach programs to develop literacy skills,\" a news release states. \n\nThe focus is getting students to read at grade level by third grade, Larry Bustle said. \n\n\"Prior to third grade, you are learning to read. After grade three, you are reading to learn,\" he said. \n\nAs a former commissioner, Larry Bustle said there is just not enough money to do all the things that are needed. \n\n\"That's going to go a long way to help lifelong learners,\" he said of the event. \n\nSince the announcement that Sparks would be speaking at the event, the Bustles have been diving into his novels as well as watching \"The Notebook.\" \n\nOn Wednesday morning, three of Sparks' books \u2014 \"The Last Song,\" \"A Walk to Remember\" and \"Message in a Bottle\" \u2014 were on the Bustles' coffee table. \n\n\"This one is another happy yet sad book,\" Edie Bustle said of \"Message in a Bottle.\" \"I really like this one \u2014 and the ending was a surprise.\" \n\nFor the Bustles, it came as a surprise that they would be co-chairs of the event, which comes just after Larry Bustle finished his time in public service and Edie Bustle ended her time on the Library Board of Trustees. \n\n\"That was a big surprise,\" Edie Bustle said. \n\nLarry added: \"It was.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"CLAIRE ARONSONThe Bradenton Herald"},"topics":[],"title":"Couple ensures today's youth become on U.S. President Donald Trump and his ban on refugees from Muslim-majority countries (all times local): \n \n3 a.m. \n \nThe Homeland Security Department says a New York court order temporarily barring the U.S. from deporting people from nations subject to President Donald Trump\u2019s travel ban will not affect the overall implementation of the White House executive action. \n \nThe agency said the court order affected a relatively small number of travelers who were inconvenienced by security procedures upon their return. \n \nThe department\u2019s statement said: \u201cPresident Trump\u2019s Executive Orders remain in place\u2014 prohibited travel will remain prohibited, and the U.S. government retains its right to revoke visas at any time if required for national security or public safety,\u201d according to the DHS statement. \n \nStephen Miller, a senior adviser to the White House, said that nothing in the judge\u2019s order \u201cin anyway impedes or prevents the implementation of the president\u2019s executive order which remains in full, complete and total effect.\u201d \n \n11 p.m. \n \nForeign-born U.S. residents who could have been barred from re-entering the United States under President Donald Trump\u2019s immigration order have been allowed back into the country. \n \nThat\u2019s according to a Department of Homeland Security official who briefed reporters on Saturday night. The official spoke on condition of anonymity because the official wasn\u2019t authorized to publicly discuss details of the matter. \n \nTrump\u2019s order Friday barred citizens of seven Muslim-majority nations from entering the United States for 90 days. That meant that even those with permanent residency \u201cgreen cards\u201d or other visas risked not being let back in to the United States. \n \nHowever, the official said all green card holders from the seven countries who sought to enter the U.S. Saturday were granted special permission. \n \nIt\u2019s not clear if other green card holders will be admitted. The official said cases are being reviewed individually. \n \n\u2014 Alicia Caldwell \n \n9:40 p.m. \n \nA federal judge in New York has issued an emergency order temporarily barring the U.S. from deporting people from nations subject to President Donald Trump\u2019s travel ban. \n \nU.S. District Judge Ann Donnelly issued the order Saturday evening after lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union filed a court petition on behalf of people from seven predominantly Muslim nations who were detained at airports across the country as the ban took effect. \n \nCheers broke out in a crowd of demonstrators outside a Brooklyn courthouse as the decision, effective nationwide, was announced. \n \nThe order barred U.S. border agents from removing anyone who arrived in the U.S. with a valid visa from Iraq, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia and Yemen. \n \nIt also covered anyone with an approved refugee application. \n \nIt was unclear how quickly the order might affect people in detention. \n \n7 p.m. \n \nNew York City\u2019s Kennedy Airport became a scene of anguish Saturday for relatives of people detained after arriving in the U.S. from nations subject to President Donald Trump\u2019s travel ban. \n \nLawyers and advocates working at the airport say they didn\u2019t have a hard count on the number of people taken into custody after getting off their flights. \n \nYosre Ghaled was among about a dozen distraught people waiting at a terminal Saturday to see if loved ones would be released or deported. \n \nShe says her mother-in-law\u2019s sister had been detained. \n \nThe 67-year-old Yemeni citizen had flown to the U.S. to live with family because she is sick from heart problems and diabetes. \n \nTwo members of congress joined hundreds of protesters at the airport, demonstrating against the detentions. \n \n1 a.m. \n \nThe government of Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto is taking exception to the Israeli prime minister\u2019s praise of a border wall to keep out illegal immigration. \n \nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Twitter Saturday that \u201cPresident Trump is right\u201d for building a wall. \n \n\u201cI built a wall along Israel\u2019s southern border,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIt stopped all illegal immigration. Great success. Great idea.\u201d \n \nMexico\u2019s Foreign Ministry said in a communique that it had expressed its \u201cprofound surprise, rejection and disappointment in the prime minister\u2019s message on Twitter\u201d to Israel\u2019s ambassador. \u201cMexico is Israel\u2019s friend and should be treated as such.\u201d \n \n____ \n \n12:20 a.m. \n \nPresident Donald Trump says his crackdown on refugees and citizens from seven majority-Muslim countries \u201cis not a Muslim ban.\u201d \n \nA day after signing an executive order implementing the ban immediately, Trump says it\u2019s \u201cworking out very nicely.\u201d \n \nBut confusion, worry and outrage boiled over Saturday as airlines blocked people from traveling to the United States and legal challenges were mounted. \n \nIncluded is a 90-day ban on travel to the U.S. by citizens of Iraq, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia and Yemen. The U.S. refugee program is suspended for 120-days. \n \nTrump\u2019s order imposed the most aggressive ban on Syrians, indefinitely blocking entry to the U.S. by anyone from that country, including those fleeing civil war. \n \n12:10 a.m. \n \nAirlines around the world are turning away passengers, refunding tickets and rebooking flights in the aftermath of President Donald Trump\u2019s immigration order. \n \nThe order signed Friday included a 90-day ban on travel to the U.S. by citizens of Iraq, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia or Yemen. It also suspended the U.S. refugee program for four months. \n \nThat forced airlines to tell some customers they couldn\u2019t proceed on flights to the U.S. \n \nDubai-based Emirates said a small number of its passengers were affected Saturday, and it was helping them rebook. Delta Air Lines and British Airways both said they were offering refunds for passengers who couldn\u2019t complete their trips. \n \nSeveral airlines, including Qatar Airways, posted travel alerts on their websites warning customers about the changes. \n \n____ \n \n11:50 p.m. \n \nIn Tehran, Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif says his country\u2019s decision to not issue give Americans visas will not be retroactive. \n \nZarif says on Twitter: \u201cUnlike the U.S., our decision is not retroactive. All with valid Iranian visa will be gladly welcomed.\u201d \n \nU.S. visa restrictions that took effect on Saturday for people from several countries, including Iran, ban travel even for those who already had American visas. \n \n____ \n \n11:20 p.m. \n \nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has a message for refugees rejected by U.S. President Donald Trump: Canada will take you. \n \nTrudeau tweeted Saturday \u201cTo those fleeing persecution, terror & war, Canadians will welcome you, regardless of your faith. Diversity is our strength #WelcomeToCanada .\u201d \n \nTrudeau also tweeted a picture of him greeting a Syrian child at Toronto\u2019s airport. \n \nTrudeau oversaw the arrival of more than 39,000 Syrian refugees soon after he was elected in late 2015. \n \nThe young prime minister has been reluctant to criticize President Donald Trump. His government has been trying to balance his liberal view of the world while not offending the new Trump administration. \n \nMore than 75 percent of Canada\u2019s exports are to the U.S. \n \n10:20 p.m. \n \nAn Iraqi who was detained overnight at a New York City airport because of President Donald Trump\u2019s ban on refugees from certain Muslim nations has called America \u201cthe land of freedom\u201d after being released from custody. \n \nHameed Khalid Darweesh worked as an interpreter for the U.S. Army when it invaded Iraq in 2003. Later he was a contract engineer for the U.S. \n \nHe was granted permission to relocate to the U.S., but was detained along with another traveler from Iraq after arriving at John F. Kennedy Airport Friday night. \n \nLawyers petitioned a federal court early Saturday to let them go. Two Democratic U.S. Representatives, Nydia Velazquez and Jerrold Nalder, were at the airport trying to get 11 other detainees released. \n \nAfter he was freed Saturday, Darweesh told a waiting crowd that \u201cAmerica is the greatest nation, the greatest people in the world.\u201d \n \n9:50 p.m. \n \nIn Somalia, people are reacting with dismay and warnings that countries could retaliate against the United States\u2019 new immigration and visa policies with restrictive policies of their own. \n \n\u201cI am shocked beyond words. This will mean that my new husband will never be able to join me in the U.S.,\u201d said Fatima Ashkir, a Somali-American woman from Florida who came to Mogadishu to marry her Somali boyfriend. \n \nOthers say they are not surprised at President Donald Trump\u2019s executive order imposing a three-month ban on refugees from seven Muslim-majority countries, including Somalia. \n \n\u201cHis intentions of hurting rather than to help were clear from the very beginning,\u201d said Ahmed Abdullahi, a university student in Mogadishu. \u201cBut you have to know that this will have a serious effect on relations between Americans and the Muslim world. A tit-for-tat response by Muslim countries, in which Americans could be barred from entering countries affected, is likely to be seen.\u201d \n \n8:30 p.m. \n \nIran\u2019s foreign ministry is suggesting the country will limit issuing visas to American tourists in retaliation for U.S. President Donald Trump\u2019s suspension of immigration and visas for nationals from Muslim countries including Iran. \n \nThe official IRNA news agency Saturday carried a statement by the Iranian foreign ministry that says Iran will resort to \u201ccounteraction\u201d to Trump\u2019s executive order. \n \nThe statement says: \u201cIran, to defend the dignity of the great Iranian nation, will implement the principle of reciprocity until the removal of the insulting restriction against Iranian nationals.\u201d \n \nThe statement adds: \u201cIt will apply corresponding legal, consular and political actions.\u201d \n \nThe two countries have had no diplomatic relations since 1979 when militants stormed the U.S. embassy. \n \n8 p.m. \n \nCairo airport officials say five U.S.-bound Iraqi migrants from one family who have been prevented from boarding an EgyptAir flight to New York\u2019s John F. Kennedy airport would return to Iraq. \n \nThey said the five will spend Saturday night at Cairo airport and leave for Irbil, capital of Iraq\u2019s Kurdish region, Sunday morning. \n \nThey added that the sixth U.S.-bound migrant, a Yemeni national, left the airport to return to Cairo, where he resides. \n \nThe officials said Saturday\u2019s action by the airport was the first since President Donald Trump imposed a three-month ban on refugees from seven Muslim-majority countries: Iraq, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia and Yemen. \n \nThe officials said the six migrants, escorted by officials from the U.N. refugee agency, were stopped from boarding the plane after authorities at Cairo airport contacted their counterparts in JFK airport. \n \nThe officials spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to brief the media. \n \n(This story corrects the number of U.S.-bound Iraqi migrants to five, not six) \n \n\u2014 Hamza Hendawi. \n \n7:05 p.m. \n \nDutch airline KLM says it has had to turn away seven would-be passengers because they would no longer have been accepted into the United States under President Donald Trump\u2019s ban on immigration from seven Muslim-majority nations. \n \nManel Vrijenhoek, at KLM\u2019s press office, said: \u201cWe would love to bring them there. That\u2019s not the problem. It\u2019s just that this is what the U.S. sprang on the rest of the world \u2014 that these people are no longer welcome.\u201d \n \nShe said the seven were due to fly with KLM from different airports around the world. Vrijenhoek said she had no specifics on their nationalities, although she confirmed they were from countries affected by the three-month immigration ban: Iraq, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia and Yemen. \n \nTrump signed the order Friday. \n \n6:40 p.m. \n \nA U.S. federal law enforcement official says any non-U.S. citizen from Iraq, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia or Yemen is now barred from entering the United States. \n \nThat covers legal permanent residents \u2014 green card holders \u2014 and visa-holders from those seven countries who are out of the United States after Friday, when President Donald Trump signed an executive order with the temporary ban. They cannot return to the U.S. for 90 days. \n \nThe official says there\u2019s an exemption for immigrants and legal permanent residents whose entry is in the U.S. national interest, but it\u2019s unclear how that exemption will be applied. \n \nThe official says visa and green card holders already in the U.S. will be allowed to stay. \n \nThe official wasn\u2019t authorized to publicly discuss the details of how Trump\u2019s order is being put in place and spoke only on condition of anonymity. \n \nCustoms and Border Protection is notifying airlines about passengers whose visas had been canceled or legal residents scheduled to fly back to the U.S., and the airlines are being told to keep them off those flights. \n \n\u2014 Alicia Caldwell \n \n6:35 p.m. \n \nIsrael\u2019s leader has endorsed President Donald Trump\u2019s plan to build a wall along the Mexican border. \n \nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu tweeted Saturday that Israel\u2019s wall along its border with Egypt has been successful in stopping a swell of African migrants. \n \n\u201cPresident Trump is right. I built a wall along Israel\u2019s southern border. It stopped all illegal immigration. Great success. Great idea,\u201d he wrote, with images of the Israeli and American flag. \n \nThe tweet marked a rare public foray for the Israeli leader into a charged American domestic affair. The two leaders spoke earlier this week and Netanyahu is planning to visit Trump in the White House next month. \n \nAfter repeated clashes with President Obama, Netanyahu has high expectations for Trump, who has signaled he will take a kinder approach. \n \n5:45 p.m. \n \nMalala Yousafzai, shot in the head by the Pakistani Taliban in 2012 to stop her campaigning for girls\u2019 education and co-winner of the 2014 Nobel peace prize, says she is heart-broken by U.S. President Donald Trump\u2019s ban on refugees from entering the United States for four months. \n \nThe order Friday suspends a program that saw around 85,000 people displaced by war, political oppression, hunger and religious prejudice resettled in the U.S. last year. Trump indefinitely blocked people fleeing Syria\u2019s civil war, and imposed a 90-day ban on U.S. entry from seven Muslim majority nations. \n \nIn a statement Saturday, Yousafzai implores Trump \u201cnot to turn his back on the world\u2019s most defenseless children and families.\u201d \n \nRefugees and immigrants, she says, have \u201chelped build your country.\u201d \n \nTrump\u2019s mother was born in Scotland. \n \n5:15 p.m. \n \nQatar Airways is advising passengers bound for the United States from seven newly banned majority Muslim countries that they need to have either a U.S. green card or diplomatic visa to travel. \n \nA statement on the company\u2019s website says: \u201cNationals of the following countries: Sudan, Libya, Somalia, Syria, Iran, Iraq, Yemen \u2026 may travel to the U.S. only if they are in possession of a permanent resident card (Green card) or any of the below visas.\u201d \n \nIt listed foreign government, United Nations, international organization and NATO visas. \n \nPresident Donald Trump has issued a 90-day ban on all entry to the U.S. from countries with terrorism concerns, including Syria, Iraq and Libya. \n \n3 p.m. \n \nCairo airport officials say seven U.S.-bound migrants \u2014 six from Iraq and one from Yemen \u2014 have been prevented from boarding an EgyptAir flight to New York\u2019s John F. Kennedy Airport. \n \nThe officials said the action Saturday by the airport was the first since President Donald Trump imposed a three-month ban on refugees from seven Muslim-majority countries: Iraq, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, Somalia and Yemen. \n \nThe officials said the seven migrants, escorted by officials from the U.N. refugee agency, were stopped from boarding the plane after authorities at Cairo airport contacted their counterparts at the Kennedy airport. \n \nThe officials spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to brief the media. \n \n\u2014 Hamza Hendawi. \n \n2:45 p.m. \n \nThe head of a leading refugee aid agency says President Donald Trump\u2019s decision to ban Syrian refugees hurts innocents fleeing violence. \n \nJan Egeland of the Norwegian Refugee Council tells The Associated Press on Saturday that Trump\u2019s decision \u201cwill not make America safer, it will make America smaller and meaner.\u201d \n \nTrump on Friday suspended refugee admissions for four months and indefinitely banned those from war-torn Syria, pending program changes that are to ensure refugees won\u2019t harm national security. \n \nEgeland says the decision dealt a \u201cmortal blow\u201d to the idea of international responsibility for those fleeing persecution. He says the U.S. is leading a \u201crace to the bottom\u201d in which politicians in wealth countries provide \u201czero moral leadership.\u201d \n \n1 p.m. \n \nIran\u2019s President Hassan Rouhani says the time has come for removing walls between nations rather that building new ones. \n \nRouhani did not name any particular country but his remarks come shortly after President Donald Trump\u2019s executive order Friday suspending all immigration and visa processes for nationals from a handful of countries with terrorism concerns, including Iran, for 90 days. \n \nRouhani said Saturday that, \u201cIt is not the day for creating distance among nations.\u201d \n \nSpeaking at a tourism conference broadcast on state TV, Rouhani said that those seeking to create such walls, \u201chave forgotten that the Berlin Wall collapsed years ago.\u201d \n \n12:30 p.m. \n \nThe International Rescue Committee is calling President Donald Trump\u2019s suspension of the U.S. refugee resettlement program a \u201charmful and hasty\u201d decision. \n \nIn a statement issued late Friday night after the suspension was announced, IRC President David Miliband said, \u201cAmerica must remain true to its core values. America must remain a beacon of hope.\u201d \n \nThe IRC statement declared that the U.S. vetting process for prospective refugees is already robust \u2014 involving biometric screening and up to 36 months of vetting by \u201c12 to 15 government agencies.\u201d \n \nMiliband praised The United States\u2019 record as a resettlement destination and said, \u201cThis is no time for America to turn its back on people ready to become patriotic Americans.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Libya news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Iran news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Egypt news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Iraq news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Israel news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Yemen news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Somalia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"The Latest: Official says ruling will not affect travel ban","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Bartholomew","zipCode":"47201","state":"Indiana","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Columbus","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Columbus Republic","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657345","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"993"},"name":"Columbus Republic","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Miscellaneous"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.therepublic.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://twitter.com/search?q=%23WelcomeToCanada"],"sequenceId":"695202529150","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:14:28Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

OHIO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"529","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396110526&p=2kx&v=1&x=wSwM3KUnzXHPN7LsLKgCFQ","id":"29396110526","content":"One of major educational programs that OSU Extension conducts on behalf of the Ohio Department of Agriculture are the re-certification sessions for farmers who have a restricted private pesticide applicator license. \n \nIn order to purchase and buy restricted pesticides to help combat troublesome weeds, diseases and insects, farmers are required to pass a competency test from the Department of Agriculture and then attend a three-hour re-certification session every three years. \n \nIn 2017, we have 50 Ashtabula County farmers who will need to complete their re-certification by March 31. \n \nToday, I would like to share information on our upcoming re-certification programs and how non-licensed farmers can become certified. \n \nWe have only one private pesticide re-certification session remaining this winter for farmers to complete their private pesticide applicator renewal. \n \nWe had our first session Jan. 13 in Williamsfield and our second Jan. 27 at the Geauga County Extension office. \n \nSo our last chance for producers to obtain their re-certification close to home will be Feb. 8 at the Trumbull County Extension office.  \n \nThis session offers renewal credits for pesticide re-certification for CORE and for the six agricultural specific areas. \n \nThese agricultural specific areas include Category 1\u2014 Grain and Cereal Crops; Category 2 \u2014 Forage Crops and Livestock; Category 3 \u2014 Fruit and Vegetable Crops; Category 4 \u2014 Nursery and Forest Crops; Category 5 \u2014 Greenhouse Crops; and Category 6 \u2014 Fumigation.  \n \nThe registration fee is $35 per person for the private pesticide applicator re-certification session. Pre-registration is required eight days prior to the session date. An additional late registration fee of $25 per person will be added for any late registration. \n \nMore information can be obtained by calling the Geauga County Extension office 440-834-4656.
