to Hollywood's time-honored traditions helped deliver a big payoff that has so far eluded its streaming rival Netflix -- the first-ever best picture nomination for an online video service. \n \n\"Manchester by the Sea,\" a family tragedy set in Massachusetts, was nominated Tuesday for best picture by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences, one of nine movies that will vie for the top honor. The film secured six Oscar nominations in all, including ones for acting, writing and directing. \n \nWhile Netflix, the streaming leader with almost 94 million subscribers worldwide, has upended entertainment industry traditions, Amazon.com has played more by Hollywood's rules. In the movie business, that means giving motion pictures a serious run in theaters, rather than releasing them simultaneously online, as Netflix often does. \n \n\"They would both like Oscar glory, all the studios do,\" said Jeff Bock, senior box office analyst at Exhibitor Relations Co., an industry researcher. \n \nWhen Amazon buys a movie, Bock said, it comes with the vow the film will have a long run in theaters before showing up on the company's video service, a concession to directors and others who make their movies with big screens in mind. That means at least a month, the company has said. \n \n\"That isn't the case with Netflix right now,\" Bock said. \n \nSeattle-based Amazon acquired \"Manchester by the Sea\" for $10 million a year ago at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah. The film stars Casey Affleck as a janitor who returns to his hometown to look after his nephew following the death of his brother. But he struggles to cope with his own tragedy. Michelle Williams and Lucas Hedges are nominated for their supporting roles, while Kenneth Lonergan was nominated for his directing and writing. Roadside Attractions distributed the movie in U.S. theaters. \n \nThe world's largest online retailer, Amazon uses movies and TV shows to attract and keep customers. Its Prime members, who pay $99 a year for delivery discounts and media streaming, are more likely to stick around on the site and spend more than those who don't subscribe. Video watchers are also more inclined to renew their prime memberships. \n \nIn April, Amazon introduced a stand-alone Prime Video service featuring on-demand access to thousands of movies and Amazon originals for $8.99 a month. In all, Prime had about 65 million members in the U.S. at the end of September, up 38 percent from a year earlier, according to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners in Chicago, which surveys Amazon shoppers. \n \nAmazon's embrace by the movie industry stands in contrast to its years of feuding with book publishers and authors, who maintained that the company's low prices have undermined their industry. Most recently, that's been with electronic books priced far below printed material. \n \nNetflix is the world's largest paid video service. The streaming pioneer, the Los Gatos, California-based company spent $6 billion on TV shows and movies last year, and has won both Emmys and Academy Awards, including Oscars for best documentary. This year, the company earned an Oscar nomination for the documentary \"13th,\" which investigates the high rate of incarceration in the U.S., particularly among African Americans. Amazon spent $3 billion, according to estimates from Cowen & Co. \n \nNetflix also just registered its best quarter ever. The company added 7 million subscribers in the final three months of 2016 and 19 million for the year. \n \nMoreover, one Hollywood agent who sells films says the two services are picking movies that target different audiences, with Amazon aiming for shoppers who want more artistic fare. Amazon's promise of a theatrical run attracts makes the service more appealing to some of those filmmakers. \n \n\"They've been a great partner to the exhibition industry,\" said Ken Thewes, chief marketing officer at Regal Entertainment Group, the No. 2 U.S. theater chain. \"They absolutely have a different approach than Netflix. They have really respected the windows and we respect that.\" \n \nRegal has teamed up with Amazon on a $35 movie pass to show all the best picture nominees at theaters ahead of the Feb. 26 Academy Awards ceremony. At last year's annual exhibitor convention, CinemaCon, Amazon presented its upcoming slate just like a major Hollywood studio. In one year, the company released 15 films, as many as Paramount Pictures. \n \nNetflix wants to change the old model -- and show movies online to customers at the same time they're in theaters. With a growing global subscriber base, the company has financed a lot of films it says are popular that never had a shot at awards (or good reviews), like comedies starring Adam Sandler and Kevin James. \n \nRich Greenfield, an analyst at BTIG, said it's too soon to say whether one or the other has come out on top in feature films. Both companies have been spending on feature films at this year's Sundance festival, and Netflix has invested large sums in new movie projects including Brad Pitt's \"War Machine\" and a Will Smith picture called \"Bright.\" \n \n\"Let's see what happens when Netflix rolls out some of its far larger films bets later this year into next,\" Greenfield said. \"It's still early.\" \n \n--- \n \nBloomberg's Lucas Shaw and Spencer Soper contributed.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Movie business news","group":"Media"},{"name":"E-commerce news","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Digital distribution news","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Amazon steals Netflix's spotlight with Oscar nomination","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Cook","zipCode":"60006","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Arlington Heights","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"469483376","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4"},"name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://dhbusinessledger.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202718395","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:01Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"506","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396119665&p=2kx&v=1&x=xmPNW9N8DXtF39fIFyJ7rw","id":"29396119665","content":"It was supposed to be the first technology IPO of 2017. \n \nLess than a day before AppDynamics Inc. was set to price its shares Wednesday, a group of employees and investors boarded a plane to New York City to attend the traditional bell-ringing ceremony for new listings at the Nasdaq stock exchange, according to a person familiar with the details. \n \nTechnology executives, investors and financiers were closely watching the deal, considered a crucial bellwether among so-called unicorns headed for public markets. \n \nThe bell was never rung. Instead of updating investors on its projected market valuation, AppDynamics was the subject of a different announcement: It had agreed to be acquired by Cisco Systems Inc. for $3.7 billion. \n \nThe deal is seen by some advisers as the first in a long-expected wave of unicorn buyouts. With more than 150 companies valued at more than $1 billion and a temperamental IPO market, being acquired offers startups an exit from the funding roller coaster and can also shield them from the regulatory and investor scrutiny that comes with a public listing. At the same time, it can create the risk that the startup loses its culture, independence and key staffers when folded into a larger business. \n \nWhile dual-track processes -- when a company pursues both an IPO and gauges buyer interest -- are common, people with knowledge of the industry say AppDynamics' 11th-hour deal is the closest to listing day that they've seen a tech company get before selling instead. \n \nA representative for Cisco declined to comment on the details of the deal, while representatives for AppDynamics didn't immediately respond to a request for comment. \n \nBankers working on AppDynamics' initial public offering were kept in the dark until moments before the official release, people familiar with the matter said, asking not to be identified as the details aren't public. The roadshow for the IPO had been going well, and underwriters even thought the deal could end up oversubscribed, meaning investors wanted more shares. \n \nThey had already decided to increase the marketed price range to $12 to $14 per share from $10 to $12 apiece, which would give the company a market value of about $1.72 billion at the top of the range. \n \nBut behind the scenes, the company had tapped boutique advisory firm Qatalyst Partners to run a sale. AppDynamics deliberately chose an adviser with no links to its IPO underwriters to avoid any information about the potential deal leaking, the people said. \n \nA representative for Qatalyst didn't immediately respond to a request for comment. \n \nMeetings with Cisco and its advisers took place late at night in hotel rooms during the IPO roadshow, and only after underwriters and investors had gone home, they said. \n \nCisco, based in San Jose, had been on the scene for months, initially holding discussions with AppDynamics about potential partnerships between the two companies, the people said. It's a common move for software makers, which can team up and integrate certain services to jointly sell their products. Over the course of discussions, the people said, Cisco realized it wanted tighter integration: That meant making a knockout offer.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Communications equipment news","group":"Technology"},{"name":"Tech latest","group":"Technology"},{"name":"Mergers and acquisitions news","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Cisco Systems news","group":"Companies"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Could Cisco's 11th-hour AppDynamics deal pave the way for unicorn buyouts?","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Cook","zipCode":"60006","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Arlington Heights","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"469483376","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4"},"name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://dhbusinessledger.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202718644","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29378618451","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COMPUTER CRIME","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TEXT MESSAGING","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"MOBILE APPLICATIONS","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"652","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396119666&p=2kx&v=1&x=D2pjiWqsssW0_CjyHHF4nA","id":"29396119666","content":"President Donald Trump is arguably Twitter's most prominent user. But, as many outlets have reported over the past couple of days, the people operating his administration's Twitter accounts may not be using all their security options to the fullest. As CNN reported, a hacker specifically wrote to the president with tips on how to lock hackers out of his official Twitter account. \n \nAlthough your own Twitter account may not be as sought-after as the president's, the hubbub over the security of the White House's accounts is a good reminder for all Twitter users to take a spin through their settings. Below are some tips. \n \n\u2022 Require personal information to reset your password: This is the main tip that hacker WauchulaGhost recommended to the Trump Twitter team. It's also a tip that Twitter itself recommends in every password reset email. In Twitter settings, there's an option to require someone to put in a phone number or email address before they see your redacted password. \n \n\u2022 Verify your log-in requests: Look at the accompanying screenshot, and you'll see an option to \"verify login requests,\" which is Twitter's way of trying to de-jargonize the phrase \"two-factor authentication.\" Using two-factor authentication means signing in with a special code in addition to your password. The code can come via text, a login notification on your phone or by using an authentication mobile app that will automatically generate codes for you. Doing any of those things makes your account harder to hack, since it requires someone to both know your password and have access to your phone or text messages. \n \nYes, it's a bit of a pain, but it's worth it. \n \nAlso, if you receive your codes by text, don't reply to them. As my colleague Abby Ohlheiser reported, doing so will post whatever you reply straight to Twitter. Some theorize that this is how White House press secretary Sean Spicer ended up sending two apparently nonsensical eight-letter strings to his account two days in a row -- though the White House's official response is that both messages were a \"pocket tweet.\" \n \n\u2022 Use an email address that doesn't have your name attached to it: If you really don't want to use two-factor authentication, then do your best to register your Twitter account using an email address that isn't easy to guess. Why? If someone is trying to hack into your Twitter account, the first thing they'll probably do is try to figure out your email address, via the \"Forgot Password?\" link that shows a redacted version of your email address. \n \nIf your name is John Doe and your email address shows up as jd***@gmail.com, it's probably going to be pretty easy for a hacker to fill in the blanks. In fact, that's exactly what WauchulaGhost did with the @VP account. Per the CNN report: He said the email associated with Vice President Mike Pence was easy to guess once you saw the redacted version: vi***************@gmail.com, which WauchulaGhost pieced together as vicepresident2017@gmail.com. \n \n--- \n \nThe @VP account is no longer linked to a Gmail account. Nor is the @POTUS Twitter account, which was also tied to a personal Gmail account -- an address the Hill and others say appears to have belonged to White House director of social media Dan Scavino. That's not illegal -- though many companies and agencies have policies against using personal accounts for professional Twitter accounts. It's also arguably pretty insecure, depending on the security settings enabled on Gmail. \n \nSince that news broke, the account has been changed to link to two different accounts, which appear to have the government \"who.eop.gov\" domain. As of time of writing, it still did not have the personal information requirement enabled. \n \nThis tip won't always work, though. If you -- like many politicians and journalists -- must use a work account for Twitter to be verified, then that will generally make it pretty easy to figure out your address. In that case, two-factor is the way to go.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Blogging news","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Twitter security tips we can learn from the Trump administration","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Cook","zipCode":"60006","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Arlington Heights","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"469483376","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4"},"name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://dhbusinessledger.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202718816","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Classie Brigade was one of the country's best three year olds but his attempts to get one up on Lazarus, such as when second to the champion in both the Flying Stakes and the Derby, were always denied. \n \nClassie Brigade was driven by Blair Orange who is making a habit of winning Invercargill Cups. much-ballyhooed mobile-ordering system has brought a painful side effect to the coffee giant: traffic jams at the pickup counter. \n \nBecause customers are now able to order and pay for coffee via their phones, many of them now head directly to the part of the cafe where beverages are handed out. That's created pileups at Starbucks and frustrated some customers enough that they've canceled their orders, said Chief Operating Officer Kevin Johnson. \n \n\"The use of mobile order and pay continues to accelerate,\" Johnson said in an interview. \"That's created congestion at the handoff.\" \n \nThe snags hurt U.S. sales in the first quarter, contributing to disappointing results for the world's largest coffee chain. But the company has been working to correct the problem, Johnson said. \n \nThe stakes of getting the process right are high for Starbucks, which now generates 27 percent of its U.S. sales via mobile payments. The company is counting on the system to help attract customers and speed them through its stores. Johnson, a veteran of Microsoft and Juniper Networks, is ascending to the chief executive officer job in April -- a move seen as solidifying Starbucks' tech ambitions. \n \nStarbucks also cited a broader restaurant slump for creating a \"challenging environment\" last quarter. The company reined in its forecast for the full year, saying revenue will rise between 8 percent and 10 percent. It had previously predicted a double-digit increase. \n \nThe stock fell as much as 4.8 percent to $55.65 in New York on Friday after the results were released. Before the drop, Starbucks' shares had increased 5.3 percent this year, outpacing the 2.6 percent gain of the S&P 500 Index. \n \nJohnson is taking the reins from Howard Schultz, who served two stints as CEO and built Starbucks into a global coffee empire. Johnson inherits a company with \"outsized expectations\" for performance, said Jennifer Bartashus, an analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence. Against that backdrop, the company's 3 percent same-store sales growth last quarter wasn't good enough. \n \n\"In the realm of restaurants in general, 3 percent is not a bad result,\" she said. \"But Starbucks is considered more of a premium brand. LOANS","domains":["IND"],"score":"67"},{"name":"HOME PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"609","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396119693&p=2kx&v=1&x=iqit1Vwf-sa9aJDWSSMuqQ","id":"29396119693","content":"As the housing market nears full recovery, widening gaps along racial, socio-economic and generational lines are impacting the growth of the housing market and individual cities, according to a growing body of Zillow research, it was noted in a special report. \n \n\"For example, though millennials want to own homes, the share of young people living at home with their parents has increased sharply. \u2026 Housing affordability is twice as bad for those making a low income than those making a high income.\" \n \nThese inconsistencies in the housing market are causing problems to our general economy, according to the report. \n \n\"Our research on housing has unlocked issues that are closely linked to broader social and economic problems in the U.S. -- such as poor access to credit, weak income growth and social mobility,\" said Zillow Chief Economist Svenja Gudell. \n \nThe report focused primarily on young and first-time homebuyers and prospective buyers. \n \n\"The research shows that millennials want to own homes and have views about homeownership that are as conservative as their grandparents.\" But the share of millennials (18-34) living at home with their parents has increased sharply over the past decade. \n \n\"Since 2012, the share of younger millennials (18-25) living at home has decreased from 55.5 percent to 54.2 percent, while the share of older millennials -- those 26-34 who were scarred by the recession in their first years out of college -- has increased from 12.9 percent to 14.5 percent. \n \n\"Young people are renting for longer before buying their first home, compared to a generation ago. And although first-time buyers' incomes have not changed significantly, the median price of their first home has increased by about a quarter. \n \n\"Over the last 20 years, home values in the metro areas with the most social mobility have soared, making it difficult for low-income people to afford living in the very places where they could most easily achieve socio-economic growth. \n \n\"Nationwide, the bottom third income earners spend twice as much of their income on mortgage payments than the top third.\" \n \nIn some expensive markets, the report pointed out, those making incomes in the bottom third would have to spend more than half of that income to afford the monthly payment on the cheapest homes on the market. \n \nQ. Why are young couples (millennials) so active as homebuyers? \n \nA. One reason might be that they are producing more offspring and feel the need of being settled in a home of their own. \n \n\"Millennial motherhood is on the rise. Could the increase in births for the millennial generation bode well for real estate and finally convince them to move into homeownership?\" \n \nThat question was asked in a recent report by the National Association of Realtors. \n \n\"About 1.3 million millennial-aged women gave birth in 2015, which accounts for 82 percent of all U.S. births that year, according to Pew Research center data. Millennial women have lagged other generations in birthrates. \n \n\"Nearly half of Generation X women were already into motherhood by the time they were in the 18-to-33 age range, which millennials are at now.\" \n \nQ. What are predictions for commercial mortgages this year? \n \nA. Commercial and multifamily mortgage lending is expected to increase in 2017, as lenders' appetites to place new loans and borrowers' appetites to borrow both remain strong, according to a new Mortgage Bankers Association survey. \n \n\"Nearly two-thirds (63 percent) of the top firms expect originations to increase in 2017, with one-quarter (26 percent) expecting an increase of 5 percent or more. A full half (50 percent) expect their own firm's originations to increase by 5 percent or more,\" it was noted in a recent report. \n \n\"Commercial mortgage bankers expect 2017 to carry-over much of the momentum from 2016,\" said Jamie Woodwell, MBA's vice president for commercial real estate research. \n \n\u2022 Email Jim Woodard at storyjim@aol.com. \n \n© 2017, Creators Syndicate","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Gaps surface in national housing market","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Cook","zipCode":"60006","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Arlington Heights","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"469483376","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4"},"name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","Industrials"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://dhbusinessledger.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202720263","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:01Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JEFFREY R BINDER","domains":["PEO"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"1211","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396119751&p=2kx&v=1&x=goA1aGc9Emy8-E-groOqPw","id":"29396119751","content":"WASHINGTON -- If you've ever signed up for cable, you're probably familiar with those big, white vans your company usually sends with someone to help install your service. But a new cable company in town is teasing a very different experience. Instead of a corporate truck, what you might see at the curb is a BMW, or perhaps a Tesla. \n \nRunning on futuristic electric batteries rather than gasoline, the luxury vehicles reflect the kind of business Layer3 wants to be: An upscale, next-gen TV provider. But the way the company is going about it may not be what you expect. It is betting big on an old-school approach, one where the traditional, fat cable bundle is king and the customers are TV die-hards who don't buy into the newfangled streaming services flooding the market. \n \nAt a time when Americans are increasingly abandoning their cable companies -- flocking to alternatives such as Netflix and Hulu -- Layer3's premise is that the big bundle of basic and premium channels that has sustained the industry for decades is still a viable formula. \n \n\"We're the first cable company in ... 10 years to come that's brand new,\" said Jeff Binder, Layer3's chief executive. \"Consumers haven't had a young innovative company to provide [pay-TV] services to them since the mid-1990s, when Dish and DirectTV came on the scene.\" \n \nThat notion flies in the face of moves by major players -- AT&T, HBO, CBS -- that believe major industry change is afoot. These companies have embraced online streaming in a big way, launching flashy stand-alone apps that deliver content over the internet and to mobile devices in a bid to compete with Netflix. Some, such as AT&T, estimate there could be 20 million U.S. households to win over that don't currently subscribe to cable. \n \nFor mainstream TV firms, the right response to streaming is to start swimming with the tide. Layer3's first instinct is to swim in the other direction. \n \nAfter several pilot projects in Texas and Illinois, Layer3 launched last summer in the District of Columbia -- its first official market -- and it plans to expand into most major U.S. cities over the next two years. The company's standard package costs $79 a month and gives you about 150 channels as well as trial subscriptions to HBO and Epix; and optional add-ons include Showtime, Cinemax and Spanish-language content. The vast majority of Layer3's 250-channel lineup comes in high definition. \n \nIn interviews, executives declined to say how many customers have signed up. But they predict there may be as many as 35 million current cable subscribers who will not be lured away by online substitutes such as Dish's SlingTV or DirecTV Now, the new streaming service from AT&T. \n \nBut if the industry's biggest players think streaming is the future, what makes Layer3 think it can survive for the long haul? \n \nOne way of answering this is by looking not at how many households are cutting the cord every year, but at how much they earn. It turns out that the most avid cord-cutters among us tend to be lower-income Americans. Does your household make $75,000 a year or more? You're more likely to have stuck with your cable company than if your annual income is below $20,000. \n \nThose findings from the Pew Research Center may sound familiar to those who've canceled their subscriptions because of rising bills. For many Americans, cable is just too expensive. But Layer3 is more interested in the other folks -- the more affluent households that absolutely need their pay-TV and are still willing to shell out for it. This market may shrink as cord-cutting grows. But it's still enormous, and it's where Layer3 hopes to find its niche. \n \n\"It is certainly a counterintuitive strategy,\" said Craig Moffett, an industry analyst at MoffettNathanson. \"Theirs will be a high cost, and therefore high priced, alternative to a service that many believe is already too expensive. There's a premium segment in any market, but what remains to be seen is whether they can capture enough of that premium segment.\" \n \nTo help court those high-end customers, Layer3 is trying to improve on the reputation many cable providers have gained as stodgy, hulking corporations trying to nickel-and-dime their customers. It isn't just rolling out red-carpet customer service in the form of fancy cars or a \"white-glove\" customer experience, such as your ability to text the company whenever you have questions or concerns. It's also trying to lure subscribers with the promise of next-gen technology embedded in its product. \n \nLayer3's wireless set-top box supports 4K-resolution video. It offers a curated feed that automatically learns what you like to watch, and it has integration with Facebook and Twitter, along with a few other bells and whistles. Behind the scenes, the company manages a large backbone network that can pipe content all across the country; by year's end, Layer3 will control about 24,000 miles of fiber optic cable. \n \nAll of this is aimed at raising the bar for cable service, making it so that consumers feel they're actually getting what they pay for -- or more. \n \n\"It's no different than comparing an HTC to an Apple,\" Binder said. \"I think we can out-innovate. I think we can have a much better customer-relationship environment.\" \n \nBinder is fond of drawing the Apple parallel. He does it often, which is little surprise: The iPhone-maker's reputation for ease-of-use, strong design chops and a history as a technological disruptor provides much for Layer3 to emulate. \n \nThe analogy is appropriate in other ways, too. Apple's products are largely viewed as status symbols, particularly among the rich. Whether by hiring former Burberry executives or launching a $17,000 smartwatch, Apple has all but begged analysts to label the tech company a successful luxury brand. \n \nThere's money to be made at the high-end of the market, and Layer3 is figuring that out, just as Apple has. \n \nBut there's a major difference between the two companies: Whereas Apple earns incredible margins on the iPhone thanks to the relatively low cost of producing one, analysts say being a cable company of Layer3's size comes with steep fixed costs. \n \nThose costs include what cable companies pay to various programmers and channels to carry their content. These rights fees can reach as high as $7 per subscriber per month, in the case of a highly lucrative channel such as ESPN. Having a large customer base can help spread out these costs, but a niche player such as Layer3 will not have that advantage, according to Moffett. \n \nBut Layer3 doesn't need to be everywhere to succeed, according to its chief executive, Binder. It just needs to take enough market share from the big players to win. \n \n\"Maybe you can't quite build the next Facebook,\" he said, \"but you can build something really, really substantial with solid, single-digit percentages [of market share].\" \n \nOther analysts say Layer3 could gain an early edge in usability. With its next-generation set-top boxes, Layer3 may be among the first to integrate on-demand content from streaming services with live cable TV in a way that really pleases consumers, according to Rich Greenfield, a media analyst at BTIG. \n \nOther cable companies such as Comcast are working on similar platforms, he added, and it's possible that well-resourced competitors could start chipping away at Layer3's usability lead. \n \n\"But, given the slow pace of innovation in the TV industry, I'm not holding my breath.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Apple news","group":"Companies"},{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"},{"name":"CRM news","group":"Business"}],"title":"Layer3 bets on fat cable bundles, 'white-glove' customer service","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Cook","zipCode":"60006","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Arlington Heights","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"469483376","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4"},"name":"Daily Herald Business Ledger","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://dhbusinessledger.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695202720759","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:02Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-28T22:14:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29394783264","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"58"},{"name":"LAWYERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EXECUTIVE ORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; GEORGIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"ATLANTA, GA, USA; UNITED STATES; GEORGIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"JOHN LEWIS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"55"}],"wordCount":"266","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396119930&p=2kx&v=1&x=Msv_sntSJ_-6T1StMEs54g","id":"29396119930","content":"ATLANTA (CBS46) - \n\nCBS46 has learned that several people from Muslim countries have been detained at Hartsfield-Jackson Airport, Saturday.\n\nSarah Owings, with the American Immigration Lawyers Association says a husband, wife, child, and 76-year-old grandmother were four of the people detained. The husband and grandmother are now being released.\n\nShe says lawyers have not been given access to the detainees.\n\nAfter learning that four Georgia residents and about 40 others were detained in Atlanta, Rep. John Lewis released the following statement:\n\nI am deeply concerned to hear that permanent residents of the state of Georgia and dozens of others who have immigrated legally to this country\u2014submitting to all the laws, rules and regulations required\u2014were detained at the Hartsfield-Jackson Airport in Atlanta today. Apparently, they had visited relatives who remained in their native land, and one day after an executive order issued from the White House blocked access to this country, lawful permanent residents have been detained.\n\nPeople immigrate to America because they are inspired by our commitment to justice and democracy. To treat as strangers these law-abiding immigrants, to whom we as a nation have seen fit to grant permanent status, is a stain on the integrity of our country and threatens the democratic principles this nation stands for. This is a dark hour for America. 7:05 pm \n   \nAustralians who have travelled to any of the seven Muslim-majority nations under the Trump administration visa ban in the past six years will no longer be allowed to apply for a mandatory security check needed for entry to the United States. \n\nAs well, Australians who hold passports from Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen may potentially be turned away from the US. \n\nThe government's Smarttraveller website has updated its notifications warning travellers to the US about the controversial new rules. \n\nAustralians who are dual citizens of Iran, Iraq, Sudan or Syria will no longer be allowed to apply for the standard electronic travel authorisation - ETSA - which travellers must complete before heading to the US. \n\nThe ETSA is an online application that determines entry eligibility based on security or police risks. \n\n\"Any of these Australians who have previously been issued an ESTA are likely to have the ESTA revoked,\" the Smarttraveller website warns. \n\nAs well, Australians who have travelled to any of the seven implicated nations since March 2011 will also no longer be allowed to apply for that permit. \n\nThis also includes government officials or defence force members who are dual citizens of Iran, Iraq, Syria or Sudan, but there may be exceptions for some who travelled on official government or defence business. \n\nAll those affected will have to apply for a non-immigrant visa at a US embassy or consulate. \n\nForeign Minister Julie Bishop says officials are in talks with US counterparts to get clarity on how the order may affect Australians. \n\n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals,\" a spokeswoman told AAP in a statement. \n\nAll travellers are being warned that rules could change at short notice. \n\n\"Travellers should contact the nearest embassy or consulate of the United States for the most current information,\" the spokeswoman added.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Rashida Yosufzai"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"57"}],"wordCount":"494","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396121115&p=2kx&v=1&x=2jDqa1Yojz_SZZCdVn9aZw","id":"29396121115","content":"Founder of leading private tutoring firm Tutors International, Adam Caller, made a statement this week questioning whether traditional and current teaching methods and technologies can adequately prepare the next generation for the future of the workforce. \n \nLondon, UK (PRWEB UK) 29 January 2017 \n \nFounder of leading private tutoring firm Tutors International, Adam Caller, made a statement this week questioning whether traditional and current teaching methods and technologies can adequately prepare the next generation for the future of the workforce. \n \nMr. Caller raised the concern that modern educators and teaching methods may not be able to adequately prepare children, who are only just starting out in their academic journey, for life in 2050, and echoed the sentiments of Sir Ken Robinson [1] that a broad curriculum, individualised learning process, and creative teaching will be vital in delivering an education that these children will continue to benefit from in decades to come. \n \n\"We've seen massive advancements in our technology over the last two decades, so is it wise to be teaching children according to rigid constrictions imposed by following a formal educational curriculum when they won't be entering the workforce for another 10 years? When focusing their learning on what has gone before, how do we know that we are teaching them the right things for what comes next?\" \n \nThe focus, according to Mr Caller, may be better applied to a child's individual talents and skills, using creativity and adapting to advancements in technology and new information as they happen. \n \nMr Caller said: \"In private tutoring, we see time after time how focusing on a child's individual interests and talents, and adapting teaching styles and lesson planning to compliment them, results in a child who is more interested and eager to learn. Tutors International is now seeing clients who are already starting to look for 'outside the box' thinkers when selecting their private tutors [2]. They want someone who can expose their child to a wide range of topics, concepts and ideas from an early age, and use new advancements in technology to their learning advantage. They want someone who can 'move with the times', and this paves the way for some very exciting job opportunities for forward thinking tutors, worldwide.\" \n \nWith a career in education spanning over 25 years, Mr Caller believes that embracing these latest developments and incorporating them into a child's own individual curriculum, while prioritising their creativity and nurturing a natural curiosity, is key in shaping adults that can use their own skills to adapt and succeed in a world that their teachers may never get to experience. \n \nTutors International places exceptional tutors with families based on their individual needs and circumstances. For more information and advice about private tutoring, wherever you are in the world, visit tutors-international.com . In fact, it seems that this formula is working pretty well for the company and that it has enticed a lot of consumers in India. \n  \nOn a similar note, while Xiaomi has achieved a great feat by releasing the successor to the popular Redmi Note 3, the new smartphone could have been a better device. Not that we are being greedy or something but Xiaomi could have gone on to set a big example to show that it is possible to launch a featured-packed smartphone with aggressive pricing. \n \nSEE ALSO:  Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 review: Xiaomi's budget legacy continues \n \nOn the other hand, we cannot expect a phone priced starting at Rs 9,999 to have everything, but if these features were to be included then Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 would have been the total package. \n \nSo, in this post, we'll discuss the missing features in the Redmi Note 4 and what Xiaomi could have done to make it the unbeatable device. \n \nStay tuned to GizBot for more updates! \n       \n 4K Video or OIS  \n \nWell, if you consider some other smartphones in this range many of them now offer 4K video recording options. But unfortunately, the Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 lacks the 4K video recording. In addition, the smartphone does not come with OIS (Optical Image Stabilization). Xiaomi could have worked in this department a bit to make the phone even better. \n \nWell if these features were added then certainly the Redmi Note would be unbeatable. Contradictorily, the absence of such small features could easily be a deal breaker for photography fanatics as other mid-range handsets are offering this feature for quite some time now. \n       \n Fast Charging  \n \nThe Redmi Note 4 comes with a huge 4100mAh battery package and if you need to charge the battery then it could easily take around two and half hours to fully charge the device. Now that is a long time to wait for your device to get fully charged. \n \nHowever, to solve this, Xiaomi could have added the support for fast charging and with this support it would have been much more convenient for the user. \n \nSEE ALSO:  Xiaomi Redmi Note 4: Reasons you should get this smartphone \n       \n USB Type-C  \n \nWhile many smartphone manufacturers are now introducing the more user-friendly USB Type-C standard, Xiaomi with its 2017 product has failed to bring in the feature with the smartphone. Why we are fussing about it is because the regular micro-USB standard is rapidly ageing and in fact needs to go. If we consider the benefits of the new USB Type-C standard, it makes charging smartphone or connecting the data cable a bit easier, faster and more intuitive. \n \nTaking into account that Redmi Note 3 was a successful handset in India, Redmi Note 4 could have been much interesting product with the addition of the Type-C port. And further it could have been a great start for their product specially designed for India. \n \nSEE ALSO:  Xiaomi Redmi Note 4: 10 accessories to make it look and function better \n       \n Screen Protection  \n \nThe 5.5-inch 1080p IPS display on the Redmi Note 4 is not protected by Corning's Gorilla Glass. While it does come with a strengthened 2.5D curved glass that is less prone to scratches, but the addition of the Gorilla Glass would have added better safety feature. \n       \n NFC  \n \nWhile Xiaomi seems to have done the research and considered NFC not necessary, it is really disappointing that the Redmi Note 4 misses out on this feature. NFC is a very basic and essential feature and should be available in all midrange phones. Moreover, at this price tag, there are many smartphones which do offer NFC. Xiaomi should keep all these small things in mind. \n \nHaving said all that, we do think that the latest Redmi Note 4 is a great update over the Redmi Note 3 and Xiaomi has done its part to bring an attractive device to the market. Its vehicle controls and responsiveness are better suited to gamers who like their vehicles to feel more like the real thing. Not to say that the vehicle controls in Saints Row 2 don't work, but they do feel more arcade-like. \n \nBy comparison, Saints Row 2 is more a shooter fan's game. The supply of guns and ammo is greater and, if you run out, you have the option to buy more (in the original, though, you can run-out of ammo completely). The accuracy of the weapons in Saints Row 2 also are much better for more bullets hitting their targets. \n \nSaints Row 2 looks better, but as an driving adventure game, Saints Row feels better. The story for Saints Row is a little more solid, but the shooting controls in Saints Row 2 are much better. Choose the game that best fits your play-style and you won't go wrong. \n \nThanks for reading; game on! \n  Submit Blog  Love this blog? {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:17Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396121520","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HOTELS & MOTELS","domains":["IND"],"score":"67"},{"name":"ELECTRIC VEHICLES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"79"},{"name":"TIRES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"GASOLINE","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"OIL & GAS PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; RHODE ISLAND, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NORTHEAST USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; MAINE, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; MASSACHUSETTS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; VERMONT, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"651","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396121520&p=2kx&v=1&x=vCJ8XRIHg9rSkNJkZNATQA","id":"29396121520","content":"Buying an EV should mean a lower cost of maintenance. True or false? \n \n\n \n\n  \nLuxury EVs \n \nLuxury EVs like the Tesla Model S and Model X are perhaps the most expensive modern vehicles one can maintain. Don\u2019t take our word for it. Here is the Tesla maintenance program offerings directly from its website: \n \n\n \n\n  \nFurther, \u201cTesla recommends an Annual Service Inspection every year or 12,500 miles to maintain your vehicle to top performance standards.\u201d The company also says this is the most economical way to maintain your vehicle and it includes such things as tire service, software updates, windshield wipers, keyfob batteries and the like. In the northern area of New England, Tesla presently has two service centers to cover the states of Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Vermont, Maine, and New Hampshire. So budget your time and maybe factor in a hotel room. \n \n \u2013 EV Buyer\u2019s Guide \u2013 Gas Savings vs. Other Green Car Options \n \nContrast Tesla\u2019s service fees with those from Jaguar and BMW.  Jaguar includes service on its (gasoline) vehicles for the first five years of ownership. BMW does for four years. Had you heard that Tesla offered a flat $100 service fee  for home visits? It did, but that went out the window. Along with free unlimited Supercharger use and Tesla\u2019s resale value guarantee . \n \n\n \n\n  \nWhich leads us to the least expensive luxury EV to maintain, the BMW i3 . By including all required maintenance (except tire replacement) for four years, BMW pretty much blows the rest of the EV field out of the water in terms of cost management. Trade, or return a leased BMW at year four and you have a fixed cost of ownership. The same is true of any BMW gasoline or diesel-powered car. After the four years is up, which will be less expensive to maintain? Presumably, the i3 would be. One difficulty is that there aren\u2019t many four-year old BMW i3s yet. Time will tell. \n \n[embedded content] \n \n[embedded content] \n  \nAffordable EVs \n \nThe spoiler for affordable EVs like the Leaf has been the Toyota Prius . Offering similar performance, and in many markets, a lower cost per mile for energy , the Prius drives EV fans nuts. The Prius eliminated three of the main maintenance items older gasoline-powered cars required. It has no power steering fluid to change, there is no timing belt to service, and there is no \u201ctune up\u201d required. \n \nMaking the cost comparison more difficult is that Toyota includes maintenance for two years. That puts the Prius ahead of the affordable EVs in general, particularly for those that lease or plan to trade after four or five years. Oil changes are once per year (10K miles) for the Prius too, so the owner\u2019s four-year cost of oil is about $160, rounding up. Early in the Nissan Leaf\u2019s run, Consumer Reports asked the local Nissan dealer they visited to perform the 1-year/15K service required in the Leaf\u2019s Service and Maintenance Guide . The $291.91 fee caused quite a stir. To its credit, Nissan includes the inspections required (not the brake fluid and cabin air filter changes) for the first two years. These include gear oil, steering linkages, ball joints, and similar. \n \nThe very high costs Tesla charges for maintenance and the surprisingly high costs of the Leaf Consumer Reports discovered offer a lesson for EV shoppers: Don\u2019t assume automakers will actually charge you less to maintain an EV, regardless of what the theoretical cost should be. Ask the dealer you buy your EV from what they charge to maintain the vehicle before you commit. If they offer you the line that \u201cSkipping the maintenance will not void your warranty\u201d that may sound attractive. Setting aside why it is necessary if that is the case, remember that when you go to trade your EV at some future point yours will be the one for sale with \u201cNo maintenance records available.\u201d \n \nShopping for a new or used EV? {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:17Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396121469","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPACECRAFT","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"VEHICLE TRAFFIC","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AUTONOMOUS MOTOR VEHICLES","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FAMILY TRAVEL","domains":["IND"],"score":"65"},{"name":"AUTONOMOUS VEHICLES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ELON MUSK","domains":["PEO"],"score":"74"}],"wordCount":"444","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396121469&p=2kx&v=1&x=UjwZIJcIhpSyBDiWGWljKw","id":"29396121469","content":"There are futuristic pieces of tech that we all think science needs to figure out right now. We want transporters that can zip us from place to place in an instant, spaceships that can take us to the stars, and the ever elusive flying car. Hyperloop is taking on the car challenge, not by making them fly in the sky, but by setting them in the hyperloop and zipping them across the planet at outrageous speeds. \n \nThe concept of a hyperloop is the brainchild of Elon Musk, but he was very busy with other things like SpaceX and Tesla. So, he put his idea out there for the public to give it a go and Hyperloop One , based out of Los Angeles, is working on a functional prototype. \n \nLooking for a new or used car? Check out BestRide\u2019s listings search here. \n \nThe idea would be to have tubes that could transport people at the same speeds as a plane, but for far less and without ever leaving the ground. Try to imagine monorail-style structures, but instead of a monorail car gliding along the top of the rail, there would be a tube with shuttles to whisk you to your destination. \n \nNow imagine your personal car pulling up to a hyperloop station, driving into the tube, and zipping you to wherever you want to go without the bother of that whole road trip thing. Hyperloop One senior vice president, global field operations, Nick Earle told The Verge , \u201cThe idea is you have a transmitter in your car. As you approach the hyperloop, it would be like a fast pass on the freeway. So you actually get the ability to open the air lock and drive into the tube.\u201d \n \nIt hinges on the availability of autonomous cars. An autonomous vehicle isn\u2019t solely about driving without human intervention. The autonomy extends to communication so cars can talk to each other and to the infrastructure. If traffic gets congested on your usual route, an autonomous car will have this information ahead of time and be able to reroute you around the trouble. This is how they plan to communicate with your car and get it to a hyperloop station so you don\u2019t have to endure the traffic jams of the annual family road trip. \n \nLooking for a new or used car? Check out BestRide\u2019s listings search here. \n \nThe problem is making the tech work and then finding the cash to build it all. Hyperloop One figures it will cost about $11.5 million per mile of tube, which is outrageous. Still, they have funding to get it started and plan to test it some time early this year. \n  Related Posts","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Nicole Wakelin"},"topics":[{"name":"Tech latest","group":"Technology"}],"title":"Hyperloop One Wants to Put Cars in Super-Fast Tubes","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Polk","zipCode":"33880","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Winter Haven","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Winter Haven News Chief","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169681948","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4"},"name":"Winter Haven News Chief","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["InformationTechnology","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.newschief.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://hyperloop-one.com/","http://bestride.com/","http://www.theverge.com/2017/1/23/14314986/hyperloop-one-self-driving-car-global-challenge-nevada-test"],"sequenceId":"695202750859","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:17Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

While his dad, Doc Rivers , says he\u2019s open to trading his son, I still find it hard to believe that he would actually do it. But if it happens, his value would most likely take a hit, depending on where he lands. But as long as he\u2019s with the Clippers, he should continue to rack up points and 3-pointers. He was quiet in Saturday\u2019s ugly blowout loss to the Clippers with 10 points and six assists on 3-of-11 shooting, but played 38 minutes and was averaging 19.8 points, 4.4 assists and 3.0 3-pointers over his previous five games. \n \nT.J. McConnell Sixers 41% - McConnell\u2019s not a big scorer, but has been racking up assists at an alarming rate lately. He hit double digits in assists in three straight games before scoring 13 points with eight dimes on Friday. He\u2019s starting for the Sixers and averaging 9.0 points, 2.8 rebounds, 9.4 assists and 1.6 steals on 53 percent shooting over his last five games. I wish he was a 3-point shooter, but he\u2019s not. \n \nMatthew Dellavedova Bucks 30% - Delly took over the starting job from Malcolm Brogdon five games ago and is averaging 13.0 points, 5.4 assists, 0.8 steals and 1.8 3-pointers in 29 minutes a game over that stretch. Brogdon has more upside and talent, but Delly\u2019s putting up better numbers right now. He\u2019s also had at least 14 points and six dimes in three of his last five games. \n \nRaymond Felton Clippers 24% - Felton has bounced in and out of the starting lineup since Chris Paul went down and played just 17 minutes for two points and three assists on 1-of-3 shooting in Tuesday\u2019s loss to the Sixers. He bounced back on Saturday with 10 points, seven rebounds, five assists, a block and two 3-pointers on Saturday, and even played garbage time in a blowout loss because the Clippers simply don\u2019t have healthy points guards right now. Over his last five he\u2019s averaging 10 points, 4.0 rebounds, 4.4 assists, 0.6 steals and 1.2 3-pointers on 38 percent shooting. His shooting took a hit on Saturday when he hit just 3-of-12 shots, but he\u2019s getting enough minutes (27.8 in his last five) to make a fantasy dent, and his shooting should be better than this going forward.  \n \nMalcolm Brogdon Bucks 55% - Brogdon lost his job to Dellavedova and had scored six or fewer points in three of his last four games before bouncing back with 11 points and five assists on Saturday, although he hit just 4-of-12 shots. He\u2019s averaging just 7.0 points, 2.0 rebounds, 5.2 assists, 1.4 steals and just 0.2 3-pointers in his five games since being moved to the bench. Brogdon has plenty of time to reclaim the job or make a comeback, but as long as Delly\u2019s starting, things aren\u2019t looking great for Brogdon. \n \nEditor\u2019s Note : Golf is coming soon to FanDuel! And they\u2019ve created the Tee Off Classic to celebrate, offering you an opportunity to win a VIP trip for 3 to play a round of golf with Jerome Bettis! Play now . \n \nShooting Guards \n \nDion Waiters Heat 58% - Waiters was at it again on Saturday with 17 points and seven assists, but hit just 1-of-9 3-pointers, or his line would have been a lot bigger. Waiters is averaging 25.2 points, 4.2 rebounds, 4.6 assists and 3.4 3-pointers over his last five games, knocking down 52 percent of his shots. He\u2019ll take a bit of a hit once Tyler Johnson is back from his shoulder injury, which should happen any day. He\u2019ll also get stung again by the return of Josh Richardson , but even with those guys lurking, Waiters is hot enough right now to be owned in all leagues. Just know that if you pick him up for the upcoming week, you probably missed the best five-game streak of his season. \n \nSeth Curry Mavericks 49% - Curry looks like a full-time starter the rest of the way for the struggling Mavericks, has scored in double figures in six straight games, and is averaging 15 points, three rebounds, 1.4 assists, 1.2 steals and 2.4 3-pointers in 31.4 minutes per game over his last five. If he continues to start the rest of the season, Curry should be owned in a lot more leagues. \n \nIman Shumpert Cavaliers 28% - Shumpert had scored in double figures in six straight games before hitting just 2-of-8 shots for six points and three steals in Friday\u2019s win over the Nets. He was 0-for-5 from downtown in that one, but had hit at least two 3-pointers in each of his previous six games. Forget about Friday\u2019s dud and consider Shumpert a favorite to average around 15 points, 2.0 steals and close to 3.0 3-pointers going forward. \n \nGary Harris Nuggets 63% - Harris came through on Saturday with 15 points, eight rebounds, four assists, two steals and a 3-pointers, but the Suns typically give it up to opposing guards. He\u2019s averaging 11 points, 3.2 rebounds, 2.0 assists, 0.8 steals and 1.2 3-pointers on 45 percent shooting over his last five games, but he\u2019d have a lot more fantasy appeal if Will Barton wasn\u2019t getting at least 20 minutes night. \n \nGarrett Temple Kings 25% (and Arron Afflalo ) - I\u2019m not a big Temple guy and there\u2019s really no one from the Kings that I love filling in for Rudy Gay , who\u2019s out for the season with a blown Achilles. But Temple appears to be the best of the bunch, getting 32 minutes with 8.0 points, 2.2 rebounds, 2.6 assists, 2.0 steals and 0.8 3-points on 34 percent shooting over his last five games. Teammate Arron Afflalo might be a better flier, as he\u2019s coming on and averaging 14 points, 1.3 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 3.0 3-pointers over his last three games, knocking down 9-of-15 shots in 34 minutes a night in the process. \n  \nWeek 15 Games Played \n \n  \n \n4 Games: BOS, BRK, DEN, DET, MEM, MIN, OKC, ORL, PHI, PHX, SAC, TOR \n \n3 Games: ATL, CHA, CLE, DAL, GSW, HOU, IND, LAC, LAL, MIA, MIL, NOP, NYK, POR, SAN, WAS \n \n2 Games: CHI, UTA \n \nFollow me on Twitter by clicking here! \n \n  \n \nPoint Guards \n \nAustin Rivers Clippers 57 percent owned in Yahoo! leagues \u2013 Rivers has been much better than Raymond Felton since Chris Paul went down and should keep rolling for about another month. While his dad, Doc Rivers , says he\u2019s open to trading his son, I still find it hard to believe that he would actually do it. But if it happens, his value would most likely take a hit, depending on where he lands. But as long as he\u2019s with the Clippers, he should continue to rack up points and 3-pointers. He was quiet in Saturday\u2019s ugly blowout loss to the Clippers with 10 points and six assists on 3-of-11 shooting, but played 38 minutes and was averaging 19.8 points, 4.4 assists and 3.0 3-pointers over his previous five games. \n \nT.J. McConnell Sixers 41% - McConnell\u2019s not a big scorer, but has been racking up assists at an alarming rate lately. He hit double digits in assists in three straight games before scoring 13 points with eight dimes on Friday. He\u2019s starting for the Sixers and averaging 9.0 points, 2.8 rebounds, 9.4 assists and 1.6 steals on 53 percent shooting over his last five games. I wish he was a 3-point shooter, but he\u2019s not. \n \nMatthew Dellavedova Bucks 30% - Delly took over the starting job from Malcolm Brogdon five games ago and is averaging 13.0 points, 5.4 assists, 0.8 steals and 1.8 3-pointers in 29 minutes a game over that stretch. Brogdon has more upside and talent, but Delly\u2019s putting up better numbers right now. He\u2019s also had at least 14 points and six dimes in three of his last five games. \n \nRaymond Felton Clippers 24% - Felton has bounced in and out of the starting lineup since Chris Paul went down and played just 17 minutes for two points and three assists on 1-of-3 shooting in Tuesday\u2019s loss to the Sixers. He bounced back on Saturday with 10 points, seven rebounds, five assists, a block and two 3-pointers on Saturday, and even played garbage time in a blowout loss because the Clippers simply don\u2019t have healthy points guards right now. Over his last five he\u2019s averaging 10 points, 4.0 rebounds, 4.4 assists, 0.6 steals and 1.2 3-pointers on 38 percent shooting. His shooting took a hit on Saturday when he hit just 3-of-12 shots, but he\u2019s getting enough minutes (27.8 in his last five) to make a fantasy dent, and his shooting should be better than this going forward.  \n \nMalcolm Brogdon Bucks 55% - Brogdon lost his job to Dellavedova and had scored six or fewer points in three of his last four games before bouncing back with 11 points and five assists on Saturday, although he hit just 4-of-12 shots. He\u2019s averaging just 7.0 points, 2.0 rebounds, 5.2 assists, 1.4 steals and just 0.2 3-pointers in his five games since being moved to the bench. Brogdon has plenty of time to reclaim the job or make a comeback, but as long as Delly\u2019s starting, things aren\u2019t looking great for Brogdon. \n \nEditor\u2019s Note : Golf is coming soon to FanDuel! And they\u2019ve created the Tee Off Classic to celebrate, offering you an opportunity to win a VIP trip for 3 to play a round of golf with Jerome Bettis! Play now . \n \nShooting Guards \n \nDion Waiters Heat 58% - Waiters was at it again on Saturday with 17 points and seven assists, but hit just 1-of-9 3-pointers, or his line would have been a lot bigger. Waiters is averaging 25.2 points, 4.2 rebounds, 4.6 assists and 3.4 3-pointers over his last five games, knocking down 52 percent of his shots. He\u2019ll take a bit of a hit once Tyler Johnson is back from his shoulder injury, which should happen any day. He\u2019ll also get stung again by the return of Josh Richardson , but even with those guys lurking, Waiters is hot enough right now to be owned in all leagues. Just know that if you pick him up for the upcoming week, you probably missed the best five-game streak of his season. \n \nSeth Curry Mavericks 49% - Curry looks like a full-time starter the rest of the way for the struggling Mavericks, has scored in double figures in six straight games, and is averaging 15 points, three rebounds, 1.4 assists, 1.2 steals and 2.4 3-pointers in 31.4 minutes per game over his last five. If he continues to start the rest of the season, Curry should be owned in a lot more leagues. \n \nIman Shumpert Cavaliers 28% - Shumpert had scored in double figures in six straight games before hitting just 2-of-8 shots for six points and three steals in Friday\u2019s win over the Nets. He was 0-for-5 from downtown in that one, but had hit at least two 3-pointers in each of his previous six games. Forget about Friday\u2019s dud and consider Shumpert a favorite to average around 15 points, 2.0 steals and close to 3.0 3-pointers going forward. \n \nGary Harris Nuggets 63% - Harris came through on Saturday with 15 points, eight rebounds, four assists, two steals and a 3-pointers, but the Suns typically give it up to opposing guards. He\u2019s averaging 11 points, 3.2 rebounds, 2.0 assists, 0.8 steals and 1.2 3-pointers on 45 percent shooting over his last five games, but he\u2019d have a lot more fantasy appeal if Will Barton wasn\u2019t getting at least 20 minutes night. \n \nGarrett Temple Kings 25% (and Arron Afflalo ) - I\u2019m not a big Temple guy and there\u2019s really no one from the Kings that I love filling in for Rudy Gay , who\u2019s out for the season with a blown Achilles. But Temple appears to be the best of the bunch, getting 32 minutes with 8.0 points, 2.2 rebounds, 2.6 assists, 2.0 steals and 0.8 3-points on 34 percent shooting over his last five games. Teammate Arron Afflalo might be a better flier, as he\u2019s coming on and averaging 14 points, 1.3 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 3.0 3-pointers over his last three games, knocking down 9-of-15 shots in 34 minutes a night in the process. \n \nSmall Forwards \n \nCaris LeVert Nets 18% - LeVert has sat out two of his last four games for \u201crest,\u201d but still has a ton of upside and could play heavy minutes the rest of the way for the dead-end Nets. He played 27 minutes on Saturday and hit 4-of-8 shots for 11 points, four rebounds, two steals, a block and a 3-pointer. He played 26 minutes on Wednesday and had 12 points, four assists and a 3-pointer, and while he\u2019s not yet a must-own player, he\u2019s getting pretty close. Hopefully his days of getting random nights off are over. \n \nMarvin Williams Hornets 67% - Williams has quietly scored in double figures in four straight games and is averaging 13.2 points, 4.8 rebounds, 1.6 assists, 1.0 steals, 0.6 blocks and 2.2 3-pointers on 43 percent shooting in 29 minutes over his last five games. He\u2019s not nearly as fun to own as he was last season, but is coming on a bit for the Hornets. \n \nMichael Kidd-Gilchrist Hornets 57% - MKG only played 19 minutes on Saturday but there are no reports of an injury. He had four fouls, so I\u2019m going to say that\u2019s the reason for his low minutes in a tough loss to the Kings. Despite the bench time, he had nine points, six rebounds and tied his season high with four blocks in that one. He\u2019s averaging 12.2 points, 8.4 rebounds, 1.8 blocks and is shooting 58 percent over his last five games. He doesn\u2019t hit 3-pointers and won\u2019t get a ton of steals, but is still worth a look in all leagues right now. \n \nKhris Middleton Bucks 39% - Middleton is nearing a return and while we don\u2019t know how long it will take him to get into basketball shape, he\u2019s hard to ignore after averaging 18.2 points, 3.8 rebounds, 4.2 assists, 1.7 steals and 1.8 3-pointers last season. He\u2019s targeting a return near the All-Star break and I like him better as a stash than Ben Simmons , simply because we still don\u2019t have any idea when Simmons will make his debut with the Sixers. \n \nJaylen Brown Celtics 4% - Brown has started in two straight games as Al Horford sits with a groin injury. Brown blew up for a career-high 20 points, eight rebounds and two 3-pointers in 30 minutes on Friday. He then started again on Saturday and had nine points, eight rebounds, two steals, a block and a 3-pointer in 28 minutes, hitting 3-of-9 shots. He\u2019s far from a must-own player, but if Horford\u2019s injury lingers, or if Brad Stevens decides he\u2019s ready to roll with Brown, he\u2019s at least worth a spot on your watch list. \n \nPower Forwards \n \n  \n \nTerrence Jones Pelicans 59% - Jones bounces in and out of the starting lineup like nobody\u2019s business, but is getting solid minutes, regardless. And with Anthony Davis constantly getting banged up and visiting the locker room during games, TJ is the ultimate handcuff for the Brow. And even with Brown playing on most nights, Jones is averaging 17.8 points, 7.0 rebounds, 1.0 steals, 1.4 blocks and 1.0 3-pointers on 51 percent shooting in 25 minutes per game over his last five. He should be owned across the board. \n \nDavid Lee Spurs 43% - Lee has played in nine straight games, so he\u2019s due to get Popped any day now with a DNP. But with Pau Gasol out indefinitely, Lee is suddenly very relevant, scoring in double figures in five straight games with double-doubles in three of those. He\u2019s averaging 12.6 points and 9.8 rebounds on 62 percent shooting in 29 minutes over his last five games, but he doesn\u2019t do much besides make shots and crash the boards. \n \nP.J. Tucker Suns 20% - Tucker had another nice line on Saturday with 12 points, six boards, five assists, a steal and two 3-pointers in 36 minutes. He\u2019s averaging 11.4 points, 5.8 rebounds, 2.6 assists, 2.0 steals and 1.4 3-pointers on 49 percent shooting in a whopping 35 minutes per game off the bench over his last five. \n \nJon Leuer Pistons 43% - Leuer was a dud with just eight points and one rebound in 24 minutes on Saturday, but hit 4-of-5 shots. He scored 15 and 10 points in each of his previous two games and has hit 14-of-22 shots in his three games since returning from a knee injury. He should be a decent source of points, rebounds and 3-pointers while shooting it well and getting the occasional steals and blocks. He\u2019s not a must-own player, but that could change as he rounds back into form. \n \nSpencer Hawes Hornets 1% - Hawes came off the bench for 12 points, seven rebounds and a block in 28 minutes on Saturday and is averaging 9.3 points, 8.3 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 1.3 blocks on 39 percent shooting over his last three games. Cody Zeller is out with a quad injury right now and Hawes will certainly take a hit when he\u2019s back, but as of this second, he\u2019s at least worth a look in some leagues. And if Zeller continues to miss time, Hawes is a decent flier, especially as a cheap, DFS center. \n \nBonus:  Anthony Tolliver and Willie Cauley-Stein both played well for the Kings on Saturday, and while they didn\u2019t officially make this list, they\u2019re worth keeping an eye on right now and should be available in most leagues. Tolliver finally had a good game with 14 points, seven boards, three assists, two steals, a block and four 3-pointers in 30 minutes. He had scored six or fewer points in three of his previous four games, but Saturday\u2019s line was more in line with what most of us were expecting when Gay went down. \n \nWCS played just 14 minutes but hit 6-of-7 shots for 13 points and three rebounds, but if you\u2019re going to take a flier on a big King, Tolliver\u2019s the guy I\u2019d aim for right now, but the bottom line is that I don\u2019t trust him. \n \nCenters \n \nIvica Zubac Lakers 19% - The 19-year-old phenom has double-doubled in two straight games and three of his last five, and the Lakers want to keep giving him minutes. The fact that Zubac is on the Lakers\u2019 roster and so talented makes the summer signing of Timofey Mozgov that much more perplexing. The Zupacalypse is averaging 9.0 points, 7.6 rebounds and 1.4 blocks on 46 percent shooting over his last five games, but the poor shooting is a result of a 5-of-15 night against the Blazers last Wednesday. He\u2019s my favorite center to pick up right now. \n \nWilly Hernangomez Knicks 21% - Willy H has played well in three straight games and might be getting ready to be turned loose by the Knicks. He\u2019s averaging 8.0 points, 10.3 rebounds, 1.0 steals and 0.5 blocks on 50 percent shooting over his last four. He\u2019s likely to be a bit hit-or-miss going forward, but his arrow is pointing up. \n \nJusuf Nurkic Nuggets 41% - I thought we might have a Nurk Alert, as Nikola Jokic was out on Saturday and will miss at least one more game with his weird hip injury, but Nurkic didn\u2019t come through. He started, but played just 15 minutes and finished with five points, four rebounds and nothing else. While that\u2019s a lot better than the DNP he had on Thursday, Nurkic continues to sit in the shadows in Denver. I would not be at all surprised to see him start again on Tuesday against the Lakers, and have a big game against them, but using him in that one is a complete roll of the dice. The Nuggets basically rolled without a center for most of the night on Saturday and Tyson Chandler had a big night because of it. But if Jokic is going to miss more than just one more game, Nurkic should at least still be on watch lists until we see how this plays out. \n \nWillie Reed Heat 7% - Hassan Whiteside played through his sprained ankle on Saturday, but wasn\u2019t great against a tough Pistons\u2019 defense. Reed, who started for an injured Whiteside on Friday, played 19 minutes and had just two points, five rebounds and three blocks in that one. In Saturday\u2019s start, he went off for 20 points and five rebounds on 9-of-11 shooting. Reed is not a must-own player, by any stretch, but with constant chatter about Whiteside being a shutdown candidate, Reed does have some fantasy appeal right now. Any time Whiteside is out Reed looks like a must-start player, and if Whitey ever goes down for an extended period of time, Reed would quickly become one of the hotter pickups in the league. But for now you can probably leave him on the waiver wire, unless you have a deep bench and want Whiteside insurance. \n \nDewayne Dedmon Spurs 4% - Dedmon\u2019s minutes have been all over the place since Pau Gasol went down. He\u2019s played 19, 10, 29, 19 and 8 minutes in each of his last five games, so it\u2019s tough to rely on him, obviously. He\u2019s averaging just 5.2 points, 5.0 rebounds, 0.6 steals and 0.2 blocks on 63 percent shooting over his last five games. He could turn it on at any time if Gregg Popovich commits to him for at least 20 minutes per night, but for now, he\u2019s probably more deserving of a spot on your watch list than he is a spot in your lineup.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: NBA - Los Angeles Lakers news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: NBA - Philadelphia 76ers news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: NBA news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: basketball news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Waiver Wired - Wired: Top NBA Pickups Week 15","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Fairfield","zipCode":"06901","state":"Connecticut","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Stamford","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Roto World","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169665003","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"95"},"name":"Roto World","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Basketball","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.rotoworld.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://twitter.com/docktora","http://wlfanduel.adsrv.eacdn.com/C.ashx?btag=a_6856b_1580c_&affid=4892&siteid=6856&adid=1580&c="],"sequenceId":"695202759043","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:21Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
