{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29382905330","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SEX OFFENSES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"TEEN SUICIDE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"FOSTER CARE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"SUICIDE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PSYCHOLOGY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"ADOLESCENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MIAMI, FL, USA; UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"608","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396123281&p=2kx&v=1&x=ySwFGezBQoJlBgPkChlj-A","id":"29396123281","content":"(1 of ) Leonard Pitts | A few thoughts on the lonely death of Naika Venant.\n\nAs you may have heard, Naika, a Miami teenager, hanged herself in the dark hours of a Sunday morning. She did this live on Facebook. We\u2019ll likely never know why she chose to do it that way. Perhaps she felt invisible. Perhaps she wanted to be seen.\n\nHer self-destruction drew attention, all right, but surely not the kind she wanted. To read the report by the Miami Herald\u2019s Carol Marbin Miller and Alex Harris is to cringe with disgust:\n\n\"A thousand people watched for nearly an hour as Naika Venant prepared to kill herself. They kept watching for another hour as the 14-year-old dangled on her scarf from the shower door in the bathroom of her Miami Gardens foster home.\n\n\"People mocked the young girl, called her names and reacted to the video with Facebook\u2019s laughing emoji, said Antonio Gethers, one of her 4,500 Facebook friends. Others posted cruel parody videos pretending to hang themselves, too.\"\n\nThe bleak despair and dead-end hope that cause people to take their lives is, unfortunately, all too familiar. And those feelings can be magnified dangerously in adolescence, an age where all emotions are outsized, all passions urgent and raw. Factor in that she was a survivor of physical abuse and sexual assault, and it becomes depressingly easy to imagine the forces that drove Naika to destroy herself.\n\nIt is less easy to understand why that act was received the way it was.\n\nThe harsh laughter and cold ridicule of \"people\" \u2014 the word is used advisedly \u2014 who watched Naika\u2019s suicide suggest that we flatter ourselves when we call ourselves a higher species. Apparently, only one individual tried to help; a friend saw the live feed and called police, but inadvertently sent them to the wrong address. By the time it got sorted out, Naika was beyond saving.\n\nMiami-Dade schools chief Alberto Carvalho blames Facebook for what happened, which is as understandable as it is misguided. Might as well blame the sidewalk where Kitty Genovese was killed in 1964 as she screamed for help that didn\u2019t come. Or the Golden Gate Bridge, where a 2006 documentary, \"The Bridge,\" shows passersby passing by without intervening as people climb up on the ledge, preparing to jump. Or the walkway behind a Salem, New Jersey, McDonald\u2019s where a young mother was brutally beaten in 2014 while observers laughed and recorded it on their cellphones.\n\nFacebook is an easy target, but it is not the web service whose behavior is appalling here. It is, rather, the ordinary people, the everyday Janes and Joes who could have acted to save this child, but did not. One is mindful of what\u2019s called \"the bystander effect,\" which, according to Psychology Today, \"occurs when the presence of others hinders an individual from intervening in an emergency situation.\"\n\nBut that doesn\u2019t explain the laughter. It does not make sense of the mocking derision of a troubled child.\n\nNo, that behavior speaks to moral stupidity, to the objectification of other people and their pain, to a selfish inability to extend compassion beyond the barricades of one\u2019s own life. All of which have come to feel far too commonplace. It cries out for families, worship houses and schools to rededicate themselves to teaching what it means to be a truly human being. That would be a good way to give meaning to this tragedy. It\u2019s haunting to think Naika might have killed herself on Facebook hoping to be seen.\n\nYes, a thousand people watched her die. Then they clicked their browsers to see what else was on.\n\nLeonard Pitts is a columnist for the Miami Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"LEONARD PITTS"},"topics":[{"name":"South Florida news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"The lonely death of Naika Venant","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Sonoma","zipCode":"95401","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Santa Rosa","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Press Democrat","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169660830","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Press Democrat","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.pdpreps.com/","http://www.northbaybusinessjournal.com/","http://lists.northbaybusinessjournal.com/index.htm","http://www.biteclubeats.com/","http://www.celebratecommunity.org/","http://www.northbaycarsearch.com/","http://www.capublicnotice.com/","http://www.pdmediasource.com/","http://santarosapressdemocrat.ca.newsmemory.com/ssindex.php"],"sequenceId":"695202784869","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:32Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com/csp/mediapool/sites/dt.common.streams.StreamServer.cls?STREAMOID=nxDiG7lXtv6hpII8rBXbsM$daE2N3K4ZzOUsqbU5sYtMC8V6mIziZeBY06JEgIT$WCsjLu883Ygn4B49Lvm9bPe2QeMKQdVeZmXF$9l$4uCZ8QDXhaHEp3rvzXRJFdy0KqPHLoMevcTLo3h8xh70Y6N_U_CryOsw6FTOdKL_jpQ-&CONTENTTYPE=image/jpeg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396123282","companies":[{"symbol":"CZH","primary":true,"name":"Choice Hotels International Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US1699051066"},{"symbol":"CHH","primary":true,"name":"Choice Hotels International Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US1699051066"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HOTEL OCCUPANCY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"HOSPITALITY SECTOR PERFORMANCE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"OUTPUT & DEMAND","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"LODGING INDUSTRY SECTOR PERFORMANCE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LODGING","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS; RECESSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"HOTELS & MOTELS","domains":["IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"AIRPORTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"94"},{"name":"CASINOS","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BAGGAGE HANDLING","domains":["IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"GOVERNMENT TOURIST OFFICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TRAVEL, HOSPITALITY & TOURISM","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AIRPORT OPERATION","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"NEW CONSTRUCTION","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AIRLINES","domains":["IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"TRAVEL & HOSPITALITY SECTOR PERFORMANCE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CONVENTION & VISITORS BUREAUS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"LOBBYING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"TOURISM DEVELOPMENT","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"TOURISM","domains":["IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"ANNIVERSARIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"ANNUAL FINANCIAL RESULTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; PENNSYLVANIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"1796","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396123282&p=2kx&v=1&x=uK_JE7tZYNGVWUBzfW84fA","id":"29396123282","content":"(1 of ) Graton Resort and Casino front desk ambassador Andrew Kleist, right, holds the casino door open for Judy and John Stepek of Las Vegas after they checked into the hotel to celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary, in Rohnert Park, California on Thursday, January 26, 2017. (Alvin Jornada / The Press Democrat) (2 of ) Guests check in and mill around the hotel lobby at Graton Resort and Casino in Rohnert Park, California on Thursday, January 26, 2017. (Alvin Jornada / The Press Democrat) (3 of ) John and Judy Stepek of Las Vegas check in to the Graton Resort and Casino hotel to celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary, in Rohnert Park, California on Thursday, January 26, 2017. (Alvin Jornada / The Press Democrat) (4 of ) Tom Gunderson of Tim Gunderson Electric, works on a new portable building (located in the Enterprise Rental Car lot), Thursday Jan. 26, 2017 at the Charles M. Schulz Sonoma County Airport. The building will be used for ticketing and baggage counter for the incoming of American Airlines. (Kent Porter / Press Democrat) 2017 | A year ago, only one commercial airline company flew routes into the Charles M. Schulz-Sonoma County Airport. Next month, there will be three. The pending arrival of American Airlines prompted the airport last week to move in temporary quarters for additional check-in and baggage handling, even as it gears up for a $20 million expansion of its terminal and parking.\n\n\"2016 was another record year for us,\" said airport manager Jon Stout, noting that passenger counts rose almost 30 percent to 339,000. He expects another increase this year of about 10 percent.\n\nThe nation\u2019s hospitality and travel sector continues to enjoy good times. And 2017 should be another growth year, with stronger household balance sheets and pent-up consumer demand for vacations, said Jesse Rogers, an associate economist for Moody\u2019s Analytics based in West Chester, Pennsylvania.\n\nFor Sonoma County, Rogers said, \"the outlook is even better.\"\n\nThe hospitality industry here has enjoyed eight years of steady growth. It ranks as the county\u2019s second-largest business sector, with $1.82 billion in spending in 2015, according to Visit California, the state\u2019s chief tourism organization.\n\nCounty hotel revenues have doubled since 2009, which was the hospitality sector\u2019s low point in the last recession. Hotel revenues last year rose 9.5 percent to $282.7 million, according to travel research firm STR, which surveys nearly 6,400 county hotel rooms, or roughly half the various types of lodging units here.\n\nThe county\u2019s average room rate rose 7 percent last year to $161.33, STR reported. Average occupancy increased to 77.6 percent from 75.9 percent in 2015. Both numbers were the highest in at least a decade.\n\nTravelers come here because they want to experience Wine Country. That includes visiting not only wineries but also restaurants and makers of craft beer, cheeses and other artisanal foods. And tourists want to get outdoors to cycle county back roads, swim in the Russian River, hike the wooded hills of state and regional parks and walk along coastal bluffs and beaches.\n\nEven last year\u2019s voter approval of an ordinance banning GMO crops is a draw for many travelers, Rogers said.\n\n\"I think it just points to the growing appeal of Sonoma as a bastion for organic\" and artisanal products, he said.\n\nAlong with drawing in visitors, the county in recent years has attracted airlines to fly new routes to and from the airport north of Santa Rosa.\n\nCommercial airline service resumed here in March 2007 with the arrival of Alaska Airlines subsidiary Horizon Air. Alaska now offers daily service from Santa Rosa to San Diego, Orange County, Los Angeles, Portland and Seattle.\n\nLast year, Alaska increased its number of total flights nearly 17 percent from a year earlier. In now offers seven flights a day, Stout said, and the airline this summer may add an extra daily flight to Portland and Seattle.\n\nLast spring, a second carrier, Allegiant, began flights to Las Vegas, plus a short-lived route to the Phoenix area, which ended earlier this month. The airline continues its twice-weekly service to Las Vegas.\n\nAnd on Feb. 16 American, the world\u2019s largest airline, will become the airport\u2019s third carrier when it begins daily service from here to Phoenix-Sky Harbor International Airport. Service will be aboard a Bombardier CRJ700, a regional aircraft that holds 70 passengers, including six in business class. The new route fits with American\u2019s strategy of linking regional airports to one of its nine hubs around the country, said spokeswoman Polly Tracey. In Phoenix, American employs 10,000 workers and carries about 20 million passengers a year through the airport. From there, travelers can take direct flights to Mexico, Costa Rica, Canada and cities around the U.S.\n\n\"You\u2019re not just starting a flight to Phoenix,\" Tracey said. \"You then have connections to places all around the world.\"\n\nPhoenix residents, meanwhile, will be attracted to the county \"because it\u2019s such a lovely leisure destination,\" she said.\n\nTo accommodate the new activity, the airport this week brought in a modular building that will serve as American\u2019s temporary check-in and baggage facility.\n\nA next step will occur this spring when a \"rigid-sided tent\" rises on the apron near the parked aircraft area, Stout said. The structure will have heating and air conditioning and initially will serve as a passenger waiting area, with gates leading to the aircraft.\n\nIn time, that tent structure will be expanded to accommodate check-in and baggage areas for some airlines, as well as the security screening area, Stout said. That will happen as the airport undertakes its $20 million terminal and parking expansion project.\n\nThe phased project could triple the terminal building to 45,000 square feet and add over 450 spaces in a second long-term parking area. The terminal design is expected to be completed and presented to the county Board of Supervisors around September, Stout said, with the project\u2019s completion slated for mid-2019.\n\nThe good times in hospitality also have prompted a surge in ne hotel projects. One of the biggest is the 200-room, $175 million hotel that opened last fall at the Graton Resort & Casino on the northwest edge of Rohnert Park.\n\n\"We expect to see continued robust hotel occupancy this year as new visitors to Graton Resort & Casino and existing casino guests experience our new hotel and spa offerings for the first time,\" general manager Joe Hasson said in an email. Staff members \"are already getting incredible feedback from guests who have stayed with us since debuting our hotel in November.\"\n\nHotel construction is underway in several cities, including Healdsburg, Windsor and Rohnert Park, where the 163-room Oxford Suites property already is taking reservations for June. The soon-to-be-completed hotel sits near the casino and across the street from Amy\u2019s Drive Thru on West Golf Course Drive.\n\nMore than two dozen other lodging projects have been proposed around the county. They include the planned transformation of the iconic Empire Building in downtown Santa Rosa\u2019s Old Courthouse Square into a 62-room hotel and the construction of a 132-room Cambria Hotel & Suites in Rohnert Park. Choice Hotels International of Rockville, Maryland, last week announced the latter project, which is slated to be built about a half-mile from the casino and open in 2019.\n\nTourism officials expect the county this year to once more host a number of events that draw large numbers of guests. The first such event comes Friday with the limited release of Pliny the Younger at Russian River Brewing Co. in downtown Santa Rosa. \n\nLast year, the two-week release of the world-famous beer drew more than 16,000 people to Russian River and generated nearly $5 million in economic activity, according to the county\u2019s Economic Development Board. Downtown Santa Rosa this year also will host two Ironman competitions, the 70.3 Vineman in May and a full-distance Ironman in late July. The latter includes a swim of 2.4 miles, a cycling segment of 112 miles and a run of 26.2 miles.\n\nThe Vineman previously had been held in Windsor. A spokesman for the Ironman organization said each competition should draw more than 5,000 visitors, and the newly renovated Old Courthouse Square will be an ideal location to host the events.\n\n\"The move of the event to downtown Santa Rosa provides the iconic finish for the athletes,\" Keats McGonigal, the group\u2019s senior regional director for North America, said in a statement.\n\nA question remains regarding how long the county\u2019s hospitality business can keep growing.\n\nThis year presents some relatively minor bumps in the road. They include the temporary closure of much of San Francisco\u2019s Moscone Center for renovation, a move that could decrease the number of conventiongoers coming to the Bay Area this year even as it increases competition by San Francisco hoteliers for smaller group gatherings, the same events Sonoma County typically seeks to attract.\n\nAlso, the strong dollar may continue to discourage international travel to the U.S., though California seems to be faring better in attracting foreign tourists than other parts of the country.\n\nNonetheless, there will be pressures to raise prices, officials said.\n\nFirst, the county\u2019s labor market \"is extraordinarily tight,\" Rogers said, which could cause hospitality business owners to raise wages to attract workers.\n\nSecond, many companies will be raising pay anyway in compliance with the state\u2019s minimum wage law.\n\nLynn Mohrfeld, president and CEO of the California Lodging and Hotel Association, told hotel operators in Santa Rosa last week that minimum wage hikes historically were one-time events, which then gave businesses several years in which to pass on costs to consumers. \n\nBut starting this year, the state is raising the minimum wage from 50 cents to $1 an hour every year until it reaches $15 an hour in 2022.\n\nThe next few years will still be strong for the hotel industry, Mohrfeld said after his speech to the annual meeting of the Sonoma County Lodging Association. But starting next year, occupancy rates may flatten even as the room rates continue to rise.\n\n\"I would say that this is probably going to be the high-water mark,\" he said.\n\nAs the hospitality industry has continued to grow, more county residents have raised concerns about its impacts. Some have complained about the effect of short-term vacation rentals on their neighborhoods. Others have opposed new winery tasting rooms and event centers because of the extra traffic and noise they bring to rural areas.\n\nHospitality officials are responding. The county lodging association revised its mission statement this year to call for the initiation of \"a vibrant exchange of ideas to ensure tourism\u2019s positive impact within Sonoma County.\"\n\nAnd Sonoma County Tourism, the county\u2019s main hospitality group, said it plans to increase community engagement efforts.\n\n\"The industry as a whole is mindful of the impacts of tourism on the local community,\" said Tim Zahner, the group\u2019s chief marketing officer. Part of the discussion will be to describe the positive impacts on the county, he said. But the community needs to see hospitality as a sustainable part of the county\u2019s economic and social life.\n\nAs such, he said, tourism officials will endeavor to speak with residents and \"hear more about what\u2019s going on and how we can assist.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"ROBERT DIGITALE"},"topics":[{"name":"Airline industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Hospitality industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Las Vegas news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"San Francisco Bay Area news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Sonoma County hotels, airlines enjoy surge of visitors","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396122993","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EMBASSIES & CONSULATES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EXTORTION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"FOREIGN RELATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"NATIONAL SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"DIPLOMATIC SERVICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"COLD WAR","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTELLIGENCE SERVICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"592","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396122993&p=2kx&v=1&x=2uIQEJnwbS_U7KGApBTEwQ","id":"29396122993","content":"| The ongoing revelations about the president\u2019s potential vulnerability to Russian influence are unprecedented. My personal professional experience may help to place this in some context.\n\nI served for 30 years in the U.S. Foreign Service, from 1970 to 2000. During that time, my colleagues and I witnessed the transitions of six U.S. presidents and at least eight secretaries of state. I served at three embassies and two consulates on three continents. I worked with intelligence officers at every post, and I think it will be useful to offer a brief description of that function at a U.S. overseas mission.\n\nSimply stated, the purpose of intelligence gathering is to provide our government with as much information about foreign governments and their policies and intentions as possible. Contrary to some current perceptions, this cannot be done solely using technology. Bugs and drones cannot reveal intentions. Ultimately, there is no substitute for information provided by human beings in positions to provide it.\n\nHow this is attained is not just the stuff of Hollywood \u2014 and the end of the Cold War has not changed anything. In general, all national intelligence agencies function similarly. Foreign government officials, businessmen, academicians and media figures are all targets.\n\nI worked with CIA officers whose task was to identify host country nationals who were in positions, or who might attain positions later, in which they had information useful or vital to our national security. The process of identifying possible sources might take months, or years, but once identified as a likely source, a different officer, sent from Washington would make the \"pitch.\" Should the target refuse, he or she was thus not able to identify who initially identified him or her.\n\nDuring the Cold War, ideology was frequently the motivation for recruiting, but if the target was considered sufficiently important, money and other incentives would be offered. Creating a compromising situation could be used if necessary, and pure blackmail was the ultimate option. Such a trap could be initiated in a mundane fashion: dinner. Sports tickets. A bottle of Scotch. Even a small loan for a vacation. We were trained and expected to report even the most trivial contact.\n\nMarital problems and tax or financial issues were vulnerable areas, but the idea that any of the gifts were offered because \"they must like me\" would be greeted with scorn or hilarity. In the very rare event that one was compromised and sensitive information was requested, there were two obvious reactions: One was to roll over and submit to being used in hopes the material would never be used. The other was to deny the accusations and try to denigrate the source of the charges and demand that the source be revealed.\n\nRegarding sources, I\u2019m amazed at the reluctance to understand why such sources need to be protected and not made public. Revealing the source not only ends the source\u2019s usefulness and makes it more difficult to persuade others in the future, but it also reveals how the information was acquired. Even the legendary Enigma/Ultra code breakers allowed setbacks and even loss of life to protect a source that was so irreplaceable.\n\nIf any of this sets off alarm bells, it should. For a foreign intelligence officer, compromising a senior U.S. government official, let alone the head of state, would be considered a virtual fantasy. But what I have described above is the precise work that Vladimir Putin did for 30 years.\n\nDean Dizikes worked for three decades in the U.S. foreign service, serving in embassies in Germany, Iran and other countries. He lives in Petaluma.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"DEAN DIZIKES"},"topics":[{"name":"Russia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Close to Home: The risk of getting too cozy with Russia","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Sonoma","zipCode":"95401","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Santa Rosa","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Press Democrat","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169660830","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Press Democrat","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.pdpreps.com/","http://www.northbaybusinessjournal.com/","http://lists.northbaybusinessjournal.com/index.htm","http://www.biteclubeats.com/","http://www.celebratecommunity.org/","http://www.northbaycarsearch.com/","http://www.capublicnotice.com/","http://www.pdmediasource.com/","http://santarosapressdemocrat.ca.newsmemory.com/ssindex.php"],"sequenceId":"695202785503","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:30Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com/csp/mediapool/sites/dt.common.streams.StreamServer.cls?STREAMOID=v_InXxAia4s1839hEyYY$c$daE2N3K4ZzOUsqbU5sYvqNFFf7t87WxCfGafdMCiBWCsjLu883Ygn4B49Lvm9bPe2QeMKQdVeZmXF$9l$4uCZ8QDXhaHEp3rvzXRJFdy0KqPHLoMevcTLo3h8xh70Y6N_U_CryOsw6FTOdKL_jpQ-&CONTENTTYPE=image/jpeg"}],"video":[]}}

The local Women\u2019s March on Jan. 21 was the most visible outcry, but there is much more evolving locally.\n\nWe will not be dragged back to our racist, homophobic, patriarchal past. We must continue to move forward, and we expect our elected representatives to join us.\n\nIf the rhetoric coming from Washington is to be believed, the people of this county will find themselves facing unjust laws that violate civil rights. And just as the colonists did, we must say, \"No!\"\n\nRecently, 70 people from all walks of life came together to craft a statement that would go to all of our county\u2019s elected representatives, letting them know that we expect them to protect all the people of Sonoma County.\n\nI grew up hearing people of all political persuasions say, \"Never again\" and \"How did the German people let this happen?\" In remembrance of 1930s Germany and what happened under the watch of the German people and their local governments, the statement is called \"It won\u2019t happen here.\"\n\nTo date, 114 civic organizations, faith communities and businesses have endorsed the \"It won\u2019t happen here\" statement. An online petition now includes the signatures of 1,300 people, and we haven\u2019t begun to count the paper petitions.\n\nThese are not normal times. We are certain that people, including our representatives, will make extraordinary efforts to be on the right side of history.\n\nThe immigrant community and others targeted by Donald Trump are bringing \"Welcoming Cities\" initiatives to Santa Rosa and the county. We have sent our declaration to Mayor Chris Coursey in support of the city\u2019s work. There are ongoing discussions with city councils around the county. The Santa Rosa School Board wrote its safe haven declaration after hearing from us and others.\n\nThe Sonoma County Commission on Human Rights wrote its \"Resolution in Support of the Protection of the Human and Constitutional Rights of All Members of the Sonoma County Community\" after reading our statement and a resolution passed by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors. The commission members will now take it to the Sonoma County Board of Supervisors. We support rewritings which maintain the spirit of our statement.\n\nEarlier this month, the Community Advisory Council of the Independent Office of Law Enforcement Review and Outreach overwhelmingly endorsed the \"It won\u2019t happen here\" declaration and will send it to the Sheriff\u2019s Office.\n\nWe are beginning to see how rapidly the Trump administration plans to undo the human rights gains of the past 50 years. That is unacceptable.\n\nGov. Jerry Brown has been defiant in defense of the people in California. Resistance from the state must be bolstered by local support and the strength of all of it depends upon the strength of the people. We can and should resist. We can and should say, \"It won\u2019t happen here.\"\n\nHere is what the \"It won\u2019t happen here\" statement says:\n\nWhereas, to safeguard the equal and inalienable rights and inherent dignity of all people that are the foundation of the relationship between a government and the people;\n\nAnd, whereas, we recognize that the rights and dignity of all people are under threat;\n\nWe, the undersigned organizations, call upon all Sonoma County governing authorities and law enforcement agencies to pledge in writing to protect all of the county\u2019s community members; Furthermore, we call upon these authorities and agencies to proclaim publicly that they will refuse to cooperate with any demands from the federal government to institute detentions, deportations, registries, conversion therapies, imprisonment or any other acts that target or discriminate based on immigration status, race, ethnicity, religion, country of origin, ability, political affiliation, economic status, age, gender-identity or sexual orientation;\n\nFurthermore, we, the undersigned organizations, in obedience to our consciences, pledge to protect all community members and will support our local governments as they move to resist these undemocratic and un-American practices in order to reaffirm their commitment to inclusivity, respect and dignity.\n\nSusan Lamont, former president of USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"558","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396123036&p=2kx&v=1&x=ro8SRFf3k1qyrR28fLQ2-A","id":"29396123036","content":"Santa Rosa City Schools, the largest school district in Sonoma County, is marching toward insolvency.\n\nStructural budget deficits are growing by about $1 million a year and, barring big changes, reserve funds will be exhausted within three years.\n\nIt is, in short, a budget crisis.\n\nAnd district officials, beginning with the Board of Education, deserve an F on their report cards for failing in their obligation to share this information with the public in a clear and timely fashion.\n\nNot a word was mentioned during the recently concluded school board election.\n\nNor is there a member of the school board, a parent or any other representative of the public on a committee of principals, administrators and union representatives that was quietly appointed last summer to study the district\u2019s options.\n\nThe most thorough update came at the end of a four-hour board meeting in mid-December \u2014 the first for three new members elected in November.\n\nIt\u2019s unlikely, at best, that anyone perusing the meeting agenda would have identified \"First Interim Report for Fiscal Year 2016-17\" as the late-night blockbuster that it proved to be.\n\nHere\u2019s a brief summary:\n\nThe deficit for 2016-17 is $10.7 million in a budget of $180 million, followed by projected deficits of $7.9 million in 2017-2018 and $11 million in 2018-19. \n\nDistrict enrollment is basically flat, but a decline in elementary school enrollment is masked by increased enrollment in charter schools, which are funded separately.\n\nSanta Rosa City Schools will experience \"staggering\" increases in retirement costs for teaching and non-teaching employees over the next several years, according to a financial consultant hired by the district. By 2020-21, payments to the California Public Employees Retirement System and the California State Teachers Retirement System will eat up 20 percent of payroll dollars \u2014 about double the level in 2014-15.\n\nTo remain solvent, and to comply with a state law requiring school districts to maintain a reserve equal to 3 percent of general fund spending, Santa Rosa schools must make budget adjustments \u2014 that\u2019s a euphemism for spending cuts and/or tax increases \u2014 totaling $4 million for 2017-18 and $2 million more for 2018-19.\n\nAt that point, consultant Terry Ryland told the school board, \"we\u2019re still deficit spending, but it gets us down to where we meet our 3 percent reserve.\"\n\nThe district\u2019s financial situation was exacerbated by million-dollar accounting mistakes that apparently resulted in the departure of two top administrators in recent weeks.\n\nIt appears that the bookkeeping mistakes have been rectified, but the district hasn\u2019t credibly addressed its systemic problems.\n\nAfter listening to Ryland\u2019s Dec. 14 report, without comment on questions, and receiving a vague report from the special budget committee, which made suggestions including attracting more students and seeking a parcel tax, the board unanimously declared that it had met its legal obligation to adopt a sustainable spending plan.\n\nSonoma County school Superintendent Steve Herrington, whose responsibilities include oversight of school district budgets, grudgingly accepted that conclusion but warned Santa Rosa school officials that they need to be much more specific about their plans for erasing the deficit.\n\nIn 2014, Santa Rosa voters taxed themselves to pay for $229 million in capital improvements to local schools \u2014 money that cannot be used for day-to-day operations. At least one school board member is on record advocating a parcel tax to help balance the books. But the district\u2019s elected and appointed leaders will need to be far more forthcoming, and establish a more transparent process, if they expect voters to bail them out.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"San Francisco Bay Area news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"PD Editorial: A brewing fiscal crisis for Santa Rosa schools","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Sonoma","zipCode":"95401","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Santa Rosa","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Press Democrat","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169660830","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Press Democrat","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.pdpreps.com/","http://www.northbaybusinessjournal.com/","http://lists.northbaybusinessjournal.com/index.htm","http://www.biteclubeats.com/","http://www.celebratecommunity.org/","http://www.northbaycarsearch.com/","http://www.capublicnotice.com/","http://www.pdmediasource.com/","http://santarosapressdemocrat.ca.newsmemory.com/ssindex.php"],"sequenceId":"695202786160","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:30Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com/csp/mediapool/sites/dt.common.streams.StreamServer.cls?STREAMOID=MeVzOcof3EEXUKnuAuGauc$daE2N3K4ZzOUsqbU5sYswTG6DQLvd7RRlZZRNnqXkWCsjLu883Ygn4B49Lvm9bPe2QeMKQdVeZmXF$9l$4uCZ8QDXhaHEp3rvzXRJFdy0KqPHLoMevcTLo3h8xh70Y6N_U_CryOsw6FTOdKL_jpQ-&CONTENTTYPE=image/jpeg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29375382745","companies":[{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":2,"exchange":"BER","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":2,"exchange":"STU","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":2,"exchange":"DUS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":2,"exchange":"MUN","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":2,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":2,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYTAB","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":2,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501114044"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TARIFFS & DUTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"OBAMA HEALTH CARE REFORM","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"JOB CREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"BUDGET DEFICITS","domains":["IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"IMPORT TRADE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"GOODS & SERVICES TRADE BALANCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"DEFENSE SPENDING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"TAXES & TAXATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS; RECESSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"MANUFACTURING FACILITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"74"},{"name":"FREE TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"US SOCIAL SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL TRADE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"CAPITAL MOVEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"MANUFACTURING OUTPUT","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"HEALTH INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS; INTEREST RATES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"US DOLLAR","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"65"},{"name":"MEDICARE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"JIMMY CARTER","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"PAUL KRUGMAN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"74"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"77"},{"name":"RONALD REAGAN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"808","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396123055&p=2kx&v=1&x=zRFfTT2nQb3yGFowBMnCYQ","id":"29396123055","content":"(1 of ) An abandoned building in Monessen, Pa. (JEFF SWENSEN / New York Times) (2 of ) Paul Krugman | Donald Trump will break most of his campaign promises. Which promises will he keep?\n\nThe answer, I suspect, has more to do with psychology than it does with strategy. Trump is much more enthusiastic about punishing people than he is about helping them. He may have promised not to cut Social Security and Medicare, or take health insurance away from the tens of millions who gained coverage under Obamacare, but in practice he seems perfectly willing to satisfy his party by destroying the safety net.\n\nOn the other hand, he appears serious about his eagerness to reverse America\u2019s 80-year-long commitment to expanding world trade. On Thursday, the White House said it was considering a 20 percent tariff on all imports from Mexico; doing so wouldn\u2019t just pull the U.S. out of NAFTA, it would violate all our trading agreements.\n\nWhy does he want this? Because he sees international trade the way he sees everything else: as a struggle for dominance, in which you only win at somebody else\u2019s expense.\n\nHis inaugural address made that perfectly clear: \"For many decades we\u2019ve enriched foreign industry at the expense of American industry.\" And he sees punitive tariffs as a way to stop foreigners from selling us stuff, and thereby revive the \"rusted-out factories scattered like tombstones across the landscape.\"\n\nUnfortunately, as just about any economist could tell him \u2014 but probably not within his three-minute attention span \u2014 it doesn\u2019t work that way. Even if tariffs lead to a partial reversal of the long decline in manufacturing employment, they won\u2019t add jobs on net, just shift employment around. And they probably won\u2019t even do that: Taken together, the new regime\u2019s policies will probably lead to a faster, not slower, decline in American manufacturing.\n\nHow do we know this? We can look at the underlying economic logic, and we can also look at what happened during the Reagan years, which in some ways represent a dress rehearsal for what\u2019s coming.\n\nNow, I\u2019m talking about the reality of Reagan, not the Republicans\u2019 legend, which assigns all blame for the early-1980s recession to Jimmy Carter and all credit for the subsequent recovery to the sainted Ronald. In fact, that whole cycle had almost nothing to do with Reagan policies.\n\nWhat Reagan did do, however, was blow up the budget deficit with military spending and tax cuts. This drove up interest rates, which drew in foreign capital. The inflow of capital, in turn, led to a stronger dollar, which made U.S. manufacturing uncompetitive. The trade deficit soared \u2014 and the long-term decline in the share of manufacturing in overall employment accelerated sharply.\n\nNotably, it was under Reagan that talk of \"deindustrialization\" and the use of the term \"Rust Belt\" first became widespread.\n\nIt\u2019s also worth pointing out that the Reagan-era manufacturing decline took place despite a significant amount of protectionism, especially a quota on Japanese car exports to the United States that ended up costing consumers more than $30 billion in today\u2019s prices.\n\nWill we repeat this story? The Trump regime will clearly blow up the deficit, mainly through tax cuts for the rich. (Funny, isn\u2019t it, how all the deficit scolds have gone quiet?) True, this may not boost spending very much, since the rich will save much of their windfall while the poor and the middle class will face harsh benefits cuts. Still, interest rates have risen in anticipation of the borrowing surge, and so has the dollar. So we do seem to be following the Reagan playbook for shrinking manufacturing. It\u2019s true that Trump appears ready to practice a much more extreme form of protectionism than Reagan, who avoided outright violations of existing trade deals. This could help some manufacturing industries. But it will also drive the dollar higher, hurting others.\n\nAnd there\u2019s a further factor to consider: The world economy has gotten a lot more complex over the past three decades. These days, hardly anything is simply \"made in America,\" or for that matter \"made in China\": Manufacturing is a global enterprise, in which cars, planes and so on are assembled from components produced in multiple countries.\n\nWhat will happen to this enterprise if the United States takes a meat ax to the agreements that govern international trade? There will, inevitably, be huge dislocation: Some U.S. factories and communities will benefit, but others will be hurt, bigly, by the loss of markets, crucial components or both.\n\nEconomists talk about the \"China shock,\" the disruption of some communities by surging Chinese exports in the 2000s. Well, the coming Trump shock will be at least as disruptive.\n\nAnd the biggest losers, as with health care, will be white working-class voters who were foolish enough to believe that Donald Trump was on their side.\n\nPaul Krugman is a columnist for the New York Times.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"PAUL KRUGMAN"},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Krugman: Making the Rust Belt rustier","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Sonoma","zipCode":"95401","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Santa Rosa","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Press Democrat","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169660830","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Press Democrat","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.pdpreps.com/","http://www.northbaybusinessjournal.com/","http://lists.northbaybusinessjournal.com/index.htm","http://www.biteclubeats.com/","http://www.celebratecommunity.org/","http://www.northbaycarsearch.com/","http://www.capublicnotice.com/","http://www.pdmediasource.com/","http://santarosapressdemocrat.ca.newsmemory.com/ssindex.php"],"sequenceId":"695202786429","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:30Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com/csp/mediapool/sites/dt.common.streams.StreamServer.cls?STREAMOID=yqi7mHeCuzSmUVOjc5JaeM$daE2N3K4ZzOUsqbU5sYvJ6mWi8QgaIcoNxez8bx3EWCsjLu883Ygn4B49Lvm9bPe2QeMKQdVeZmXF$9l$4uCZ8QDXhaHEp3rvzXRJFdy0KqPHLoMevcTLo3h8xh70Y6N_U_CryOsw6FTOdKL_jpQ-&CONTENTTYPE=image/jpeg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29370676695","companies":[{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"DUS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"BER","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"STU","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"GHC","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"GRADE INFLATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CONSULTING SERVICES","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"TEACHING & TEACHERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US NAVY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"TUITION FEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"RESEARCH REPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CHICAGO, IL, USA; UNITED STATES; ILLINOIS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"53"}],"wordCount":"743","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396123056&p=2kx&v=1&x=RSt5razs5S9J9f4BRIzfYQ","id":"29396123056","content":"(2 of ) George Will\n\nIn 2013, a college student assigned to research a deadly substance sought help via Twitter: \"I can\u2019t find the chemical and physical properties of sarin gas someone please help me.\" An expert at a security consulting firm tried to be helpful, telling her that sarin is not gas. She replied, \"yes the (expletive) it is a gas you ignorant (expletive). sarin is a liquid & can evaporate \u2026 shut the (expletive) up.\"\n\nTom Nichols, professor at the U.S. Naval War College and the Harvard Extension School, writing in the Chronicle Review, says such a \"storm of outraged ego\" is an increasingly common phenomenon among students who, having been taught to regard themselves as peers of their teachers, \"take correction as an insult.\" Nichols relates this to myriad intellectual viruses thriving in academia. Carried by undereducated graduates, these viruses infect the nation\u2019s civic culture.\n\nSoon the results include the presidential megaphone being used to amplify facially preposterous assertions, e.g., that upward of 5 million illegal votes were cast in 2016. A presidential minion thinks this assertion is justified because it is the president\u2019s \"long-standing belief.\"\n\n\"College, in an earlier time,\" Nichols writes, \"was supposed to be an uncomfortable experience because growth is always a challenge,\" replacing youthful simplicities with adult complexities. Today, college involves the \"pampering of students as customers,\" particularly by grade inflation in a context of declining academic rigor: A recent study showed \"A\" to be the most commonly awarded grade, 30 percent more frequent than in 1960. And a 2011 University of Chicago study found that 45 percent of students said that in the previous semester none of their courses required more than 20 pages of writing and 32 percent had no class that required more than 40 pages of reading in a week.\n\n\"Unearned praise and hollow successes,\" Nichols says, \"build a fragile arrogance in students that can lead them to lash out at the first teacher or employer who dispels that illusion, a habit that carries over into a resistance to believe anything inconvenient or challenging in adulthood.\" A habit no doubt intensified when adults in high places speak breezily of \"alternative facts.\"\n\n\"Rather than disabuse students of their intellectual solipsism,\" Nichols says, \"the modern university reinforces it,\" producing students given to \"taking offense at everything while believing anything.\" Many colleges and universities, competing for tuition dollars \"too often drawn thoughtlessly from an inexhaustible well of loans,\" market a \"college experience\" rather than an education. The experience \"turns into five and, increasingly, six (years).\" Nichols notes that \"the fragility of 21st-century students\" results from \"the swaddling environment of the modern university\" that \"infantilizes students\" who demand \"trigger warnings\" and \"safe spaces.\"\n\nMuch attention has been given to the non-college-educated voters who rallied to Trump. Insufficient attention is given to the role of the college miseducated. They, too, are complicit in our current condition because they emerged from their expensive \"college experiences\" neither disposed nor able to conduct civil, informed arguments. They are thus disarmed when confronted by political people who consider evidence, data and reasoning to be mere conveniences and optional.\n\nFor all the talk in high places about emancipating the many from \"the elites,\" political philosopher Walter Berns was right: The question always is not whether elites will govern but which elites will. And a republic\u2019s challenge is to increase the likelihood that the many will consent to governance by worthy elites. So, how is our republic doing? What is most alarming about the president and his accomplices in the dissemination of factoids is not that they do not know this or that. And it is not that they do not know what they do not know. Rather, it is that they do not know what it is to know something.\n\nThe republican form of government rests on representation: The people do not decide issues, they decide who will decide. Who, that is, will conduct the deliberations that \"refine and enlarge\" public opinion (Madison, Federalist 10). This system of filtration is vitiated by a plebiscitary presidency, the occupant of which claims a direct, unmediated, almost mystical connection with \"the people.\"\n\nSoon, presidential enablers, when challenged about their employer\u2019s promiscuous use of \"alternative facts,\" will routinely use last week\u2019s \"justification\" of the illegal voting factoid: It is the president\u2019s \"long-standing belief,\" so there. In his intellectual solipsism, he, too, takes correction as an insult. He resembles many of his cultured despisers in the academy more than he or they realize.\n\nGeorge Will is a columnist for the Washington Post.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"WASHINGTON POST WRITERS GROUP"},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"An excess of intellectual emptiness","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Sonoma","zipCode":"95401","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Santa Rosa","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Press Democrat","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169660830","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Press Democrat","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.pdpreps.com/","http://www.northbaybusinessjournal.com/","http://lists.northbaybusinessjournal.com/index.htm","http://www.biteclubeats.com/","http://www.celebratecommunity.org/","http://www.northbaycarsearch.com/","http://www.capublicnotice.com/","http://www.pdmediasource.com/","http://santarosapressdemocrat.ca.newsmemory.com/ssindex.php"],"sequenceId":"695202786602","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:30Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.pressdemocrat.com/csp/mediapool/sites/dt.common.streams.StreamServer.cls?STREAMOID=aApRBP5GAeHOONvVquYJGc$daE2N3K4ZzOUsqbU5sYttUsoXHepbzrmmMXEG9t9lWCsjLu883Ygn4B49Lvm9bPe2QeMKQdVeZmXF$9l$4uCZ8QDXhaHEp3rvzXRJFdy0KqPHLoMevcTLo3h8xh70Y6N_U_CryOsw6FTOdKL_jpQ-&CONTENTTYPE=image/jpeg"}],"video":[]}}

TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"HOUSTON, TX, USA; UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"70"},{"name":"HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"BARACK OBAMA","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"}],"wordCount":"846","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396123058&p=2kx&v=1&x=XO9ScSvxHWWw0hYvF8MH-Q","id":"29396123058","content":"(1 of ) GARY VARVEL / Indianapolis Star (2 of ) Pete Golis | While my Democratic friends are busy trying to navigate their confusion and despair, my Republican friends aren\u2019t saying much about Donald Trump.\n\nIt is awkward to talk about him, isn\u2019t it? Maybe they\u2019re being polite, maybe they worry Trump will do something to cause them to regret their votes, maybe they didn\u2019t vote for him. I don\u2019t know. \n\nIf we\u2019re cautioned not to discuss religion or politics in polite company during normal times, what do we do in the age of President Trump? Nice weather we\u2019re having today. \n\nIn Sonoma County, of course, Republicans are outnumbered. Only 1 in 5 local voters cast a vote for Trump in November. More people are registered as decline-to-state than are registered as Republicans.\n\nLast week\u2019s anti-Trump march in Santa Rosa, perhaps the biggest political demonstration ever in Sonoma County, testifies to the widespread fear and anxiety among Democrats \u2014 not to mention a palpable sense of disbelief. \n\nPolitical views aside, Democrats remain flummoxed by the idea that millions of Americans would vote for a person who has so many unredeeming qualities. \n\nIn social settings and business meetings, too, have you noticed that people are reluctant to speak his name until they can\u2019t stand it any longer? Then the same questions come spilling out: Is it OK to talk about this here? How could this happen? What do we do now?\n\nIt\u2019s worth noting that we are only having this conversation because a relative handful of voters in Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania didn\u2019t vote or switched from Barack Obama in 2012 to Trump to 2016. In a divided country, small shifts in the electorate can cause dramatic changes in the way the country is governed, and if you don\u2019t believe it, you\u2019re not paying attention. \n\nDespite all the hand wringing, we know a lot about the majority of Trump voters. \n\nThey tend to be older, white and male. Many have voted for Republicans for their entire lives, just as their parents before them and their parents before them. \n\nMost Trump voters don\u2019t live in big cities. Only 1 in 10 voters in Manhattan voted for him, and only 1 in 10 in San Francisco, too. Trump won Texas, but Hillary Clinton won Dallas and Houston.\n\nTrump voters subscribe to what might be called the new Republican orthodoxy. \n\nThey don\u2019t like the way the country is changing, whether the changes involve immigration, social programs, abortion, identity politics, regulation or corporate efforts to control costs (and prices) by offshoring jobs. \n\nThey blame politicians, and they want the government run by politicians to be turned upside-down.\n\nYou know the rest. \n\nThey think they pay too much in taxes. They want to roll back laws intended to protect health, safety and the environment (laws they view as wasteful and ineffective). They distrust efforts intended to level the playing field for women and minorities. \n\nSome also believe a smaller government should still find the resources to round up and deport 11 million people. Some believe iPhones can be made in Petaluma (never mind that a minimum wage worker in California is paid three times what a worker in an iPhone factory in China is paid). If Democrats don\u2019t understand what Trump voters could be thinking, the same could be said for Republicans who could never imagine voting for Hillary Clinton. \n\nTo avoid dealing with some of Trump\u2019s more incendiary statements, Trump voters say they \"take him seriously but not literally.\" In the coming months, they will find out whether their trust was justified.\n\nAll these are generalizations, of course. People carry around different combinations of reasons for voting the way they vote. But most of the Republican voters I know would agree with most of these characterizations. Many would also agree that while they voted for Trump, they worry about what happens now.\n\nOh, and one more thing: Trump supporters share the conviction that their critics in places like California and New York can be condescending jerks. This is important, I think. There is no reason to be surprised that people don\u2019t like being called all the names \u2014 racist, xenophobe, sexist, homophobe, deplorables \u2014 that have been thrown at Trump\u2019s supporters.\n\nIn a 2014 column, after exploring the Central Valley and eastern California, I wrote this:\n\n\"There is a sense of isolation in these towns, not just physical isolation, but economic and political isolation as well. Some choose to live here to escape the hustle, hype and conformity of urban areas.\n\n\"But there\u2019s also a belief that their values aren\u2019t shared by other Californians \u2014 a belief that government is denying to them the right to live as they choose.\"\n\nFrom Bakersfield to Alturas, no one should be surprised that these were the areas of California that voted for Trump. This was their opportunity for vindication and for pay-back \u2014 and they grabbed it.\n\nSurveying the distance between Santa Rosa and Bakersfield, we are reminded again that there are two Americas now \u2014 one prosperous, one less so \u2014 each with very different ideas about the present and the future.\n\nPete Golis is a columnist for The Press Democrat. Email him at golispd@gmail.com.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"PETE GOLIS"},"topics":[{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Golis: Donald J. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"reg","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29382725955","companies":[{"symbol":"TRCO","primary":true,"name":"Tribune Media Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US8960475031"},{"symbol":"TRBAB","primary":true,"name":"Tribune Media Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US8960476021"},{"symbol":"TM9","primary":true,"name":"Tribune Media Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US8960475031"},{"symbol":"TRBCQ","primary":true,"name":"Tribune Media Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US8960473051"},{"symbol":"TM9","primary":true,"name":"Tribune Media Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"STU","titleCount":0,"isin":"US8960475031"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PENSION & RETIREMENT PLANS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PENSION & RETIREMENT PLANS; US 401K PLANS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"STOCK INDEXES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"RETIREMENT & RETIREES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"RETIREMENT AGE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"882","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396123327&p=2kx&v=1&x=dcEQNVDQa51bgWdvW6nkIA","id":"29396123327","content":"Do you have Dow 20,000 envy? \n\nTake heart, you might be richer than you think. \n\nYou may have wished during all the hype over the Dow Jones industrial average hitting 20,000 that you had been buying stocks. \n\nBut you may actually own stocks without knowing it. If you've been dutifully putting a little money into a 401(k) or other retirement fund at work without paying attention to where it goes, you may very well have a good chunk in the stock market. It's become common in the last couple of years for large companies with 401(k)s to simply route a little of every employee's paycheck into what's known as a target-date fund. And if you have one of these funds, you do own stocks and you've become a little richer as the stock market has soared 10 percent since Donald Trump was elected president. \n\nOn average the stock market climbs 10 percent during an entire year, so making 10 percent in just a couple of months is unusual. During all of 2016, the stock market gained about 12 percent - a very good year. \n\nSo you've done well if you've been working at a place that's been putting your money in one of these funds for several months or years. Consider a worker who is now about 25, with a fund that is set up for a person who is going to retire in roughly 40 years. That fund might have the number 2055 in the name, because it's designed for a person retiring at around 65 years old - give or take a couple of years. If you had $1,000 in one of those funds on the day of the presidential election, you'd likely have about $1,060 now, according to Morningstar. \n\nOver long periods of time, the impact of the stock market is even more pronounced. A person who had about $10,000 in one of these funds 10 years ago and then never added another penny would have over $18,000 now, according to Morningstar. \n\nHow does this happen? \n\nIf you pick a target-date fund on your own, or if your employer picks it for your workplace 401(k) based on the year you will approach retirement age, most of your money will be put into the stock market. \n\nAt about age 25, about 80 percent of your money will be deposited into the stock market, because young people get the biggest bang for their buck in the stock market and can recover later if stocks become losers for a while. The other 20 percent goes into bonds. \n\nFor people within a few years of retiring, the funds geared for retirement take a different approach. They ratchet back stock exposure in favor of investing options that are more conservative, putting only about 60 percent of your money in the fund into stocks. The reason is that stocks don't always climb like they have during the last few months, and if they go into a losing period, people on the verge of retiring might not have time to wait for another benevolent period. \n\nSo let's assume you are about 25 and started 2016 with $1,000 in the fund and didn't add another penny during the year. The fund manager handling your money would have put $800 of your money in stocks and $200 in bonds at the beginning of 2016. And now you'd have about $1,160. Most of the increase in your money would have come from the stock market. During 2016 alone, money in the stock market grew by about 12 percent, while bond gains were tiny by comparison - only about 2.6 percent. \n\nBonds are for fear \n\nIf you are like most people, you like making money. So after watching the celebration of Dow 20,000, you might conclude that you should put every penny of your savings in stocks. But there's a reason why a fund designed for someone at 25 has about 20 percent of the money invested in bonds, rather than using only stocks: Not all time periods are like the present, and you never know when the stock market will turn cruel. \n\nAbout every five years, and when no one is expecting it, a cruel period shows up called a \"bear market.\" It can destroy a lot of your money quickly and make you think it will never come back again. Historically, money lost in the stock market does come back, but it can take more than a year before you regain what's lost and start making money again. \n\nConsider the horrible bear market that came along with the housing crisis and Great Recession of 2008. The person with $10,000 invested entirely in the stock market lost so much they had only $4,980 left at one point and they were still waiting for a recovery after three years. The person with 80 percent in stocks and 20 percent in bonds didn't lose as much. At the worst point they had $5,980 of their original $10,000 left. And in a couple of years, they'd recovered and were positioned to make money again. And the person with only 60 percent in stocks at the beginning of the stock market plunge recovered in about a year and half. \n\nSo the moral of the story is you don't have to be a wallflower during the Dow 20,000 celebration - but party in moderation. \n\nABOUT THE WRITER \n\nGail MarksJarvis is a personal finance columnist for the Chicago Tribune and author of \"Saving for Retirement Without Living Like a Pauper or Winning the Lottery.\" Readers may send her email at gmarksjarvis@tribune.com.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"GAIL MARKSJARVISChicago Tribune"},"topics":[{"name":"Pensions news","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Personal finance news","group":"Finance"}],"title":"Gail MarksJarvis: Think you missed the Dow 20,000 party? how to instil a sense of pride, build something solid.\n\nBut instead the group awoke in this idyllic setting on Sunday morning to the ugly news that US President Donald Trump had decreed that citizens of Somalia and six other predominantly Muslim countries would be barred entry to the United States for 90 days.\n\nAnd this divisive move has taken the gloss off their special Anglesea trip.\n\n\"We are shocked, it's very disappointing,\" Mr Haraco said. \"This is banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families.\"\n\nMr Haraco, a dual citizen of Somalia and Australia, speaks from personal experience.\n\nHis mother-in-law, Nadira Tabid, raised him as her own after she married his father in Somalia.\n\nNow she lives in Houston and he had planned to visit her in July, continuing the rhythm of trips he has always made to her. From Somalia, to her last home in India, and now Texas, the state that abuts another Trump target: Mexico.\n\nMr Haraco, secretary of the Somali Australian Council of Victoria, doesn't know if he should book tickets or wait to see what unfolds when the 90-day period ends.\n\nWill the ban continue? When will he see his elderly mother-in-law again? She is over 70 now; he doesn't want to leave it too long.\n\nConfusion and concern among immigrants and refugee advocates has been widespread, with travellers detained or sent home from US airports.\n\nThere is confusion, too, among the young men that Mr Haraco has brought down to the ocean to mull over the qualities of a leader.\n\nSome have talked about finding it difficult to get a job in Melbourne because of the colour of their skin, or their religion.\n\nThe group also discussed gangs, and young people they know who are dropping out of school, drawn to these groups.\n\nBut the bigger purpose was to inspire them, says council member Abdi Aziz, and he remains convinced that Trump's ruling won't quash their enthusiasm for multiculturalism.\n\n\"Diversity is mainstream in Australia \u2026 but the risk is there. For us it's an important time for our Prime Minister to show political leadership in this area.\"\n\nMany people he had spoken to that morning were feeling a sense of loss, he said. This semi-fluid, half-lotion serum brings together a trio of hyaluronic acid, the benchmark molecule approved by dermatologists and used in optimum concentrations to effectively act on crepey and wrinkled skin . Hyaluronic acid helps to maintain optimum levels of hydration within the skin by trapping water in deep layers, in the same way as a sponge, strengthening skin cohesion and increasing firmness. Over time, hyaluronic acid contained in the body decreases by half, making WRINKLE DIMENSION an appropriate year-round solution to provide maturing and wrinkled skin with a perfect supply of hyaluronic acid for an instantly rejuvenating effect. \n \nWRINKLES DIMENSION HYALURONIC ACID CONCENTRATE...15 ml, suggested retail price $100.50 \n \nDirections for use: apply several drops before face cream, morning and evening. \n \nKey ingredients: \n \n\u2022Hyaluronic Acid Trio: \n\n Encapsulated High Molecular Weight Hyaluronic Acid - deep wrinkles are filled and hollow areas are volumized thanks to the strategic shape and controlled release of ingredient.  Low Molecular Weight Hyaluronic Acid - small molecules of hyaluronic acid penetrate skin layers, swell on contact with water and accumulate to fill fine lines, smoothing surface wrinkles.  High Molecular Weight Hyaluronic Acid - plays a vital role in regulating skin hydration thanks to its strong water-retaining power. Skin is moisturized and transepidermal water loss is stopped.  \nVie Collection at a glance : \nAs a cosmeceutical expert in the spa industry, Vie Collection is a high performance, high-end skin care line focused on bridging the gap between traditional cosmetics and esthetic medicine. We are one of few spa brands with our own laboratory which allows us to always be on the cutting-edge of scientific progress in cosmetics. We offer in-spa solutions for a spa-savvy clientele that seek medical results but prefer the use of topical products. Vie Collection has targeted, non-invasive and clinically proven alternatives and complements to the top five cosmetic medicine procedures available today. With the partnership of a prestigious French esthetic doctor, Vie Collection brings expertise, authenticity and real results in the form of expert formulations and treatments, from the finest ingredients. \n \nFor the original version on PRWeb visit: http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/01/prweb14023081.htm \n  NEXT ARTICLE  More From BioPortfolio on \" \"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Vie Collection Launches WRINKLE DIMENSION Hyaluronic Acid Concetrate","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","countryCode":"GB","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"BioPortfolio","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"279272929","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1"},"name":"BioPortfolio","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","HealthCare","Pharmaceuticals"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bioportfolio.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.viecollection.com/","http://www.lespausa.com/WRINKLES-DIMENSION-HYALURONIC-ACID-CONCENTRATE-p/700254r.htm","http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/01/prweb14023081.htm","http://www.prweb.com/","http://www.kqzyfj.com/click-5573218-12231380-1432767066000"],"sequenceId":"695202796338","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:16:35Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
